headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Textron Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference ov
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Textron Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to our VP, Investor Relations, Mr. Doug Wilburne. Please go ahead.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during the call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. 
Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during the call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our SEC filings and also in today's press release. 
On the call today, we have Scott Donnelly, Textron's Chairman and CEO; and Frank Connor, our Chief Financial Officer. Our earnings call presentation can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website.
Textron revenues in the quarter were $3.9 billion, down 4.2% from $4.1 billion in last year's fourth quarter. Income from continuing operations was $0.81 per share, up 6.6% from $0.76 in the fourth quarter of 2014.
Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions of $18 million was $534 million compared to $449 million in last year's fourth quarter.
For the full year, revenues were $13.4 billion, down 3.3% from the year-ago. Income from the continuing operations was $2.50 per share, up 16.3% from $2.15 last year. Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions of $68 million was $631 million. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, good morning, everybody. Revenue aviation overall decrease in revenue in the quarter. Despite a decline in revenues, with good exclusion with margin improvement in aviation, Systems and industrial, and saw double-digit margins Bell and str
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug, good morning, everybody. 
Revenue aviation overall decrease in revenue in the quarter. Despite a decline in revenues, with good exclusion with margin improvement in aviation, Systems and industrial, and saw double-digit margins Bell and strong cash flow across all the business segments. Bell issued 56 commercial helicopters compared to 57 in last year's fourth quarter. Commercial revenues were down, reflecting aftermarket volume and a change in mix of aircraft delivered. On the new product front, we are making good progress with our 525 Relentless program. We have now 2 aircraft in flight test the program and are preparing to bring a third aircraft in spring. We successfully obtained a top speed of 186 knots, validating the aircraft's maximum target. Although testing includes continued signal and stability testing, as well as full development of the gross weight and center of gravity extremes.
Aircraft will heading north to gather initial order data next month. continues to progress, developing phase of the test program, we are preparing to enter into certification test phase in the spring.
We also plan to 525 to Heli-Expo in the Louisville in March so that our customers can see the actual aircraft for the first time. Overall, the aircraft continued to perform very well, meeting or exceeding all of our initial performance expectations. Customer demand remained strong as we currently have about 80 letters of intent from around the world. We are targeting certification of first delivery of the 525 next year. Our 505 Jet Ranger X program is also making good progress, with 3 test aircraft now in operation. We are targeting certification and entering the service later this year. Our upgraded 407 GXP model continues to generate great reception in the marketplace, with overall 407 deliveries up 13 units in 2015. Earlier this month, we made the first delivery to air methods under the 10-year[ph] 200 unit contract that we signed at last year's Heli-Expo show.
While we're having good success on our helicopters, the medium segment of the market continued to be challenged. This is reflected in the low volume that we saw in 2015, and the outlook from unit helicopter remains soft as we look to 2016. 
On the defense side, V-22 deliveries were up in the quarter, as we delivered 8 V-22s compared to 7 a year ago. H-1 deliveries were also off as we delivered 9 units compared to 7 in the last year's fourth quarter. 
In systems, lower year-over-year revenues in the quarter were primarily the results of initial deliveries in last year's fourth quarter. This year's fourth quarter revenues include delivery of 55 COMMANDO select armored vehicles for the Afghan National Army, but did not include any Canadian TAPV deliveries as we are still conducting our internal testing.  now have completed initial testing, we'll begin the customer testing process this week. We expect that the process final will take 5 to 6 months to complete. in October, we opened our first commercial aviation maintenance training facility in Wichita, with initial courses for mechanical and avionics maintenance for the King Air, Baron and products. We also received a phase certification for both our and Fusion [indiscernible] 50 aircraft and associate simulator. We in the Tampa Center supporting initial aircraft deliveries in the quarter.
Moving to aviation. 
We delivered 60 Jets and 33 King Airs compared to 55 Jets and 41 King Airs last year. For the full year, we delivered 166 Jets, up from last year's 159, including 16 latitude deliveries. 
During the quarter, we delivered our 102, marking the success form this product in the marketplace during the 2 years it's been in service.  Most significant event during the quarter aviation was the unveiling of our new longitude and hemisphere aircraft, NBAA, in November. The customer reaction to both of these models have been very positive, and we believe they will generate substantial growth opportunities. The launch of superior operating performance compared to aircraft in its class and should provide meaningful contribution to revenue to aviation after its expected entry into service late next year. Longer term, the Hemisphere should provide to be a game changer as it will open up an entirely new market opportunity for us. With first flight targeted for 2019, we expect the Hemisphere will growth aviation as we enter next decade. We also announced details of our new single-engine turboprop, including a new 1300 shelf horsepower G turboprop engine. We're developing this aircraft product for the range of 1,500 nautical miles, speeds at over 280 knots, a larger cabin and reduced operating costs.
An important part of Textron Aviation and the Bell brand is our service footprint and after market support capabilities. In that regard, last week, able and journey component services, an innovative low-cost repair and overhaul business operated in Arizona. Able provides component repairs, component exchanges and replacement parts, along with other support and service offerings for commercial rotorcraft and fixed wing aircraft customers. This is a great extension to our aftermarket business.  
Wrapping up the quarter with Industrial, we achieved a 6.4% increase in revenues after a 5.8% negative impact from foreign exchange, reflecting strong organic growth in the quarter. At Caltex, we had solid growth, with revenues up in Europe, North America and Asia. Textron's vehicles had solid growth across all business lines, reflecting our focus on new products and the success of recent acquisitions, such as for ground support equipment businesses. 
To summarize the year. Despite decline in manufacturing revenues, we were able to achieve a 60 basis point improvement in manufacturing margins. We believe we entered the year with strong EPS and cash flow performance, especially given the challenges of the weaker-than-expected commercial helicopter market. Throughout the year, we took action that should position our businesses for growth and profitability over the next several years. At Textron Systems, we advanced our Ship to Shore program with the first 2 units in production. The targeted deliveries of 2017, the DoD exercise options for another 2 ships out of a total expected program of 73 units. At , we opened our Trent supplier training center and facility, received the King Air training certification and announced 3 additional from 737 max platform. At Industrial, our top line growth for the year reflects our continuing investment in new products, such as the Jacobsen HD, heavy-duty vehicle, the 4 x 4, and Green the something Wi-Fi system. Industrial growth also reflects the success of recent acquisitions which demonstrates our ability to leverage these businesses for growth and long-term shareholder value. At Bell, we continue to prove our win rate in the commercial helicopter market -- of our new and operated products, our industry-leading aftermarket support and our expanding sales presence around the world. On the military front, we made important progress with our order program. -- on demonstrations of each to potential domestic and foreign customers using a flight simulator to develop our teams at Bell and. Manufacturing at several operations first aircraft were well underway, and we remain on track for first flight in 2017.
Military's version or Belfour 12 model was selected for Japan's UH-X program. We've been partnering with Industries to deliver 150 aircraft beginning in 2021. We also signed contracts to deliver the first with 3 of at least 12 planned H-1 helicopters for Pakistan and the first 5 of 17 expected V-22s for Japan. Looking forward, we have a significant number of foreign opportunities for the H-1 which we are pursuing and expect to secure additional orders this year.
In Textron Aviation, last year, we began deliveries of our new Latitude, announces turboprop, 2 new business jets, and realized the full year impact of operational benefits from our Beechcraft acquisition. 
To finish with Textron's 2016 financial guidance. We're predicting revenues of about $14.3 billion, as we expect solid growth of aviation, industrial and Systems, and approximately flat revenue at Bell. We expect EPS from continuing operations between the range of $2.60 to $2.80, and manufacturing veteran cash flow before pension contributions in the range of $600 million to $700 million. 
With that, I turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $378 million, down $20 million from the fourth quarter of 2014, a $[indiscernible]million decrease in revenue. Let's review of how each of the segments performed, starting w
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $378 million, down $20 million from the fourth quarter of 2014, a $[indiscernible]million decrease in revenue. 
Let's review of how each of the segments performed, starting with Textron Aviation.
Revenues were down $32 million from this period last year, reflecting lower King Air and preowned aircraft volumes, partially offset by higher jet volumes. Aviation had a profit of $138 million compared to $130 million a year ago. This increase primarily reflected improved performance, which included lower amortization of $8 million related to fair value step-up adjustments, partially offset by the lower volumes. Backlog in the segment ended the quarter at $1.1 billion, down $308 million from the end of the third quarter.
Moving to Bell. 
Revenues were down $36 million, reflecting lower commercial aftermarket volume and a change in mix of commercial aircraft delivered in the quarter, partially offset by higher military deliveries.
Segment profit decreased $22 million from the fourth quarter of 2014, primarily reflecting an unfavorable impact from the change in mix of commercial aircraft delivered in the quarter and lower commercial aftermarket volume, partially offset by improved performance. Backlog in the segment ended the quarter at $5.2 billion, up $76 million from the end of the third quarter. 
At Textron Systems, revenues were down $158 million, primarily due to lower Unmanned Systems volume, partially offset by higher Marine & Land Systems volume. Segment profit was down $9 million, reflecting the impact of the lower volumes.
Industrial revenues increased $55 million due to higher overall volumes and the impact of acquisitions, partially offset by a $50 million unfavorable impact from foreign exchange. Segment profit increased $6 million, primarily reflecting the impact of the higher volumes.
Finance segment revenues decreased $2 million and profit decreased $3 million.
Moving below the segment profit line. 
Corporate expenses were $52 million, and our tax rate in the quarter was 23.5%. The fourth quarter tax rate benefited from the U.S. R&D tax legislation passed late in the quarter, as well as some other discrete items. 
Interest expense was $32 million, down $8 million from last year, reflecting lower debt levels. We repaid $100 million of the backlog from the Beechcraft acquisition and repurchased approximately 208,000 shares in the quarter. We ended the year with gross manufacturing debt of $2.7 billion, resulting in a year-end manufacturing debt-to-EBITDA multiple of about 1.8x. For the full year, we repurchased approximately 5.2 million shares at an overall cost of about $219 million.
Turning now to our 2016 guidance, beginning with our segments on Slide 9. 
At Textron Aviation, we're expecting about 6% revenue growth, bringing revenues to about $5.1 billion, primarily reflecting a ramp-up in Latitude deliveries. Segment margins are expected to be in the range of 8.5% to 9%. 
At Bell, we expect overall revenues will be flattish at about $3.4 billion, reflecting lower V-22 revenues, offset by higher H-1 deliveries on the military side, and essentially flat revenues in our Commercial business. We are forecasting margins in the range of 10% to 11%.
At Systems, we are estimating 2016 revenues at about $1.9 billion, up 25% from last year, reflecting the expected deliveries and good growth in most of our other Systems businesses. Segment margins are expected to be in the range of 10% to 10.5%. 
At Industrial, we're expecting solid growth in each of our businesses, resulting in a projected 7% segment revenue growth to about $3.8 billion, with estimated margins in the range of 9% to 9.9%. 
At Finance, we are forecasting segment profit of about about $15 million. 
Turning to Slide 10. 
Based on U.S. planned discount rate of 4.75%, we are estimating 2016 pension costs will be about $85 million, down from $138 million last year.
Turning to Slide 11. 
R&D is expected to be about $615 million, approximately flat with 2015. We're estimating CapEx will be about $475 million, up from last year's expenditures of $420 million, reflecting our investments in new products and geographic expansion.
Moving below the segment line, and looking at Slide 12. 
We're projecting about $155 million for corporate expense. Next year's interest expense is estimated at $133 million, reflecting higher rates on variable rate debt. We're assuming a tax rate of about 31%, as we had some items in 2015 that benefited our tax rate that we do not expect to reoccur in 2016, as well as an expected higher mix of U.S. revenues in 2016, which are taxed at higher rates. Our guidance assumes a flat share count of about 277 million shares, reflecting repurchases sufficient to offset dilution. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. So Steve, we can open the line for questions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our first question comes from the line of Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our first question comes from the line of Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you guys could touch a little bit more on the margin in aviation, flattish sequentially and kind of a fairly moderate growth planned for next year.
componenttext: I wonder if you guys could touch a little bit more on the margin in aviation, flattish sequentially and kind of a fairly moderate growth planned for next year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the sequential sort of flatness from Q3 to Q4 is largely driven by the fact that we had a fair bit of expense in the fourth quarter between R&D and a lot of costs associated with the ramp-up of what we did with for NBAA, which offset a fair bit of what
componenttext: So the sequential sort of flatness from Q3 to Q4 is largely driven by the fact that we had a fair bit of expense in the fourth quarter between R&D and a lot of costs associated with the ramp-up of what we did with for NBAA, which offset a fair bit of what we saw in some of the incremental volumes on a sequential basis. Nothing more than that. In terms of next year, the volume leverage probably is not as high as you guys would expect. I think that's largely driven by the fact that we're going to see probably some lower margin on a lot of our incremental sales, particularly that which is going into the business. So we have a fairly high number of deliveries next year. on the NetJets, you probably saw yesterday, they've announced the official launch of that product into their customer base. And typically, sales into the fractional channel are at a lower margin than our typical retail sales.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe just as a quick follow up. For Bell, I think you talked about commercial being flattish, and military, it sounds like maybe flattish as well, has been 22 down and H-1 up. I wonder if you could talk about the levels, the level of decl
componenttext: Great. And then maybe just as a quick follow up. For Bell, I think you talked about commercial being flattish, and military, it sounds like maybe flattish as well, has been 22 down and H-1 up. I wonder if you could talk about the levels, the level of decline on V-22 and kind of is this the bottom? And then what gives you confidence on kind of flat in commercial?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at the mix in the business as we go into next year, the military and commercial are both probably relatively flat. I think we saw the big drop down this year obviously with V-22 reductions earlier in the year. We'll continue partly down a l
componenttext: So if you look at the mix in the business as we go into next year, the military and commercial are both probably relatively flat. I think we saw the big drop down this year obviously with V-22 reductions earlier in the year. We'll continue partly down a little bit V-22, probably up a little bit on the H-1 side of things. So all in all, I expect to be relatively flattish, and I think the same is true on the commercial side. The big adjustment that we really made this year was a reduction in medium-sized helicopters that, you're probably about 12, 412s[ph], and we expect that to be about flat on a year-over-year basis. So I don't think there's going to be a big mix shift within the business as we look at flattish revenues. I think it's going to be true on both the military and commercial side.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so with the V-22, it's consistent with the Multiyear II, which called for 100 units over 5 years. We've been delivering a little ahead of schedule, few options exercise. So that's just consistent with that. And then as we look forward to '18 and the J
componenttext: And so with the V-22, it's consistent with the Multiyear II, which called for 100 units over 5 years. We've been delivering a little ahead of schedule, few options exercise. So that's just consistent with that. And then as we look forward to '18 and the Japanese deliveries, we should see some recovery there.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the V-22s, we totally expect it, right? I mean what we saw on the military side of the business in 2015 and what we expect in '16 is entirely consistent with what we've always talk about, I mean the programs in record in terms of the units. Now that
componenttext: Well, the V-22s, we totally expect it, right? I mean what we saw on the military side of the business in 2015 and what we expect in '16 is entirely consistent with what we've always talk about, I mean the programs in record in terms of the units. Now that there are absolutely no surprises there. The issue really was largely around the commercial side and particularly on the medium segment. Those are, for us, the 412s, that's typically a very international product. And as you can imagine, between the pressure around oil and other commodities, and just in general, international marketplace is pretty soft, and I think that's perfect overall in the Bell curve margins, so we expect that to be pretty flat as we go from '15 to '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to stick with Bell 4 just a moment here, and I'm just going to have you talk a little bit about the margin outlook and a bit more detail and talk a little bit about some of the puts and takes that are going on this year. And then as a follow
componenttext: I just wanted to stick with Bell 4 just a moment here, and I'm just going to have you talk a little bit about the margin outlook and a bit more detail and talk a little bit about some of the puts and takes that are going on this year. And then as a follow-up to that, just as we head into the Heli-Expo so in early March, maybe just talk a little bit about things you're going to be looking for into that show and kind of expectations around it.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So look, I think on the margin rate, what we've communicated to you, guys, we've been trying to hold that business at 11% to 12% rate. I think as we manage through, knowing what was going to happen on the military programs, we adjusted our cost base
componenttext: Sure. So look, I think on the margin rate, what we've communicated to you, guys, we've been trying to hold that business at 11% to 12% rate. I think as we manage through, knowing what was going to happen on the military programs, we adjusted our cost base to make sure that we could hit that target. Just in our segment level kind of color at this point, we think we're probably 100 basis points lower than that, and that's a reflection of the fact that we're seeing a significant reduction in what we would have expected in terms of the volume in the midsized market as we go forward. So there will still -- obviously, there will be some cost reductions that come associated with that as we lower the production rates and our production rates on the 412 side in particular. But to try to pick up more costs from that and sustain the investments that we need to make in the 505 and 525 and V-280, I think that's going to cost a little about 100 basis points, and that's why you see that reflection of the drop. So what we committed an internal margin and then we dealt with the fact that we're going to have this known ramp down on the military side and then further reductions that we made this year on the commercial side has sustained margins about where we want it to be. But I think this point, given where we're taking the forecast on 412s, that's probably going to cost us about 100 basis points. So as we go into Heli-Expo, look, it's going to be an interesting show to try to understand where customers are, what their expectations are going forward. 505, we continued to feel very good about. The level of customer demand in that area is great. The 407s, as I said earlier, very strong, and delivering out some big programs and a continued strong interest. 429s are kind of flattish. I think the question is really going to be, with a lot of our international customers, how they feel going forward, now 412 obviously and give us a feel of where things are going in terms of the 525. We're still 1.5 years from or so of making first orders on an aircraft, so there are still a fair bit of time here to understand what that market dynamic is going to look like.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

It just seems like you've got earnings up, pension looks like -- I know CapEx is up and depreciation is up about the same. Can you just talk about what else might be going against you why you're not seeing a bit of pick up on the cash flow on?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, if you look at the -- late next year, Sam, we're going to have a lot of inventories that were accumulating in the bills of the first lots of the 525s and also the Longitude. So we'll probably start deliveries of both those aircraft, not until 2017,
componenttext: Look, if you look at the -- late next year, Sam, we're going to have a lot of inventories that were accumulating in the bills of the first lots of the 525s and also the Longitude. So we'll probably start deliveries of both those aircraft, not until 2017, but we'll have the priming the pump, if you will, and those are fairly high dollar, big programs, it will drive our working capital late in '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We also are planning for some higher cash taxes in '16.
componenttext: Yes. We also are planning for some higher cash taxes in '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of the margin pick up at Systems next year, is that all TAPV related? Why is there such a big step up from '15 to '16?
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of the margin pick up at Systems next year, is that all TAPV related? Why is there such a big step up from '15 to '16?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, TAPV is certainly a big part of it, have that program going, but we expect we're going to see solid performance, if you look at our UAIS businesses continue to perform well. I think the momentum is very good there, similarly, in our Precisio
componenttext: Well, I mean, TAPV is certainly a big part of it, have that program going, but we expect we're going to see solid performance, if you look at our UAIS businesses continue to perform well. I think the momentum is very good there, similarly, in our Precision Initiatives business, good contracts, good backlog of healthy business. So it's really across the whole segment. And of course, our Simulation Training business which continues to perform and grow. So they're really it's not just 1 item. I mean certainly getting -- TAPV is a big driver of the revenue increase in terms of finally delivering on that, but in terms of overall margins, it's pretty solid performance across all of those business segments.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Robert Stallard of Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, there has been some signs of weakness in large cabin business jet in recent months. I was wondering about if you can comment about what you're seeing in your market at the smaller, midsized and if that?
componenttext: Scott, there has been some signs of weakness in large cabin business jet in recent months. I was wondering about if you can comment about what you're seeing in your market at the smaller, midsized and if that?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, really, a lot. I mean, we've seen not strong growth, but we've seen increased volumes in '15. We expect again to see some increased volumes as we go into 2016. But yes, it's primarily driven by new product. I would say, most Legacy models will be sort
componenttext: No, really, a lot. I mean, we've seen not strong growth, but we've seen increased volumes in '15. We expect again to see some increased volumes as we go into 2016. But yes, it's primarily driven by new product. I would say, most Legacy models will be sort of flattish, but growth of new things like Latitude coming out is really what's driving the growth in the business. So I think we see the market as kind of about where we expected to be. It's performing well, particularly in the U.S., but it's pretty soft internationally. So I think at this point, products that have stronger demand or dependency on international markets are tougher markets. So we've seen that, certainly, in the midsized helicopter market, we've seen a little bit on our King Air market because that is typically more international, but the business jet market itself, which is stronger and a little more U.S. centric at this point, is doing fine.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Well, I mean I think it's good. I mean obviously our key programs like V-22 and H-1 came through the process exactly where we would have expected them to be. The U.S. business I mean, just got another order on the continuation of V-2 program. So there's not -- we're not really in a situation right now where there's a lot of big new start programs, but certainly, all of our existing and important programs, be it in the aviation world, the Ship-to-Shore Connector, the UAIS programs are all funded and in good shape.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And we have a question from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So did I hear you say there is another 5 to 6 months of customer testing for the TAPV? Maybe give us an update on your schedule there.
componenttext: So did I hear you say there is another 5 to 6 months of customer testing for the TAPV? Maybe give us an update on your schedule there.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Cai. So what happened is we talked in the fourth quarter about our expectation, we felt we could get some of the delivery starting late next year as we had finalized our initial testing. We had a couple of failures. It was a very strong small number
componenttext: Sure, Cai. So what happened is we talked in the fourth quarter about our expectation, we felt we could get some of the delivery starting late next year as we had finalized our initial testing. We had a couple of failures. It was a very strong small number, but we have the customer determined that because it was steering related, it could present a safety problem, so we decided we really needed to permanently resolve this thing. We did that. We our internal testing, it looks great. But it does completely reset the clock on the customer test as well. And so we've now started that. The vehicles are actually as we speak. It's going well, but it didn't reset the whole clock. So unfortunately, what was a fairly minor change in minor fix, those reset the clock, and that means you're probably looking at something delivers start in second half of this year. Now we built many, many of the vehicles, so there's a lot of vehicles sitting there. There've been modified. There's a minor change. So I think once delivery start, we'll do very well, but it does reset the clock on test.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's not just testing. There was the testing process and then the acceptance process, so that's why it takes a little bit longer than what you might expect.
componenttext: And it's not just testing. There was the testing process and then the acceptance process, so that's why it takes a little bit longer than what you might expect.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And so aviation, you had a 0.7 book to bill. Particularly, will you maybe give us some color on why was it so weak and color on demand may be buy product with specific reference may be to the King Airs?
componenttext: Got it. And so aviation, you had a 0.7 book to bill. Particularly, will you maybe give us some color on why was it so weak and color on demand may be buy product with specific reference may be to the King Airs?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, Cai, I don't know if it was terribly different than what we've been seeing cyclically with a lot of deliveries in Q4 on Jets. If you recall, last year,fourth quarter, we didn't have as much a drop of, but that was also -- there was a pretty signific
componenttext: Look, Cai, I don't know if it was terribly different than what we've been seeing cyclically with a lot of deliveries in Q4 on Jets. If you recall, last year,fourth quarter, we didn't have as much a drop of, but that was also -- there was a pretty significant military order which was in there which we talked about. So I don't think the color of the market, and frankly, the position that we have today in terms of backlog is very different than what we've seen frankly for the last 5 or 6 years. So in terms of what we need to do in sales and conversion, our orders, our conversion of sales as we go into '16 is not really different than where we've been. So I think we feel pretty good about where we are. Seniors, we're a little bit softer in the quarter frankly than I would have liked. They were up very modestly on a total year, but there's a lot of interest, there's a lot of customer discussions. Remember, we did transition from the old cockpit to the new ColdFusion cockpit on that line of product here in the fourth quarter, so that also creates a little bit of a gap. And so I think as we have now made -- gone through that production transition to the new model, we should be in pretty good shape for '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And last one, you're looking for flat R&D year-over-year. Could you give us a little bit of color in terms of which of your businesses the R&D might be trending up and where it might be flat to down?
componenttext: And last one, you're looking for flat R&D year-over-year. Could you give us a little bit of color in terms of which of your businesses the R&D might be trending up and where it might be flat to down?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: There wasn't really a material change on a year-over-year basis, Cai. Obviously, we ramped down now on Latitude, but we're ramping up clearly on Longitude and some work going into the hemisphere, some on internal props. Bell, 505 should wrap up this year,
componenttext: There wasn't really a material change on a year-over-year basis, Cai. Obviously, we ramped down now on Latitude, but we're ramping up clearly on Longitude and some work going into the hemisphere, some on internal props. Bell, 505 should wrap up this year, but we're full in the 525 and get ready for first flight on the 280. So the number is relatively flat. And I have to say if you look across all our different segments, the R&D spending is about the same from '15 into '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we have a question from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on Bell, firstly. If you could just sort of quantify how much of the commercial aftermarket sales were down in Q4, and how that pace has changed versus, say, 6 months ago, and how you see that playing out this year?
componenttext: Just a question on Bell, firstly. If you could just sort of quantify how much of the commercial aftermarket sales were down in Q4, and how that pace has changed versus, say, 6 months ago, and how you see that playing out this year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know if we give the exact number. But I mean, it's down slightly on a run-rate basis. And I think, frankly, it reflects the fact that we're seeing utilization across most of the platforms down in sort of low mid-single digits. And the aftermarket
componenttext: I don't know if we give the exact number. But I mean, it's down slightly on a run-rate basis. And I think, frankly, it reflects the fact that we're seeing utilization across most of the platforms down in sort of low mid-single digits. And the aftermarket tends to follow that pretty well.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then in terms of the margins for 2016 at Bell, should we think about it as you have a lot of pressure, particularly upfront in the first half just as the cost base rightsizes for the level of commercial aftermarket and then it's a better s
componenttext: Understood. And then in terms of the margins for 2016 at Bell, should we think about it as you have a lot of pressure, particularly upfront in the first half just as the cost base rightsizes for the level of commercial aftermarket and then it's a better second half, or do you think it's a fairly level loaded year on margins?

componenttext: To help clarify that, last year's deliveries were units that had been produced at a higher rate. And next year, it flows to the inventory, it shows up next year, and without the higher revenues on the commercial side to offset that, it puts pressure on the margin.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's going to bear as a function of 412 deliveries. The military margin rates are pretty consistent through the year and deliveries are pretty consistent through the years, it's been largely come down to the medium-sized, particularly 412 new deliveries as we work our way through the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And then last quick one. Just asset prices, I guess your own as well have come in in the last few months. So any change in the view on the sort of relative merits or appeal of buyback versus M&A when you think about capital deployment this y
componenttext: Very helpful. And then last quick one. Just asset prices, I guess your own as well have come in in the last few months. So any change in the view on the sort of relative merits or appeal of buyback versus M&A when you think about capital deployment this year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our strategy is really the same. We will always kind of keep an eye out for some M&A activity. I think is a great example. This is a business that's a very healthy business. It helps to augment what we bring to customers in terms of our aftermarke
componenttext: I think our strategy is really the same. We will always kind of keep an eye out for some M&A activity. I think is a great example. This is a business that's a very healthy business. It helps to augment what we bring to customers in terms of our aftermarket capability. So those are deals we do. They're not huge deals, but that's the kind of a deal that we would do in terms of the market. On stock buyback, as you know, we're still committed to at least offset dilution, and opportunistically, we'll do more than that.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I guess just conceptually, how long can you run a business with $5 billion in revenue, but only $1 billion in backlog, that question pertaining to aviation? I get it's become a more of a turn business than a backlog business. I get there is compone
componenttext: Scott, I guess just conceptually, how long can you run a business with $5 billion in revenue, but only $1 billion in backlog, that question pertaining to aviation? I get it's become a more of a turn business than a backlog business. I get there is components of that revenue number that don't have backlog. But I mean, it seems like it's just a risky thing to do, where if you keep this kind of neutralish environment, you're fine, but if you were to have a more sinister backdrop, you'd have to maybe cut things more sharply than you would if you were already reset to where backlog is.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, no, I mean, the market is what it is, like, I yes, so I mean, we've been doing this for a long time, right, where we're kind of coming in with the almost kind of backlog and our team is selling aircraft, and so I think we're in a position here where
componenttext: Well, no, I mean, the market is what it is, like, I yes, so I mean, we've been doing this for a long time, right, where we're kind of coming in with the almost kind of backlog and our team is selling aircraft, and so I think we're in a position here where we, given in a pretty flat market, we've been able to continue to eke out some growth on the top line in terms of -- don't forget the deal organically in terms of -- we sold more this year than we sold last year, we sold more jet this year than we sold last year, and we continue to expand the margin rate. So look, if I could pick up, if somebody give me another $1 billion or so of backlog, we take it. But the fact of the matter is that's not where the market's been, and it's been this way for -- it's been at least 6 years, right, where we've been kind of operating in this mode and that's just the nature of the semester right now. It's not a big -- announce a plane and get billions of dollars of backlog. You go out and you sell them pretty much one point at a time and that's working for us, right? So our revenue keeps going up and our margins keep expanding, and that's what we're going to be doing.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I guess the question was just more around risk mitigation of -- that's been working. But if you had a tougher global macro environment, that $1.1 billion could move sub-$1 billion pretty quickly and then you're staring at a more difficult situatio
componenttext: Yes. So I guess the question was just more around risk mitigation of -- that's been working. But if you had a tougher global macro environment, that $1.1 billion could move sub-$1 billion pretty quickly and then you're staring at a more difficult situation I guess. But I don't know.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, no, this is a -- it's just -- I mean, I appreciate the question. I understand. And as I said, if I could wave the magic wand and make it a different market environment, I'd certainly do that. Where we spend most of our discretionary monies is in the
componenttext: Look, no, this is a -- it's just -- I mean, I appreciate the question. I understand. And as I said, if I could wave the magic wand and make it a different market environment, I'd certainly do that. Where we spend most of our discretionary monies is in the produced, and that the new products have been working, right. If I were to go and say, guys, what if we took a different approach, what if we kind of hanker down and ride this thing out, what if we didn't do this plus or the Latitude or the M2 or -- or I think that new product investment, it will be tough to sustain a business that can grow revenue and expand margins.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm definitely not advocating for that, my question is more, should production be much lower on the Legacy products?
componenttext: Yes, I'm definitely not advocating for that, my question is more, should production be much lower on the Legacy products?

componenttextpreview: Well, look, we've taken those numbers down quite a bit over the years. And I think, right now, we are -- you're not seeing big overbuilt of stuff, right? I mean, we're not pumping out Whitetail. We -- pretty well on our production today over the last few
componenttext: Well, look, we've taken those numbers down quite a bit over the years. And I think, right now, we are -- you're not seeing big overbuilt of stuff, right? I mean, we're not pumping out Whitetail. We -- pretty well on our production today over the last few years, frankly, has been running to demand. So we're not generating a big surplus of aircraft, I mean we're just not going to do that.

And so if I assumed that you made it to a cumulative delivery #30, call it the middle of this year, that will get you somewhere in the vicinity of 30 Latitude deliveries for the year. Is that in the ballpark?

componenttext: No.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I just want to pursue a little bit more. I know you touched on it, but wanted to touch on it a little more. The aviation guide for margin in 2016, I mean, effectively, you're assuming that margins really flat with '15 because you don't have any of
componenttext: Scott, I just want to pursue a little bit more. I know you touched on it, but wanted to touch on it a little more. The aviation guide for margin in 2016, I mean, effectively, you're assuming that margins really flat with '15 because you don't have any of the step-up in '16 that you have in '15. I know you commented that a lot of it is because of deliveries. But still, I need to go from what you've been -- the high incrementals you've been running to relatively minimal incremental of maybe 9%, at least in your guidance, since pretty darn big shift. So I was just wondering if you comment a little bit more on it.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, George, I mean, I think you're accurate in terms of your assessment of kind of how we get there. And it's certainly on the lower end of the conversion than we would normally like to see. But no -- yes, a big piece of it is expectations on lower marg
componenttext: Well, George, I mean, I think you're accurate in terms of your assessment of kind of how we get there. And it's certainly on the lower end of the conversion than we would normally like to see. But no -- yes, a big piece of it is expectations on lower margin and in terms of the fractional, which is a big part of our growth, frankly, right? So if you look at that year-over-year incremental and -- was just kind of walking through the math as well, reading serial numbers of aircraft, but the -- a lot of our incremental, as we go from '15 to '16, is Latitudes, and a big chunk of that is going to the fractional market. So I mean, I think that's 3 out of where we are. A big piece of the year-over-year is going to be delivery which are at lower margin rates, it's still good business for us but at lower margin rates.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But one of the things that came away with from the investor conference in Wichita was the cost that you had taken out on the Latitude versus the Sovereign, and so my expectation was that the Latitude margin would start out no worse than some of the averag
componenttext: But one of the things that came away with from the investor conference in Wichita was the cost that you had taken out on the Latitude versus the Sovereign, and so my expectation was that the Latitude margin would start out no worse than some of the average mature programs that you had. I guess is that -- I guess that's not correct. I mean, or maybe it's just overwhelmed by the fractional ownership.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's the price we on the fractional as opposed to a cost basis. I think where we wanted to be on the cost. We're pretty good about where we are on the cost on the latitudes. I mean you're always going to have a little bit of inefficiency in the ramp-
componenttext: Yes. It's the price we on the fractional as opposed to a cost basis. I think where we wanted to be on the cost. We're pretty good about where we are on the cost on the latitudes. I mean you're always going to have a little bit of inefficiency in the ramp-up of a new one, but it's not a material issue for us. It's doing really well. The cost is in a good place. It's really a question of pricing on fractions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one other one. Your comment to I think to Cai's question earlier about the book to bill, the largest quarter[ph], but when I went back and looked at the book-to-bill in the fourth quarter of last year, it was actually around 1 versus the 0.
componenttext: Okay. And then one other one. Your comment to I think to Cai's question earlier about the book to bill, the largest quarter[ph], but when I went back and looked at the book-to-bill in the fourth quarter of last year, it was actually around 1 versus the 0.7 plus that we saw this quarter. So is there any added color you could provide on that?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. If you go back to fourth quarter last year, we did talk about the fact that we had a pretty significant international military order, and those are lumpier than a normal flow, so that contributed a pretty good backlog in Q4 next year. So if you took
componenttext: Sure. If you go back to fourth quarter last year, we did talk about the fact that we had a pretty significant international military order, and those are lumpier than a normal flow, so that contributed a pretty good backlog in Q4 next year. So if you took that out, the dynamic we typically see in Q4 is because it's such a high delivery quarter has been that we see a much lower book-to-bill in Q4, since we have in recent time, and so I don't think this year, if you were to back out the military deal in the fourth quarter, it doesn't look very different on a year-over-year basis.

componenttext: And we have a question from the line of Johnny Wright of Nomura.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 1 question on Industrials. It's clearly exciting pretty decent growth again this year. I'm just wondering what are you anticipating from Nordic markets in 2016 year, anything else you want to call out, the guide there?
componenttext: Just 1 question on Industrials. It's clearly exciting pretty decent growth again this year. I'm just wondering what are you anticipating from Nordic markets in 2016 year, anything else you want to call out, the guide there?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if the other markets continue to be pretty healthy, as I mentioned in the prepared comments, we saw growth again this year in all 3 regions, in North America, Europe and Asia. And all the forecast -- yes, we carve our guidance obviously in our model
componenttext: Well, if the other markets continue to be pretty healthy, as I mentioned in the prepared comments, we saw growth again this year in all 3 regions, in North America, Europe and Asia. And all the forecast -- yes, we carve our guidance obviously in our model based on what's out there in terms of what all the OEMs are saying. And right now, they're all forecasting growth again in 2016. And so we expect obviously to grow with that. We've had some nice wins on new models, which is helping to drive our growth. So our growth has been in excess of what overall markets have done on the other side, and I expect that will be true again in 2016.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: This is John Walsh on the line for Jeff. A lot of ground covered. Just had 1 quick question on pricing. I totally understand what's going on at the fractional business. headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple quick ones on aviation. Scott, aviation aftermarket, it kind of last year and this year, is it similar to the Bell commercial aftermarket trends? And then I just was wondering if you can talk about aviation -- citation preowned, your pricing
componenttext: Just a couple quick ones on aviation. Scott, aviation aftermarket, it kind of last year and this year, is it similar to the Bell commercial aftermarket trends? And then I just was wondering if you can talk about aviation -- citation preowned, your pricing and activity wise?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the aftermarket, on a couple of basis, we are pretty flat. We have some changes in how we recognize revenue in terms of some engine programs, we talked about before this doesn't affect our profitability but just the revenues. We're not basically bet
componenttext: So on the aftermarket, on a couple of basis, we are pretty flat. We have some changes in how we recognize revenue in terms of some engine programs, we talked about before this doesn't affect our profitability but just the revenues. We're not basically between the customer and the engine side. So all in all, I think it's relatively flat, and we expect, frankly, on a comparable basis, a slight uptick in the aftermarket in 2016 from '15. And similarly on the used aircraft pricing, it's been fairly stable.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from the line of Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We have a question from the line of Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe, Frank, a quick question on the balance sheet and maybe Scott on capital deployment. So is the idea to refi the notes coming due or repay instead to reduce debt further seems like you're getting to a point where maybe the debt load is at a point whe
componenttext: Maybe, Frank, a quick question on the balance sheet and maybe Scott on capital deployment. So is the idea to refi the notes coming due or repay instead to reduce debt further seems like you're getting to a point where maybe the debt load is at a point where you're comparable? And so, Scott, is the x the increasing as there's more excess free cash flow here?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, from a balance sheet standpoint, we'll probably refi what we have coming due this coming year. So we're pretty comfortable now with our debt levels. That the balance sheet has -- we've had good flexibility over the past couple years, we think,
componenttext: Yes. Well, from a balance sheet standpoint, we'll probably refi what we have coming due this coming year. So we're pretty comfortable now with our debt levels. That the balance sheet has -- we've had good flexibility over the past couple years, we think, from an M&A standpoint, so I do think that there's a real change in the M&A aperture. We feel like we've been able to kind of do get things that we wanted to do and we'll be able to continue to do that, but we will stop paying down debt at these levels.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

We haven't in anyway constrained. I think our M&A strategy is one where we see opportunities. It's a great fit. I think we get good leverage. It supports the balance of our business, and then we'll do them.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of big picture questions for you. On the Hemisphere, when you think about, I know it's still early days, but with G450s coming off the line and my understanding is that they're selling for not too much over $30 million, isn't that really a diffic
componenttext: A couple of big picture questions for you. On the Hemisphere, when you think about, I know it's still early days, but with G450s coming off the line and my understanding is that they're selling for not too much over $30 million, isn't that really a difficult place to try to put a new product and then with the Gulfstream there, with the Bombardier guys there, there, it seems pretty crowded.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when we look at the Hemisphere and how we size the Hemisphere, our intent is to be sort of just below where that market is because, you're right, I think the 450, 550, 7000, 8000, there's 7 AEX, it's not our intent to be competing with that
componenttext: Well, I think when we look at the Hemisphere and how we size the Hemisphere, our intent is to be sort of just below where that market is because, you're right, I think the 450, 550, 7000, 8000, there's 7 AEX, it's not our intent to be competing with that guy. So if somebody is looking at a G450, the Hemisphere is designed to be slotted sort of one tier below that echelon of aircraft. And we think that's the market where there hasn't been a lot of reinvestment, while a lot of the big iron guys, which is why we're going there, not looking the intent of going up and joining in that area. So I think you're right. I think it's a well served market. In terms of current pricing, I have no idea. That market cycles just like a midsized cycle. So where pricing and demand is right now is a function of the market, but the intent that we have with Hemisphere is it slots just below before you get into those big iron guys.

componenttext: For the Scorpion, no, we have -- the good news is that one of the most critical issues for the program was always determining a path to certification. I think the good news is, through a lot of work last year, the Air Force was now opened up the ability to go through an airworthiness process with the Air Force. They've initiated that program. And obviously, we fully expect to participate in that, so we have the first aircraft, we'll be conforming test articles in production as we speak and are working with the Air Force to get under contract to have them conduct and ultimately provide an air wellness certification for their aircraft, so that's a big step forward for us.
