headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, we'd like to thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Textron Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call will be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over t
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, we'd like to thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Textron Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Teleconference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call will be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to our VP, Investor Relations, Mr. Doug Wilburne. Please go ahead.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention, we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention, we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our SEC filings and also in today's press release.
On the call today, we have Scott Donnelly, Textron's Chairman and CEO; and Frank Connor, our Chief Financial Officer. Our earnings call presentation can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website.
Textron revenues in the quarter were $3.9 billion, down 4.2% from $4.1 billion in last year's fourth quarter. Income from continuing operations was $0.81 per share, up 6.6% from $0.76 in the fourth quarter of 2014. Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions of $18 million was $534 million compared to $449 million in last year's fourth quarter.
For the full year, revenues were $13.4 billion, down 3.3% from a year ago. Income from continuing operations was $2.50 per share, up 16.3% from $2.15 last year. Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions of $68 million was $631 million.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, good morning, everybody. Revenue growth for Industrial but down at Systems, Bell and Aviation were [indiscernible] due to an overall decrease in revenue in the quarter. Despite the decline in revenues, with good execution with margin improve
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug, good morning, everybody. Revenue growth for Industrial but down at Systems, Bell and Aviation were [indiscernible] due to an overall decrease in revenue in the quarter. Despite the decline in revenues, with good execution with margin improvements at Aviation, Systems and Industrial and saw double-digit margins at Bell, with strong cash flow across all our business segments. At Bell, we shipped 56 commercial helicopters compared to 57 in last year's fourth quarter. Commercial revenues were down, reflecting lower aftermarket volume and a change in mix of aircraft delivered.
On the new product front, we're making good progress with our 525 Relentless program. We now have 2 aircraft in our flight test program and are preparing to bring a third aircraft into testing this spring. It successfully attained a top speed of 186 knots, validating the aircraft's maximum true airspeed target, although our new [ph] testing includes continued signal and stability testing as well as further development of the gross weight and center of gravity extremes.
Aircraft will heading north to gather initial cold weather data next month. As the team continues to progress with the development phase of the test program, we're preparing to enter the certification test phase in the spring.
We also plan to fly the 525 to Heli-Expo in Louisville in March so that our customers can see the actual aircraft for the first time. Overall, the aircraft continued to perform very well, meeting or exceeding all of our initial performance expectations. Customer demand remains strong as we currently have about 80 letters of intent from around the world. We're targeting certification of first delivery of the 525 next year.
Our 505 Jet Ranger X program is also making good progress, with 3 test aircraft now in operation. We're targeting certification and entering into service later this year. Our upgraded 407GXP model continues to generate great reception in the marketplace, with overall 407 deliveries, up 13 units in 2015. Earlier this month, we made the first GXP delivery to Air Methods under the 10-year 200 unit contract that we signed at last year's Heli-Expo show.
While we're having good success selling our lighter helicopters, the medium segment of the market continues to be challenged. This was reflected in the low 412 volumes that we saw in 2015, and the outlook from medium helicopter remains soft as we look to 2016.
On the defense side, V-22 deliveries were up in the quarter, as we delivered 8 V-22s compared to 7 a year ago. H-1 deliveries were also up as we delivered 9 units compared to 7 in last year's fourth quarter.
Moving to systems, lower year-over-year revenues in the quarter were primarily the result of TCDL V2 Shadow deliveries in last year's fourth quarter. This year's fourth quarter revenues included delivery of 55 COMMANDO Select Armored Vehicles for the Afghan National Army, but did not include any Canadian TAPV deliveries as we're still conducting our internal testing. Now -- having now completed initial testing, we'll begin the customer testing process this week. We expect this process and final acceptance will take 5 to 6 months to complete. At TRUE, in October, we opened our first commercial aviation maintenance training facility in Wichita, with initial courses covering mechanical and avionics maintenance for the King Air, Baron and Bonanza products. We also received a phase certification for both our Pro Line Fusion-equipped King Air 350 aircraft and its associated simulator. We give the in pilot training in the new simulator at our Tampa ProFlight center, supporting initial aircraft deliveries in the quarter.
Moving to Aviation. We delivered 60 Jets and 33 King Airs compared to 55 Jets and 41 King Airs last year. For the full year, we delivered 166 Jets, up from last year's 159, including 16 Latitude deliveries. During the quarter, we delivered our 102nd, marking the solid success that this product has had in the marketplace during the 2 years it's been in service.
The most significant event during the quarter to Aviation was the unveiling of our new Longitude and hemisphere aircraft at NBAA in November. Customer reaction to both of these models have been very positive, and we believe they will generate substantial growth opportunities. The Longitude has superior operating performance compared to any aircraft in its class and should provide meaningful contribution to revenue and profits at Aviation after its expected entry into service late next year.
Longer term, the Hemisphere should provide to be a game changer as it will open up an entirely new market opportunity for us. With first flight targeted for 2019, we expect the Hemisphere will accelerate growth at Aviation as we enter the next decade. We also announced details of our new single-engine turboprop, including a new 1,300 shaft horsepower GE turboprop engine. We're developing this aircraft to be a class-leading product with a range of 1,500 nautical miles, speeds of over 280 knots, a larger cabin and reduced operating costs.
An important part of Textron Aviation and the Bell brand is our service footprint and aftermarket support capabilities. In that regard, last week, we acquired Able Engineering & Component Services, an innovative low-cost repair and overhaul business operated in Mesa, Arizona. Able provides component repairs, component exchanges and replacement parts, along with other support and service offerings for commercial rotorcraft and fixed-wing aircraft customers. This business is a great extension to our aftermarket business.
Wrapping up the quarter with Industrial, we achieved a 6.4% increase in revenues after a 5.8% negative impact from foreign exchange, reflecting strong organic growth in the quarter. At Kautex, we had solid growth, with revenues up in Europe, North America and Asia. Textron's specialized vehicles had solid growth across all business lines, reflecting our focus on new products and the success of recent acquisitions, such as TUG and Douglas airport ground support equipment businesses.
To summarize the year, despite a decline in manufacturing revenues, we were able to achieve a 60 basis point improvement in manufacturing margins. We believe we entered the year with strong EPS and cash flow performance, especially given the challenges of a weaker-than-expected commercial helicopter market.
Throughout the year, we took actions that should position our businesses for growth and profitability over the next several years. At Textron Systems, we advanced our Ship to Shore program with the first 2 units in production. With targeted deliveries in 2017, the DoD exercised options for another 2 ships out of the total expected program of 73 units. At TRUE, we opened our Tampa pilot training center and Wichita maintenance training facility, received the King Air training certification and announced 3 additional orders from Boeing for its new 737 MAX platform.
At Industrial, our top line growth for the year reflected our continuing investment in new products, such as the Jacobsen Truckster XD heavy-duty vehicle, the Cushman Hauler 4x4 and Greenlee's AirScout Wi-Fi test system. Industrial growth also reflects the success of recent acquisitions, which demonstrates our ability to leverage these businesses for growth and long-term shareholder value.
At Bell, we continue to prove our win rate in the commercial helicopter market based on the attractiveness of our new and upgraded products, our industry-leading aftermarket support and our expanding sales presence around the world. On the military front, we made important progress with our V-280 order program, provided a handful of demonstrations of V-280s to potential domestic and foreign customers using a flight simulator developed by our teams at Bell and TRUE.
Manufactured at several operations, the first aircraft were well underway, and we remain on track for first flight in 2017. The militarized version or Bell 412 model was selected for Japan's UH-X program. We've been partnering with Fuji Heavy Industries to deliver 150 aircraft beginning in 2021. We also signed contracts to deliver the first 3 of at least 12 planned H-1 helicopters for Pakistan and the first 5 of 17 expected V-22s for Japan. Looking forward, we have a significant number of foreign opportunities for the H-1s that we are pursuing and expect to secure additional orders this year.
In Textron Aviation, last year, we began deliveries of our new Latitude, announced its new single-engine turboprop, 2 new business jets and realized the full year impact of operational benefits from our Beechcraft acquisition.
To finish with Textron's 2016 financial guidance, we're predicting revenues of about $14.3 billion as we expect solid growth at Aviation, Industrial and Systems and approximately flat revenues at Bell. We expect EPS from continuing operations will be in the range of $2.60 to $2.80 and manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions in a range to $600 million to $700 million.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $378 million, down $20 million from the fourth quarter of 2014, [indiscernible] $3 million [ph] decrease in revenue. Let's review how each of the segments performed, starting
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $378 million, down $20 million from the fourth quarter of 2014, [indiscernible] $3 million [ph] decrease in revenue. Let's review how each of the segments performed, starting with Textron Aviation.
Revenues were down $32 million from this period last year, reflecting lower King Air and preowned aircraft volumes, partially offset by higher jet volume. Aviation had a profit of $138 million compared to $130 million a year ago. This increase primarily reflected improved performance, which included lower amortization of $8 million related to fair value step-up adjustments, partially offset by the lower volumes. Backlog in the segment ended the quarter at $1.1 billion, down $308 million from the end of the third quarter.
Moving to Bell. Revenues were down $36 million, reflecting lower commercial aftermarket volume and a change in mix of commercial aircraft delivered in the quarter, partially offset by higher military deliveries. Segment profit decreased $22 million from the fourth quarter of 2014, primarily reflecting an unfavorable impact from the change in mix of commercial aircraft delivered in the quarter and lower commercial aftermarket volume, partially offset by improved performance. Backlog in the segment ended the quarter at $5.2 billion, up $76 million from the end of the third quarter.
At Textron Systems, revenues were down $158 million, primarily due to lower Unmanned Systems volume, partially offset by higher Marine & Land Systems volume. Segment profit was down $9 million, reflecting the impact of the lower volumes.
Industrial revenues increased $55 million due to higher overall volumes and the impact of acquisitions, partially offset by a $50 million unfavorable impact from foreign exchange. Segment profit increased $6 million, reflecting -- or primarily reflecting the impact of the higher volumes. Finance segment revenues decreased $2 million and profit decreased $3 million.
Moving below the segment profit line. Corporate expenses were $52 million, and our tax rate in the quarter was 23.5%. The fourth quarter tax rate benefited from the U.S. R&D tax legislation passed late in the quarter, as well as some other discrete items. Interest expense was $32 million, down $8 million from last year, reflecting lower debt levels.
We repaid $100 million of the bank loan from the Beechcraft acquisition and repurchased approximately 208,000 shares in the quarter. We ended the year with gross manufacturing debt of $2.7 billion, resulting in a year-end manufacturing debt-to-EBITDA multiple of about 1.8x. For the full year, we repurchased approximately 5.2 million shares at an overall cost of about $219 million.
Turning now to our 2016 guidance, beginning with our segments on Slide 9. At Textron Aviation, we're expecting about 6% revenue growth, bringing revenues to about $5.1 billion, primarily reflecting a ramp-up in Latitude deliveries. Segment margins are expected to be in the range of 8.5% to 9%.
At Bell, we expect overall revenues will be flattish at about $3.4 billion, reflecting lower V-22 revenues, offset by higher H-1 deliveries on the military side and essentially flat revenues in our commercial business. We're forecasting margins in the range of 10% to 11%.
At Systems, we're estimating 2016 revenues at about $1.9 billion, up 25% from last year, reflecting expected TAPV deliveries and good growth in most of our other Systems businesses. Segment margins are expected to be in the range of 10% to 10.5%. 
At Industrial, we're expecting solid growth in each of our businesses, resulting in a projected 7% segment revenue growth to about $3.8 billion, with estimated margins in the range of 9% to 9.9%. 
At Finance, we're forecasting segment profit of about $15 million.
Turning to Slide 10. Based on U.S. planned discount rate of 4.75%, we're estimating 2016 pension costs will be about $85 million, down from $138 million last year.
Turning to Slide 11. R&D is expected to be about $615 million, approximately flat with 2015. We're estimating CapEx will be about $475 million, up from last year's expenditures of $420 million, reflecting our investments in new products and geographic expansion.
Moving below the segment line and looking at Slide 12, we're projecting about $155 million for corporate expense. Next year's interest expense is estimated at $133 million, reflecting higher rates on variable rate debt. We're assuming a tax rate of about 31% as we had some items in 2015 that benefited our tax rate that we do not expect will reoccur in 2016 as well as an expected higher mix of U.S. revenues in 2016, which are taxed at higher rates. Our guidance assumes a flat share count of about 277 million shares, reflecting repurchases sufficient to offset dilution.
That concludes our prepared remarks. So Steve, we can open the line for questions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our first question will come from the line of Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our first question will come from the line of Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you guys could touch a little bit more on the margin in Aviation, flattish sequentially and kind of the fairly moderate growth planned for next year.
componenttext: I wonder if you guys could touch a little bit more on the margin in Aviation, flattish sequentially and kind of the fairly moderate growth planned for next year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, the sequential sort of flatness from Q3 to Q4 is largely driven by the fact that we had a fair bit of expense in the fourth quarter between R&D and a lot of costs associated with the ramp-up of what we did for NBAA, which offset a fair bit o
componenttext: First of all, the sequential sort of flatness from Q3 to Q4 is largely driven by the fact that we had a fair bit of expense in the fourth quarter between R&D and a lot of costs associated with the ramp-up of what we did for NBAA, which offset a fair bit of what we saw in some of the incremental volumes on a sequential basis. Nothing more than substantive than that. In terms of next year, the volume leverage probably is not as high as you guys would expect. I think that's largely driven by the fact that we're going to see probably some lower margin on a lot of our incremental sales, particularly that which is going into the fractional business. So we have a fairly high number of deliveries next year. It will go on the NetJets. You probably saw yesterday, they've announced the official launch of that product into their customer base. And typically, sales into the fractional channel are at a lower margin than our typical retail sales.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then maybe just as a quick follow-up. For Bell, I think you talked about commercial being flattish. And military, it sounds like maybe flattish as well with V-22 down [ph] and H-1 up. I wonder if you could talk about the levels -- the level of
componenttext: Great. And then maybe just as a quick follow-up. For Bell, I think you talked about commercial being flattish. And military, it sounds like maybe flattish as well with V-22 down [ph] and H-1 up. I wonder if you could talk about the levels -- the level of decline on V-22 and kind of -- is this the bottom? And then what gives you confidence on being flat in commercial?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at the mix in the business as we go into next year, the military and commercial are both probably relatively flat. I think we saw the big drop-down this year obviously, with V-22 reductions earlier in the year. We'll continue to probably be
componenttext: So if you look at the mix in the business as we go into next year, the military and commercial are both probably relatively flat. I think we saw the big drop-down this year obviously, with V-22 reductions earlier in the year. We'll continue to probably be down a little bit V-22, probably up a little bit on the H-1 side of things. So all in all, I expect to be relatively flattish, and I think the same is true on the commercial side. The big adjustment that we really made this year was a reduction in that medium-sized helicopters that you're going to see probably about 12 [ph] 412s, and we expect that to be about flat on a year-over-year basis. So I don't think there's going to be a big mix shift within the business as we look at flattish revenues. I think it's going to be true on both the military and commercial side.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the volumes with the V-22, it's consistent with the Multiyear II, which called for 100 units over 5 years. We've been delivering a little ahead of schedule, but there were a few options exercised. So that's just consistent with that. And then as w
componenttext: Yes. On the volumes with the V-22, it's consistent with the Multiyear II, which called for 100 units over 5 years. We've been delivering a little ahead of schedule, but there were a few options exercised. So that's just consistent with that. And then as we look forward to '18 and the Japanese deliveries, we should see some recovery there.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Look, the V-22s were totally expected, right? I mean, what we saw in the military side of the business in 2015 and what we expect in '16 is entirely consistent with what we've always talked about. I mean, the programs are record in terms of the uni
componenttext: Right. Look, the V-22s were totally expected, right? I mean, what we saw in the military side of the business in 2015 and what we expect in '16 is entirely consistent with what we've always talked about. I mean, the programs are record in terms of the units, that there are absolutely no surprises there. The issue really was largely around the commercial side and particularly on the medium segment. And those are -- for us, Bell 412s, that's typically a very international product. And as you can imagine, between the pressure around oil and other commodities and just in general, the international marketplace is moving pretty soft, and I think that's reflected overall in the Bell 412 margins. So again, we expect that to be pretty flat as we go from '15 to '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to stick with Bell for just a moment here. And I just got -- maybe have you talk a little bit about the margin outlook and a bit more detail and talk a little bit about some of the puts and takes that are going on this year. And then as a fo
componenttext: I just wanted to stick with Bell for just a moment here. And I just got -- maybe have you talk a little bit about the margin outlook and a bit more detail and talk a little bit about some of the puts and takes that are going on this year. And then as a follow-up to that, just as we head into the Heli-Expo show in early March, maybe just talk a little bit about things you're going to be looking for into that show and kind of expectations around it.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So look, as I think on the margin rate, what we've communicated to you guys, we've been trying to hold that business at [ph] 11% to 12% rate. I think as we manage through, knowing what was going to happen on the military programs, we adjusted our co
componenttext: Sure. So look, as I think on the margin rate, what we've communicated to you guys, we've been trying to hold that business at [ph] 11% to 12% rate. I think as we manage through, knowing what was going to happen on the military programs, we adjusted our cost base to make sure that we could hit that target. As you see in our segment level kind of color at this point, we think we're probably 100 basis points lower than that. And that's a reflection of the fact that we're seeing a significant reduction in what we would have expected in terms of the volume in the midsized market as we go forward. So there will still -- obviously, there will be some cost reductions that come associated with that as we lower the production rates and are lowering the production rates on the 412 side in particular. But to try to take out more costs from that and sustain the investments that we need to make in the 505 and 525 and V-280, I think that's going to cost a little about 100 basis points, and that's why you see that reflection of the drop. So what we committed, internal margin and how we dealt with the fact that we're going to have this known ramp-down on the military side and then further reductions that we made this year on the commercial side has sustained margins about where we want it to be. But I think at this point, given where we've taken the forecast on 412s, that's probably going to cost us about 100 basis points. So as we go into Heli-Expo, look, it's going to be an interesting show to try to understand where customers are, what their expectations are going forward. 505, we continue to feel very good about. The level of customer demand in that area is great. The 407s, as I said earlier, very strong and delivering out some big programs and a continued strong interest. 429s are kind of flattish. I think the question is really going to be, with a lot of our international customers, how they feel going forward, and that will affect the 412 obviously and give us a feel of where things are going in terms of the 525. We're still 1.5 years away from -- or so of making the first deliveries on an aircraft, so there's still a fair bit of time here to understand what that market dynamic is going to look like.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question will come from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the manufacturing cash flow outlook into 2016? It just seems like you've got earnings up, pension looks like -- I know CapEx is up but depreciation is up about the same. Can you just talk about what else might be going agai
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the manufacturing cash flow outlook into 2016? It just seems like you've got earnings up, pension looks like -- I know CapEx is up but depreciation is up about the same. Can you just talk about what else might be going against you, why you're not seeing a bigger pickup on the cash flow line?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, if you look at the -- going into late next year, Sam, we're going to have a lot of inventory that were accumulating in the bills of the first lots of the 525s and also the Longitude. So we'll probably start deliveries of both those aircraft, obvi
componenttext: So look, if you look at the -- going into late next year, Sam, we're going to have a lot of inventory that were accumulating in the bills of the first lots of the 525s and also the Longitude. So we'll probably start deliveries of both those aircraft, obviously not in the -- until 2017, but we'll have the kind of priming the pump, if you will, and those are 2 fairly high dollar, big programs that will drive our working capital late in '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we also are planning for some higher cash -- tax cashes in '16.
componenttext: Yes, we also are planning for some higher cash -- tax cashes in '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of the margin pick-up at Systems next year, is that all TAPV related? Why is there such a big step-up from '15 to '16?
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of the margin pick-up at Systems next year, is that all TAPV related? Why is there such a big step-up from '15 to '16?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, TAPV is certainly a big part of it. The have that program going, but we expect we're going to see solid performance. If you look at our UAS, businesses continue to perform well. I think the momentum is very good there, similarly, in our prec
componenttext: Well, I mean, TAPV is certainly a big part of it. The have that program going, but we expect we're going to see solid performance. If you look at our UAS, businesses continue to perform well. I think the momentum is very good there, similarly, in our precision munitions business, good contracts, good backlog of healthy business. So it's really across the whole segment and of course, our simulation training business, which continues to perform and grow. So they're really -- it's not just one item. I mean, certainly getting -- TAPV is a big driver of the revenue increase in terms of finally delivering on that, but in terms of overall margins, it's pretty solid performance across all of those business segments.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Robert Stallard of Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Robert Stallard of Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, there has been some signs of weakness in large cabin business jet in recent months. I was wondering if you could comment about what you're seeing in your market at the smaller and midsized and if anything has weakened that?
componenttext: Scott, there has been some signs of weakness in large cabin business jet in recent months. I was wondering if you could comment about what you're seeing in your market at the smaller and midsized and if anything has weakened that?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really hasn't, Robert. I mean, we've seen not strong growth, but we've seen increased volumes in '15. We expect again to see some increased volume as we go into 2016. But again, it's primarily driven by new product. I would say, most Legacy models will
componenttext: It really hasn't, Robert. I mean, we've seen not strong growth, but we've seen increased volumes in '15. We expect again to see some increased volume as we go into 2016. But again, it's primarily driven by new product. I would say, most Legacy models will be sort of flattish, but growth of new things like Latitude coming out is really what's driving the growth in the business. So I think we see the market as kind of about where we expect it to be. It's performing well, particularly in the U.S., but it's pretty soft internationally. So I think at this point, products that have stronger demand or dependency on international markets are tougher markets. So we've seen that certainly in the midsized helicopter market, we've seen a little bit on our King Air market because that is typically more international. But the business jet market itself, which is stronger and a little more U.S. centric at this point, is doing fine.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe switching gears. Looking at the defense side of your business, we got a recent FY '16 budget go through in December. It's early days, but how do you think that will flow through to Textron?
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe switching gears. Looking at the defense side of your business, we got a recent FY '16 budget go through in December. It's early days, but how do you think that will flow through to Textron?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think it's good. Our -- it's obviously -- our key programs like V-22 and H-1 came through the process exactly where we would have expected them to be. The U.S. business, I mean, we just got another order on the continuation of V-2 program.
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think it's good. Our -- it's obviously -- our key programs like V-22 and H-1 came through the process exactly where we would have expected them to be. The U.S. business, I mean, we just got another order on the continuation of V-2 program. So there's not -- we're not really in a situation right now where there's a lot of big new start programs. But certainly, all of our existing and important programs, be it in the aviation world, the Ship-to-Shore Connector, the UAS programs are all funded and in good shape.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from the line of Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And we have a question from the line of Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So did I hear you say there's another 5 to 6 months of customer testing for the TAPV? Maybe give us an update of your schedule there.
componenttext: So did I hear you say there's another 5 to 6 months of customer testing for the TAPV? Maybe give us an update of your schedule there.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Cai. So look, what happened is when we talked in the fourth quarter about our expectation, we felt we could get some of the delivery starting late next year as we had finalized our initial testing. We had a couple of failures. It was a very strong s
componenttext: Sure, Cai. So look, what happened is when we talked in the fourth quarter about our expectation, we felt we could get some of the delivery starting late next year as we had finalized our initial testing. We had a couple of failures. It was a very strong small number, but we and the customer determined that because it was steering related, it could present a safety problem. So we decided we really needed to permanently [ph] resolve this thing. We did that. We've completed all our internal testing, it looks great. But it does completely reset the clock on the customer test as well. And so we've now started that. The vehicles are actually under test as we speak. It's going well, but it did reset the whole clock. So unfortunately, what was a fairly minor change and minor fix does reset the clock, and that means you're probably looking at something where deliveries will probably start in second half of this year. Now we've built many, many of the vehicles, so there's a lot of vehicles sitting there. They're -- they've been modified. There's a minor change. So I think once deliveries start, we'll do very well, but it does reset the clock on the test.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear, it's not just testing, there's the testing process and then the acceptance process. So that's why it takes a little bit longer than what you might expect.
componenttext: Just to be clear, it's not just testing, there's the testing process and then the acceptance process. So that's why it takes a little bit longer than what you might expect.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And so aviation, you had a 0.7 book to bill. Particularly, will you maybe give us some color on why was it so weak and color on demand maybe by product with specific reference maybe to the King Airs?
componenttext: Got it. And so aviation, you had a 0.7 book to bill. Particularly, will you maybe give us some color on why was it so weak and color on demand maybe by product with specific reference maybe to the King Airs?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, Cai, I don't know that it was terribly different than what we've been sort of seeing cyclically with a lot of deliveries in Q4 on Jets. You recall, last year, fourth quarter, we didn't have as much a dropoff, but that was also -- there was a pretty
componenttext: Look, Cai, I don't know that it was terribly different than what we've been sort of seeing cyclically with a lot of deliveries in Q4 on Jets. You recall, last year, fourth quarter, we didn't have as much a dropoff, but that was also -- there was a pretty significant military order that was in there which we talked about. So I don't think the color of the market and frankly, the position that we have today in terms of backlog is very different than what we've seen frankly for the last 5 or 6 years. So in terms of what we need to do in sales, in conversion or orders, the conversion of sales as we go into '16 is not really different than where we've been. So I think we feel pretty good about where we are. King Airs, we're a little bit softer in the quarter frankly than I would have liked. They were up very modestly on the total year, but there's a lot of interest, there's a lot of customer discussions. Remember, we did transition from the old cockpit to the new Collins Fusion cockpit on that line of product here in the fourth quarter, so that also creates a little bit of a gap. So I think as we have now made -- gone through that production transition to the new model, we should be in pretty good shape for '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And last one, you're looking for flat R&D year-over-year. Could you give us a little bit of color in terms of which of your businesses the R&D might be trending up and where it might be flat to down?
componenttext: And last one, you're looking for flat R&D year-over-year. Could you give us a little bit of color in terms of which of your businesses the R&D might be trending up and where it might be flat to down?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not really a material change on a year-over-year basis, Cai. Obviously, we ramped down now on Latitude, but we're ramping up clearly on Longitude and some work going on in the -- into the Hemispheres and the turboprops. Bell 505 should wrap up this y
componenttext: It's not really a material change on a year-over-year basis, Cai. Obviously, we ramped down now on Latitude, but we're ramping up clearly on Longitude and some work going on in the -- into the Hemispheres and the turboprops. Bell 505 should wrap up this year, but we're full in the 525 and getting ready for first flight on the 280. So the number is relatively flat. And I have to say, if you look across all of our different segments, the R&D spending is about the same from '15 into '16.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from the line of Julian Mitchell of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we have a question from the line of Julian Mitchell of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on Bell, firstly. If you could just sort of quantify how much the commercial aftermarket sales were down in Q4 and how that pace has changed versus, say, 6 months ago and how you see that playing out this year.
componenttext: Just a question on Bell, firstly. If you could just sort of quantify how much the commercial aftermarket sales were down in Q4 and how that pace has changed versus, say, 6 months ago and how you see that playing out this year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know if we give the exact number. But I mean, it's down slightly on a run-rate basis. And I think, frankly, it reflects the fact that we're seeing utilization across most of the platforms down in sort of low mid-single digits. And the aftermarket
componenttext: I don't know if we give the exact number. But I mean, it's down slightly on a run-rate basis. And I think, frankly, it reflects the fact that we're seeing utilization across most of the platforms down in sort of low mid-single digits. And the aftermarket tends to follow that pretty well.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then in terms of the margins for 2016 at Bell, should we think about it as you have a lot of pressure, particularly upfront in the first half just as the cost base rightsizes for the level of commercial aftermarket and then it's a better s
componenttext: Understood. And then in terms of the margins for 2016 at Bell, should we think about it as you have a lot of pressure, particularly upfront in the first half just as the cost base rightsizes for the level of commercial aftermarket and then it's a better second half? Or do you think it's a fairly level loaded year on margins?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I...
componenttext: That's a good question. I...

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It depends upon -- depend on how the 412 delivers more than anything else. I mean, it's...
componenttext: It depends upon -- depend on how the 412 delivers more than anything else. I mean, it's...

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's really dependent on mix and deliveries. It's not a question of kind of -- we kind of get to a different type of cost structure just because of the way things are accounted for in kind of our military programs and our inventory. So it's really a
componenttext: Yes, it's really dependent on mix and deliveries. It's not a question of kind of -- we kind of get to a different type of cost structure just because of the way things are accounted for in kind of our military programs and our inventory. So it's really a function, as Scott said, of the kind of, at this point, the lower production activities. And the impact quarter-to-quarter will be dependent on delivery activity.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to help clarify that, last year's deliveries were units that had been produced at a -- in a higher rate. And next year, it's -- as it flows to the inventory, it shows up next year, and without the higher revenues on the commercial side to offset that,
componenttext: And to help clarify that, last year's deliveries were units that had been produced at a -- in a higher rate. And next year, it's -- as it flows to the inventory, it shows up next year, and without the higher revenues on the commercial side to offset that, it puts pressure on the margin.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Look, that's going to vary principally as a function of 412 deliveries. The military margin rates are pretty consistent through the years and then deliveries are pretty consistent through the years. It's going to largely come down to the medium siz
componenttext: Right. Look, that's going to vary principally as a function of 412 deliveries. The military margin rates are pretty consistent through the years and then deliveries are pretty consistent through the years. It's going to largely come down to the medium size, particularly 412 deliveries as we work our way through the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And then last quick one, just asset prices, I guess, your own as well, have come in, in the past few months. So any change in your view on the sort of relative merits or appeal of buyback versus M&A when you think about capital deployment th
componenttext: Very helpful. And then last quick one, just asset prices, I guess, your own as well, have come in, in the past few months. So any change in your view on the sort of relative merits or appeal of buyback versus M&A when you think about capital deployment this year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our strategy is really the same as we'll -- we're -- we'll always kind of keep an eye out for some M&A activity. I think Able is a great example. This is a business that's a very healthy business. It helps to augment what we bring to customers in
componenttext: I think our strategy is really the same as we'll -- we're -- we'll always kind of keep an eye out for some M&A activity. I think Able is a great example. This is a business that's a very healthy business. It helps to augment what we bring to customers in terms of our aftermarket capability. So those are deals we do. They're not huge deals, but that's the kind of a deal that we would do in terms of the market. On stock buyback, as you guys know, we're still committed to at least offset dilution and opportunistically, we'll do more than that.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I guess, just conceptually, how long can you run a business with $5 billion in revenue, but only $1 billion in backlog? That question pertaining to Aviation. I get it's become more of a turn business than a backlog business. I get there's component
componenttext: Scott, I guess, just conceptually, how long can you run a business with $5 billion in revenue, but only $1 billion in backlog? That question pertaining to Aviation. I get it's become more of a turn business than a backlog business. I get there's components of that revenue number that don't have backlog. But I mean, it seems like it's just a risky thing to do, where if you keep this kind of neutralish environment, you're fine. But if you were to have a more sinister backdrop, you'd have to maybe cut things more sharply than you would if you were already reset to where backlog is.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, no, I mean, the market is what it is. Like yes, I mean, we've been doing this for a long time, right, where we're kind of coming in with the [indiscernible] kind of backlog and our team is selling aircraft. And so I think that we're in a position he
componenttext: Well, no, I mean, the market is what it is. Like yes, I mean, we've been doing this for a long time, right, where we're kind of coming in with the [indiscernible] kind of backlog and our team is selling aircraft. And so I think that we're in a position here where we, even in a pretty flat market, we've been able to continue to eke out some growth on the top line in terms of -- just don't forget the deal, right, just organically in terms of -- we sold more King Airs this year than we sold last year. We sold more jets this year than we sold last year and we continue to expand the margin rate. So look, if I could pick up -- if somebody would give me another $1 billion or so of backlog, we'd take it. But the fact of the matter is that's not where the market's been, and it's been this way for -- and we're talking this morning, it's been at least 6 years, right, where we've been kind of operating in this mode and that's just the nature of this industry right now. It's not a big -- announce a plane and get billions of dollars of backlog. You go out and you sell them pretty much one point at a time and that's working for us, right? So our revenue keeps going up and our margins keep expanding, and that's what we're going to be doing.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it makes sense. So I guess the question was just more around risk mitigation of -- that's been working. But if you had a tougher global macro environment, that $1.1 billion could move sub-$1 billion pretty quickly and then you're staring at a more di
componenttext: Yes, it makes sense. So I guess the question was just more around risk mitigation of -- that's been working. But if you had a tougher global macro environment, that $1.1 billion could move sub-$1 billion pretty quickly and then you're staring at a more difficult situation, I guess, but I don't know.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, no, this is a -- it's just -- I mean, I appreciate the question. I understand. And as I said, if I could wave a magic wand and make it a different market environment, I'd certainly do that. Look, we -- where we spend most of our discretionary money
componenttext: Look, no, this is a -- it's just -- I mean, I appreciate the question. I understand. And as I said, if I could wave a magic wand and make it a different market environment, I'd certainly do that. Look, we -- where we spend most of our discretionary money is in new products. And what -- the new products have been working, right? If I was to go and say, "All right, guys, what if we took a different approach, what if we kind of honker down and ride this thing out, what if we didn't do the Sovereign+ or the Latitude or the M2 or -- boy, I think without all that new product investment, it would be tough to sustain a business that can grow revenue than expand margins.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm definitely not advocating for that. My question is more, should production be much lower on the Legacy products?
componenttext: Yes, I'm definitely not advocating for that. My question is more, should production be much lower on the Legacy products?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I -- we've taken those numbers down quite a bit over the years. And I think, right now, we're -- you're not seeing big overbuild of stuff, right? I mean, we're not pumping out white tails. We are matched pretty well -- our production today, ov
componenttext: Well, look, I -- we've taken those numbers down quite a bit over the years. And I think, right now, we're -- you're not seeing big overbuild of stuff, right? I mean, we're not pumping out white tails. We are matched pretty well -- our production today, over the last few years, frankly, has been running to demand. So we're not generating big surpluses of aircraft, I mean, we just don't that.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Makes sense. On the Latitude, on the new product topic, when you had us all at Wichita, you could see in the facility some tail numbers and you could see some tail numbers in the 30s. And so if I assume that you made it to a cumulative delivery number 30,
componenttext: Makes sense. On the Latitude, on the new product topic, when you had us all at Wichita, you could see in the facility some tail numbers and you could see some tail numbers in the 30s. And so if I assume that you made it to a cumulative delivery number 30, call it the middle of this year, that would get you somewhere in the vicinity of 30 Latitude deliveries for the year. Is that in the ballpark?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No, we would...
componenttext: No. No, we would...

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then so we should think about Legacy -- or production excluding that roughly flat and then roughly that number for the Latitude?
componenttext: Okay. And then so we should think about Legacy -- or production excluding that roughly flat and then roughly that number for the Latitude?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I just want to pursue a little bit more, and I know you've touched on it but I wanted to touch on a little more. The Aviation guide for margin in 2016, I mean, effectively, you're assuming that margin's really flat with '15 because you don't have a
componenttext: Scott, I just want to pursue a little bit more, and I know you've touched on it but I wanted to touch on a little more. The Aviation guide for margin in 2016, I mean, effectively, you're assuming that margin's really flat with '15 because you don't have any of the step-up in '16 that you had in '15. I know you commented that a lot of it is because of deliveries to fractionals. But still, I mean, to go from what you've been -- the high incrementals you've been running to a relatively minimal incremental of maybe 9%, at least in your guidance, seems pretty darn big shift. So I was just wondering if you'd comment a little bit more on it.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, George, I mean, I think you're accurate in terms of your assessment of kind of how we get there. And it's certainly on the lower end of the conversion than we would normally like to see. But no -- yes, a big piece of it is expectations on lower marg
componenttext: Well, George, I mean, I think you're accurate in terms of your assessment of kind of how we get there. And it's certainly on the lower end of the conversion than we would normally like to see. But no -- yes, a big piece of it is expectations on lower margin and in terms of the fractional, which is a big part of our growth, frankly, right? So if you look at that year-over-year incremental, and then I know it was just kind of walking through the math as well, reading serial numbers of aircraft, but the -- a lot of our incremental, as we go from '15 to '16, is Latitudes, and a big chunk of that is going into the fractional market. So I mean, I think that's the reality of where we are. A big piece of the year-over-year is going to be fractional deliveries which are at lower margin rates. It's still good business for us but at lower margin rates.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But one of the things that I came away with from the investor conference in Wichita was the cost that you had taken out on the Latitude versus the Sovereign. And so the -- my expectation was that the Latitude margin would start out no worse than some of t
componenttext: But one of the things that I came away with from the investor conference in Wichita was the cost that you had taken out on the Latitude versus the Sovereign. And so the -- my expectation was that the Latitude margin would start out no worse than some of the average mature programs that you had. I guess, is that -- I guess, that's not correct, I mean, or maybe it's just overwhelmed by the fractional ownership.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's the pricing on the fractionals as opposed to the cost basis. I think where we wanted to be on the cost -- we're pretty good about where we are on the cost on the latitudes. I mean, you're always going to have a little bit of inefficiencies in the ram
componenttext: It's the pricing on the fractionals as opposed to the cost basis. I think where we wanted to be on the cost -- we're pretty good about where we are on the cost on the latitudes. I mean, you're always going to have a little bit of inefficiencies in the ramp of a new one, but it's not a material issue for us. It's doing really well. The cost is in a good place. It's really a question of pricing on fractionals.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other one. Your comment to, I think, to Cai's question earlier about the book-to-bill being low this quarter -- but when I went back and looked at the book-to-bill in the fourth quarter of last year, it was actually around 1 versus
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other one. Your comment to, I think, to Cai's question earlier about the book-to-bill being low this quarter -- but when I went back and looked at the book-to-bill in the fourth quarter of last year, it was actually around 1 versus the 0.7 plus that we saw this quarter. So is there any added color you could provide on that?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, George. If you go back to fourth quarter last year, we did talk about the fact that we had a pretty significant international military order, and those are lumpier than a normal flow, so that contributed a pretty good backlog into Q4 next year. So i
componenttext: Sure, George. If you go back to fourth quarter last year, we did talk about the fact that we had a pretty significant international military order, and those are lumpier than a normal flow, so that contributed a pretty good backlog into Q4 next year. So if you took that out, the dynamic we've typically seen in Q4 is because it's such a high delivery quarter. It has been that we see a much lower book-to-bill in Q4. It's the least we have in recent time. And I don't -- so I don't think this year, if you were to back out the military deal in the fourth quarter, it doesn't look very different on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if the other markets continue to be pretty healthy. As I mentioned in the prepared comments, we saw growth again this year in all 3 regions, in North America, Europe and Asia, and all the forecast -- so yes, we drive our guidance obviously and our m
componenttext: Well, if the other markets continue to be pretty healthy. As I mentioned in the prepared comments, we saw growth again this year in all 3 regions, in North America, Europe and Asia, and all the forecast -- so yes, we drive our guidance obviously and our model based on what's out there in terms of what all the OEMs are saying. Right now, they're all forecasting growth again in 2016. And so we expect obviously to grow with that. We've had some nice wins on new models, which is helping to drive our growth. So our growth has been in excess of what overall markets have done on the other side, and I expect that will be true again in 2016.

componenttext: So on the aftermarket, on a couple of basis, we are pretty flat. componenttext: Maybe, Frank, a quick question on the balance sheet and maybe, Scott, on capital deployment. So is the idea to refi the notes coming due or repay and start to reduce debt further seems like you're getting to a point where maybe the debt load is at a point where you're comfortable? And so, Scott, is the M&A aperture actually increasing as there's more excess free cash flow here?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, from a balance sheet standpoint, we'll probably refi what we have coming due this coming year. So we're pretty comfortable now with our debt levels that the balance sheet has. We've had good flexibility over the past couple years, we think, fro
componenttext: Yes. Well, from a balance sheet standpoint, we'll probably refi what we have coming due this coming year. So we're pretty comfortable now with our debt levels that the balance sheet has. We've had good flexibility over the past couple years, we think, from an M&A standpoint, so I don't that there's a real change in the M&A aperture. We feel like we've been able to kind of do the things that we've wanted to do and we'll be able to continue to do that. But we will stop paying down debt at these levels.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as Frank said, look, our debt levels are getting about where they should be from a ratio standpoint, but I would add the same color to Frank there. We'll do deals that we think make sense. We haven't felt in any way constrained. Clearly, we have access
componenttext: So as Frank said, look, our debt levels are getting about where they should be from a ratio standpoint, but I would add the same color to Frank there. We'll do deals that we think make sense. We haven't felt in any way constrained. Clearly, we have access to the market if we need to do that, if the right deal came along, but we're not going to do deals that we don't think makes sense. And we're certainly not going to run around and try to find stuff or force stuff that we don't think fits on the business very well just to deploy it that way. It's -- I think our M&A strategy is one where we see opportunities. It's a great fit. We think we can get good leverage. It supports the balance of our business and then we'll do them.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I see that. But if you're starting to generate excess cash that's not going back to paying down debt is all I'm kind of getting at to. If you kind of think about the $600 million to $700 million pre-pension, you get a $100 million to repo and ano
componenttext: Yes. No, I see that. But if you're starting to generate excess cash that's not going back to paying down debt is all I'm kind of getting at to. If you kind of think about the $600 million to $700 million pre-pension, you get a $100 million to repo and another sub-$100 million to dividends and so you're starting to have excess cash. I'm just curious if, a, the aperture is -- can get better; or b, you want to be more opportunistic maybe on the industrial side as the rest of the world kind of derates in that sector?

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, again, I think -- I don't think our cash on the balance sheet thing is particularly excessive yet. I mean, so that's -- it's not like we're worried about cumulative to cash. We'll continue to be pretty aggressive at looking for opportunities ac
componenttext: Yes. Look, again, I think -- I don't think our cash on the balance sheet thing is particularly excessive yet. I mean, so that's -- it's not like we're worried about cumulative to cash. We'll continue to be pretty aggressive at looking for opportunities across all our business on the acquisition side. And as we said, we'll also be opportunistic around the share buyback in terms of deploying debt capital if we think it makes sense and based on where we share would frame. [ph]

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of big picture questions for you. On the Hemisphere, when you think about it, I know it's still early days, but with Gulfstream G450s coming off the line and my understanding is that they're selling for not too much over $30 million, isn't that a
componenttext: A couple of big picture questions for you. On the Hemisphere, when you think about it, I know it's still early days, but with Gulfstream G450s coming off the line and my understanding is that they're selling for not too much over $30 million, isn't that a really difficult place to try to put a new product? I mean, with the Gulfstream there, with the Bombardier guys there, with Dassault there, then it seems pretty crowded.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think when we look at the Hemisphere and how we size the Hemisphere, our intent is to be sort of just below where that market is because you're right, I think the 450, 550, the Global 7000, 8000, there's 7X, 8X, it's not our intent to be competing
componenttext: Look, I think when we look at the Hemisphere and how we size the Hemisphere, our intent is to be sort of just below where that market is because you're right, I think the 450, 550, the Global 7000, 8000, there's 7X, 8X, it's not our intent to be competing with that guy. So if somebody is looking at a G450, the Hemisphere is designed to be slotted sort of one tier below that echelon of aircraft. And we think that's the market where there hasn't been a lot of reinvestment by a lot of the big iron guys, which is why we're going there, not with the intent of going up and joining in that area because I think you're right, I think it's a well-served market. In terms of current pricing, I have no idea. That market cycles just like a midsized cycle. So where pricing and demand is right now is a function of the market. But the intent that we have with Hemisphere is it slots just below before you get into those big iron guys.

headline: Textron Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the Scorpion, look, I think the good news is that one of the most critical issues for that program was always determining a path to certification. I think the good news is, through a lot of work last year, the Air Force has now opened up the ability to
componenttext: So the Scorpion, look, I think the good news is that one of the most critical issues for that program was always determining a path to certification. I think the good news is, through a lot of work last year, the Air Force has now opened up the ability to go through an airworthiness process with the Air Force. They've initiated that program. And obviously, we fully expect to participate in that. So we have the first aircraft that will be the conforming test articles in production as we speak and are working with the Air Force to get under contract to have them conduct and ultimately provide Airworthiness Certification for the aircraft, so that's a big step forward for us.

componenttext: Well, I think, eventually, there could be either. Obviously, there's a lot going on budget wise in the U.S. government. But we've always thought that, while this is certainly intended more as international product for a lot of countries that can afford to fly the F-22s and the F-35s of the world, we certainly think the capability of the aircraft might be one at that price point and that capability could be attractive for a lot of missions that could include U.S.
