componenttext: And then last follow-up. So should we assume that the Latitude is a mixed negative in terms of your segment? And also could you comment on the level of used aircraft losses if any?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think as we talked about, I think the Latitude mix will be a slight drag in terms of our normal gross margin flow-through. We expect obviously that should improve over time. It's still a good product for us, but it's a little bit lower on the mi
componenttext: Yes. So I think as we talked about, I think the Latitude mix will be a slight drag in terms of our normal gross margin flow-through. We expect obviously that should improve over time. It's still a good product for us, but it's a little bit lower on the mix side than some of our other aircraft at this point. Used aircraft, there were some losses in the [indiscernible], but they are de minimis. I mean, they are not a material number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robert I would say if we look at the first quarter, there's no question that January and February were pretty rough. The turmoil in the market and general sentiment, I mean, I think caused a lot of people to sort of stop and wait to see what's going on. B
componenttext: Robert I would say if we look at the first quarter, there's no question that January and February were pretty rough. The turmoil in the market and general sentiment, I mean, I think caused a lot of people to sort of stop and wait to see what's going on. But as we went in through March and I'd say continuing now into April, the market has been pretty good. I mean, we'd always like to see it stronger but the momentum that we felt in the latter part of last year certainly took a pause through January and February, but it's returned to pretty decent market here in March going into April.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sam, I think that the commercial market is still challenging, for sure, on the helicopter side, and exchange rates, U.S. dollar doesn't help us particularly, but the 412, I would say our line of sight on the year for the guidance we provided, which i
componenttext: Yes, Sam, I think that the commercial market is still challenging, for sure, on the helicopter side, and exchange rates, U.S. dollar doesn't help us particularly, but the 412, I would say our line of sight on the year for the guidance we provided, which is around 12, I think is firming up. So I think we feel pretty good about that, and there's certainly opportunities out there as we look into the outyears, and there's a deals that still need to close, but they're still -- it's a great helicopter. It serves its purpose very well, it's got a great customer base, and there are still people looking at expanding, increasing their fleets of 412s. So I'd say we have pretty reasonable line of sight to the 2016 and are working opportunities that are going out into '17, '18 at this point.

componenttextpreview: Well, Sheila, I would say the total year R&D is probably going to be pretty consistent with what we guided, which we only do for the total company level. There's always a little bit of timing in this thing. I mean, clearly with getting ready for the fligh
componenttext: Well, Sheila, I would say the total year R&D is probably going to be pretty consistent with what we guided, which we only do for the total company level. There's always a little bit of timing in this thing. I mean, clearly with getting ready for the flight test programs and whatnot at Aviation and Longitude program, we spent a disproportionate amount of that in terms of the run rate getting ready for flight test. So the other programs are running about as we expected. There's really no change to the guidance. The 525 flight test programs are going very well and are consuming expense at about the pace we expected. V-280s going very well. We had nice significant milestones in the fabrication of that first unit for flight next year. So I think our guidance for the total year remains unchanged, and we just had some higher spending here in the first quarter, particularly the Aviation getting ready for the Longitude program.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Aviation has been fairly flattish on a year-over-year basis, Sheila. There's a couple of models that have seen a little bit of an uptick in price, a couple have been a little bit down in price. But overall, not a big impact in pricing really across t
componenttext: Yes, Aviation has been fairly flattish on a year-over-year basis, Sheila. There's a couple of models that have seen a little bit of an uptick in price, a couple have been a little bit down in price. But overall, not a big impact in pricing really across the whole company. Pricing's been relatively flat. As I said, I think part of it was we have to be a little bit patient here as we went through a couple of pretty tough months and hanging in there, but the demand environment, which is really kind of in the end what drives it, picked up in March and felt pretty good.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky from Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky from Citi.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Going back to Bell, can you just talk a little bit about the next multiyear on the V-22? There's been some recent report out there about how that's shaping up. Can you maybe provide a little bit color on your thoughts on that, particularly on the vol
componenttext: Yes. Going back to Bell, can you just talk a little bit about the next multiyear on the V-22? There's been some recent report out there about how that's shaping up. Can you maybe provide a little bit color on your thoughts on that, particularly on the volumes.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'd start by saying that it's early in that process. So we've already started to work with the customer on providing information. Right now, Jason, the challenge is it's a pretty broad range of volumes depending on is they're working on their bud
componenttext: Sure. So I'd start by saying that it's early in that process. So we've already started to work with the customer on providing information. Right now, Jason, the challenge is it's a pretty broad range of volumes depending on is they're working on their budget for those outyears. And obviously, it's -- there's a mix of what they want to do with a program of record. For the Marine Corps, you've seen some articles other about the Air Force having an interest in some additional CVs. There's the Navy program and how that starts to drive demand as well as creating some optionality around FMS opportunities. So right now, when we're providing numbers, it's across a pretty broad range of units. So it's -- at this point, I'd be reluctant to put a number out there. Seriously, I don't think there's anything we'd want to guide to yet to give you guys idea because it is just the range of opportunity is just too high in terms of where that number falls out. It could -- it's just a -- they're running the numbers, running the financials and asking us for a lot of input on a pretty broad range of possible numbers of units.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, but asking it differently without FMS, is the top end of that range allow you to hold current production rates?
componenttext: Okay, but asking it differently without FMS, is the top end of that range allow you to hold current production rates?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it's likely that we will hold current production rates. It's going to be -- it'll be south of that. I really don't see a potential outcome that would be at current production rates. So we are planning for another decrement down when we g
componenttext: No, I don't think it's likely that we will hold current production rates. It's going to be -- it'll be south of that. I really don't see a potential outcome that would be at current production rates. So we are planning for another decrement down when we get out there into that '19, '20 time frame, but it's -- we just don't know how big that decrement's going to be right now. When you look at Navy, that's 40-some units. There's still 20 some in the Marine Corps program at record. There could be a couple of CVs. There could be some optionality built in for FMS, but I do not think that the expectations should be it would run at the current run rates.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then the follow-on, the LOI got from the 505 and the 525, can you just remind us when those convert into actual contracts? When will you start telling us we'll have a better idea of what your ramp's going to look like on deliveries f
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then the follow-on, the LOI got from the 505 and the 525, can you just remind us when those convert into actual contracts? When will you start telling us we'll have a better idea of what your ramp's going to look like on deliveries for both of those aircraft? Just timing of the LOIs could bring the contract.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you'll start to can see conversion on 505 contracts and probably starting here pretty soon. Those aircraft will be looking at initial deliveries likely in the fourth quarter. So there's already conversations going on with customers that are -- wil
componenttext: I think you'll start to can see conversion on 505 contracts and probably starting here pretty soon. Those aircraft will be looking at initial deliveries likely in the fourth quarter. So there's already conversations going on with customers that are -- will convert to actual contracts. I would say on the 525, you won't likely see that until sometime as you get closer to certification in mid-summer or so last year -- next year rather with a -- just because our certification expectations are kind of late summer, early fall before we would start firming those up for deliveries by the end of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, geographically, is North America kind of still the only game in town? I think you had been running, I don't know, 75% of your Citation deliveries were North America, and I think a similar amount at Bell commercial. I'm wondering if that's the statu
componenttext: Scott, geographically, is North America kind of still the only game in town? I think you had been running, I don't know, 75% of your Citation deliveries were North America, and I think a similar amount at Bell commercial. I'm wondering if that's the status. And if there's any change you detect in the North American market versus 3 or 4 months ago.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly the Aviation side, it's still more or less U.S. driven. I think Jets this quarter were probably about 80% U.S. deliveries, about 20% international deliveries. If you look at our turboprop product, between the King Air and the caravans, tho
componenttext: Well, certainly the Aviation side, it's still more or less U.S. driven. I think Jets this quarter were probably about 80% U.S. deliveries, about 20% international deliveries. If you look at our turboprop product, between the King Air and the caravans, those are more like 50-50 U.S. and international, and that's more difficult for those products, and I think the turboprops are doing well. Caravans, particularly in China, are strong. So we -- but I would say, however, that we're starting to see some momentum pick up a little bit in Europe. So I think you'll start to see some increased jet deliveries over there and turboprop again staying fairly balanced between U.S. and international as we go through the balance of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. Got you. And then last one, I just want to know your expectation was on this Air Force nuclear helicopter program. I think basically you guys are the incumbent. It's -- I think a few billion dollars probably, and there's been a lot of chatter
componenttext: Okay, okay. Got you. And then last one, I just want to know your expectation was on this Air Force nuclear helicopter program. I think basically you guys are the incumbent. It's -- I think a few billion dollars probably, and there's been a lot of chatter that they would sole source it to a competitor. I'm just wondering what your expectation is there, and if you had any thoughts.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, we're probably seeing and hearing the same thing that you're hearing. It sounds like, I mean, we are the incumbent, but those helicopters have been there, those are Hueys from a long time ago, and at least the requirements that we've seen out the
componenttext: So look, we're probably seeing and hearing the same thing that you're hearing. It sounds like, I mean, we are the incumbent, but those helicopters have been there, those are Hueys from a long time ago, and at least the requirements that we've seen out there we think they're looking for a larger, a different helicopter. So we're seeing and hearing the same chatter. It sounds like they're looking at going sole source to another product at this point.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just Scott, quickly wondered if you could give us some color on what you saw in service revenues across Aviation and Bell in the quarter?
componenttext: Just Scott, quickly wondered if you could give us some color on what you saw in service revenues across Aviation and Bell in the quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the Aviation side, it was pretty consistent with where we've been. I think it's around 35% of revenue. On the helicopter side, I'm sorry I don't have exact percentage here in front of me, but it was down a bit year-over-year, and I think that's just
componenttext: So on the Aviation side, it was pretty consistent with where we've been. I think it's around 35% of revenue. On the helicopter side, I'm sorry I don't have exact percentage here in front of me, but it was down a bit year-over-year, and I think that's just reflecting that we continue to see lower utilization, particularly in the oil and gas segment in the marketplace.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when do you think you'll reach a bottom on that? I mean, clearly there's some destocking in that end market. So when do you start to lap that some of the easier compares there?
componenttext: Yes, when do you think you'll reach a bottom on that? I mean, clearly there's some destocking in that end market. So when do you start to lap that some of the easier compares there?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hard to say, Carter, I mean, I would just be just making a total guess, but I think a lot of it's going to have to do with obviously what happens with oil prices and when the guys start utilizing the assets. I can tell you down in the Gulf, where we have
componenttext: Hard to say, Carter, I mean, I would just be just making a total guess, but I think a lot of it's going to have to do with obviously what happens with oil prices and when the guys start utilizing the assets. I can tell you down in the Gulf, where we have an awful lot of 412s that are operating with the oil prices being down, things have been slower. Frankly, some customers are going to slow the pace some of the operators that we work. As a result, those guys will put aircraft on the ground or back off in general, but it's got to go through it's cycle. So I'm not probably the right guy to opine on the oil prices and what that recovery looks like, but I think it'll tie more to that going for that forward.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on Systems just a quick follow-up, any more color you can give us on the unmanned revenue in the quarter? Is that a negative impact for the margins?
componenttext: Great. And then on Systems just a quick follow-up, any more color you can give us on the unmanned revenue in the quarter? Is that a negative impact for the margins?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think the unmanned is probably in line with typically what we expect for margins in that business. We've seen fairly high utilization our fee-for-service program, which are going well, and the aircraft are performing well and executing the contracts
componenttext: No, I think the unmanned is probably in line with typically what we expect for margins in that business. We've seen fairly high utilization our fee-for-service program, which are going well, and the aircraft are performing well and executing the contracts that we have. We've continued to deliver the upgrades for the Shadow B2 program, and those are going to flowing through exactly as we expected, and we've got some decent business development work going on for some international sales and things like that. So I think everything in the unmanned world is good. The margins obviously, we were this quarter fairly light at marine and land systems because we'll largely generate a lot of the revenue here in the third and fourth quarter associated with Canadian program obviously, getting that milestones is complete was a big deal for us. So I think each of the units are doing well and are where we expected, but unmanned is good business and margins consistent with our expectations.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to start with the first question on Aviation margins because, I guess, in Q1, you were talking earlier about how the margins were a couple of hundred points short of the full year margin target in Aviation based off of mix of leverage, volume
componenttext: Just wanted to start with the first question on Aviation margins because, I guess, in Q1, you were talking earlier about how the margins were a couple of hundred points short of the full year margin target in Aviation based off of mix of leverage, volume leverage and also R&D. As we think about the rest of the year and how you make up that 200 bps, should we think about that is fairly evenly split between R&D trailing off and leverage recovery? Or is there some sort of weighting between the 2?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julian, I mean, I think it's -- I wouldn't read a whole lot into the Q1 numbers, right? I mean, the revenue us was up $40 million. So leverage on $40 million, a couple of million of -- a few million of R&D, a couple million of this or that just make such
componenttext: Julian, I mean, I think it's -- I wouldn't read a whole lot into the Q1 numbers, right? I mean, the revenue us was up $40 million. So leverage on $40 million, a couple of million of -- a few million of R&D, a couple million of this or that just make such a huge swing. So I don't think there's anything that I would look at the first quarter granted, yes, just in terms of specific R&D, the R&D spending is probably somewhat disproportionate in terms of the overall impact on margins here in Q1 that would be in the latter quarters. But I mean, I really don't think there's anything fundamental we look at in the leverage issue in the first quarter as being indicative of what's going to happen in Q2, 3 and 4. So our guidance that we provided you guys around sort of that window of overall operating margin percent, I think we're on track to do that in the revenue side. So the leverage is going to be pretty consistent, I think, with what we told you, and again the number in Q1 is such a small incremental on the revenue that I don't think you read a whole lot into it in terms of leverage.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very clear, and a follow-up would be around the manufacturing cash outflow. That was about $100 million higher year-over-year. The vast majority of that due to working capital stepping up but, at the same time, your buyback spend in Q1 suggests you're ver
componenttext: Very clear, and a follow-up would be around the manufacturing cash outflow. That was about $100 million higher year-over-year. The vast majority of that due to working capital stepping up but, at the same time, your buyback spend in Q1 suggests you're very confident of that cash flows swinging around. So maybe just giving a little bit of background as to where that big working capital build really came and you think we should see the manufacturing cash flow swing positive in the second quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think first of all, on an absolute basis, you guys know we generally consume cash in the first quarter. We tend to have inventory build associated with products that do sell off good, better and different Aviation, and Bell tend to have more higher s
componenttext: So I think first of all, on an absolute basis, you guys know we generally consume cash in the first quarter. We tend to have inventory build associated with products that do sell off good, better and different Aviation, and Bell tend to have more higher sales in the latter part of the year. So on an absolute basis, there's -- I don't think there's anything terribly surprising. In terms of the year-over-year comparative, we will have a situation with respect to customer deposits primarily almost exclusively, frankly, on the military side of Bell whereas a result of performance-based payments over the last couple of years. We had a favorable position in terms of working capital, which will unwind through the course of this year, and that's a good part of what you're seeing here in the first quarter, but those numbers are absolutely consistent with what we guided you guys in the overall cash number. So we'll see that working capital impact through the course of the year. But again, completely planned and consistent with the expectation, and so we have no change in our confidence in terms of our overall cash flow for the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott, I wanted to pursue a little bit more this R&D. So you made a comment first thing that the R&D spend was more than offset what was maybe $5 million step up in Beech. Could you quantify how much more it offset? And then how much lower the R&D mi
componenttext: Yes, Scott, I wanted to pursue a little bit more this R&D. So you made a comment first thing that the R&D spend was more than offset what was maybe $5 million step up in Beech. Could you quantify how much more it offset? And then how much lower the R&D might be in the subsequent quarters?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the dynamics we have in the quarter, George, for sure, we have the last quarter really of any of the step-up impact on accounting in Aviation. That was about a $5 million number, and all I'm saying is that our spending on the R&D side on a year-over-ye
componenttext: So the dynamics we have in the quarter, George, for sure, we have the last quarter really of any of the step-up impact on accounting in Aviation. That was about a $5 million number, and all I'm saying is that our spending on the R&D side on a year-over-year basis to be comparative was a number that was quite a bit bigger than that. So it was -- if you take those 2 significant pieces, it was dilutive to our margin rate or overall leverage, if you will, on a year-over-year basis. But again, in either case are these huge numbers. It's just when you're looking at a $40 million increase in revenue, the difference between $4 million better in margin and $8 million better in margin, 10% leverage, 20% leverage, you're talking about a couple million dollars. So it's -- none of these numbers are big numbers, and so...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I reckon. So I was wondering so is R&D of $10 million versus, say, the step up being $5 million in the quarter just trying to roughly calculate what that impact might be and then how much higher R&D was this quarter than what you might expect it to be in
componenttext: I reckon. So I was wondering so is R&D of $10 million versus, say, the step up being $5 million in the quarter just trying to roughly calculate what that impact might be and then how much higher R&D was this quarter than what you might expect it to be in subsequent quarters?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, it was on the order of about $10 million. I mean, I think for modeling purposes that's about the right number to put in there. Again, it's not a particular big number, and we don't expect it to change our overall company R&D over the whole course
componenttext: George, it was on the order of about $10 million. I mean, I think for modeling purposes that's about the right number to put in there. Again, it's not a particular big number, and we don't expect it to change our overall company R&D over the whole course of the year. It's a relatively small number, but it's on that magnitude.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: okay. So does R&D go down a little bit then in the subsequent quarters?
componenttext: okay. So does R&D go down a little bit then in the subsequent quarters?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but again not by a very big number because it was only up by a very small number.
componenttext: Yes, but again not by a very big number because it was only up by a very small number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, understood. And, Frank, just to qualify the tax rate was more like 30% this quarter versus the 31% guide? Are we going to still see 31%? Or is 30% a better number?
componenttext: Right, understood. And, Frank, just to qualify the tax rate was more like 30% this quarter versus the 31% guide? Are we going to still see 31%? Or is 30% a better number?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Use 31%. It obviously depends on, at the end of the day, kind of what our international versus domestic mix is, and we won't know that until we move further into the year but I continue to use 31%.
componenttext: Use 31%. It obviously depends on, at the end of the day, kind of what our international versus domestic mix is, and we won't know that until we move further into the year but I continue to use 31%.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one last one, Scott. Orders this year versus last year's first quarter were up like $90 million or so or almost 10%. Was that still primarily domestic? Or did you see more of the orders from international at all this quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And one last one, Scott. Orders this year versus last year's first quarter were up like $90 million or so or almost 10%. Was that still primarily domestic? Or did you see more of the orders from international at all this quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say on the jet side, most of the orders in the quarter were U.S. I think we'll see more international mix here certainly as we're proceeding through April into Q2.
componenttext: I would say on the jet side, most of the orders in the quarter were U.S. I think we'll see more international mix here certainly as we're proceeding through April into Q2.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Seth Seifman from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Seth Seifman from JPMorgan.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll really beg for your indulgence here to ask one more question about Aviation margins, which is just that if you look at what's implied for the remainder of the year, it looks fairly flat with what you did in Q2, Q3 and Q4 overall last year, excluding
componenttext: I'll really beg for your indulgence here to ask one more question about Aviation margins, which is just that if you look at what's implied for the remainder of the year, it looks fairly flat with what you did in Q2, Q3 and Q4 overall last year, excluding the inventory step up, and so to have flat margins year-on-year in Aviation for the rest of the year when it would seem like more Latitude deliveries to NetJets would be headwind, what's sort of the opposing factor that allows you to keep those margins flat?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in general performance in the business is, I mean, the guys are executing well, and we do have some volume that's increased on a year-over-year basis, and we still have good gross margin product, so that does great some leverage to help offs
componenttext: Well, I think in general performance in the business is, I mean, the guys are executing well, and we do have some volume that's increased on a year-over-year basis, and we still have good gross margin product, so that does great some leverage to help offset some of what might be a bit of a negative mix on a year-over-year comparative basis in terms of the mix of aircraft. So...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just as a follow-up also in terms of the pickup in activity that you've seen in March and April in terms of where it is or across, would you say it's across platforms? Or is there any place where it's concentrated? I mean, one of the
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just as a follow-up also in terms of the pickup in activity that you've seen in March and April in terms of where it is or across, would you say it's across platforms? Or is there any place where it's concentrated? I mean, one of the reasons I ask, I know that we're talking about small number so it's hard to tell. But if you just look at the high end, the sovereign and ex deliveries were fairly low in Q1. I know Q1 is light, but is that a place where you're seeing kind of incremental weakness and demand relative to the other platforms?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably what you're seeing with the Latitude in there, we do see some aircraft that maybe a year, 2 years ago could be sovereign are now going to be Latitude. So the aircraft in terms of their range and performance are different, and for a lot of ou
componenttext: It's probably what you're seeing with the Latitude in there, we do see some aircraft that maybe a year, 2 years ago could be sovereign are now going to be Latitude. So the aircraft in terms of their range and performance are different, and for a lot of our customers, the sovereign is still the right answer, and that's why we still see these in both sales of sovereign but for sure when we look at the total number of aircraft in that sovereign space, some of those are now becoming Latitude. So someone's in the middle of the country or they're in Europe or they're in some place, where that 2,800 nautical miles will get you there, they're tending to err on that side of the Latitude versus sovereign. So that explains kind of where I think we are on sovereigns and on 10s, as we said, that's a fairly unique product. It's been very popular product over time, but it's a relatively small number of units each year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It sounded like in the fourth quarter, the King Airs may be were a little bit disappointing on the international side, but I guess, Scott, some of your commentary there sounded like you had seen a pickup as expected, and so I expect year-on-year growth in
componenttext: It sounded like in the fourth quarter, the King Airs may be were a little bit disappointing on the international side, but I guess, Scott, some of your commentary there sounded like you had seen a pickup as expected, and so I expect year-on-year growth in King Airs.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think we've seen the King Air market been pretty solid in most applications. I'd say it's been a little lighter on special missions there has in the past. That's a little bit of what we saw in the fourth quarter and the first quarter this y
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think we've seen the King Air market been pretty solid in most applications. I'd say it's been a little lighter on special missions there has in the past. That's a little bit of what we saw in the fourth quarter and the first quarter this year, but remember we also the conversion going from the old cockpit to the new model that came out very late last year, and so getting that into production and getting the last of the older models sold and not making that conversion to the new model also has some impact on volume. But frankly, with the new model out there selling well, we just got certification in Europe, which is through is a big deal for us. So I think we feel pretty good about the King Air market and where it's going.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just a clarification on the margins, the pension tailwind year-over-year, I expect it would have been $10 million to $15 million across the segments, maybe Aviation they got $5 million of that. Is that the right way to think about the tailw
componenttext: Okay, and then just a clarification on the margins, the pension tailwind year-over-year, I expect it would have been $10 million to $15 million across the segments, maybe Aviation they got $5 million of that. Is that the right way to think about the tailwind for pension.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, probably somewhere around that $10 million number, but most of that is actually taken at corporate, just the way we -- I mean, we spent -- it wouldn't be $5 million at Aviation. It's going to be a smaller number than that. So I wouldn't -- I don't hav
componenttext: No, probably somewhere around that $10 million number, but most of that is actually taken at corporate, just the way we -- I mean, we spent -- it wouldn't be $5 million at Aviation. It's going to be a smaller number than that. So I wouldn't -- I don't have the exact number in front of me, but it's relatively small number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a benefit, but it's spread around the organization.
componenttext: There's a benefit, but it's spread around the organization.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your neck next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Your neck next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague with Vertical Research.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, just a couple of questions on cash flow. Frank, thanks for the color on the -- or maybe it was Scott but on the military dynamics, but just trying to think about the quarter here. Accounts receivable and inventories were both actually up. I would gue
componenttext: Hey, just a couple of questions on cash flow. Frank, thanks for the color on the -- or maybe it was Scott but on the military dynamics, but just trying to think about the quarter here. Accounts receivable and inventories were both actually up. I would guess that Bell issue was actually some accrued account somewhere. Can you speak to what was going on in the accounts receivable and inventories in the quarter?

So I think that the scope of the contract that we have this for the sales directly to Boeing, but obviously, from our perspective while that's a great contract, and we're thrilled to have it, it also gives us, we think, the position in the marketplace that we should win our fair share of end customers from Boeing who'll buy their own simulator. So it's the contract value specifically associated with Boeing plus future opportunities that are still to be determined.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it is. So true -- when we bought Mechtronix, obviously part of the rationale for the acquisition was we felt they had some terrific technology, very capable team and a great product, but they were very small company, and they had, had some challenges
componenttext: No, it is. So true -- when we bought Mechtronix, obviously part of the rationale for the acquisition was we felt they had some terrific technology, very capable team and a great product, but they were very small company, and they had, had some challenges and got a little overleveraged at one point and ran into some can financial trouble. And that hurts you in that market because when you look at the customers, whether it's a Boeing or a lot of the major airlines in the world, these assets are like an aircraft they're very long-lived, right? So companies want to know when you're buying a fairly high dollar capital item that you're going to be able to be around and provide the services and support and upgrades and such over time, and I do think that one of the things that hampered them in the marketplace was as a result of their financial struggles. They had some uncertainty around them. So it was any technical or product problem. It was a business liability issue, and obviously, when we acquired sort of put our balance sheet and reputation behind it, that kind of got rid of that sort of barrier with a lot of customers. So the team up there won the 737 MAX a couple of years ago. I think that they've executed very, very well on that. The Boeing folks obviously have been very happy with how the team has performed on the 737 MAX, and that gave them confidence to then also make us their partner on the 777 X. So if you execute well and perform well, it can snowball in the right direction. But for sure, part of the underlying pieces of the deal was he thought you had a company that a lot of great technology, great product, great capability, but it needed to have a little more certainty and strength from a financial standpoint, and I think we provided that.

componenttext: So I think there's a fair bit of international interest. We still have a lot of customers that are talking to us. We have aircraft all over the country. We have a lot of customers flying it. Really the next major milestone for us, there's really 2. One is we had a couple of relatively minor things that we wanted to change in the production configuration of the aircraft. We completed that engineering work, and we're in the manufacturing process right now, building that, let's call it, the conforming production version of the aircraft. Customers, obviously, want to fly that and see that before they would place an order. And the other was around airworthiness how do you get a certification and as I think you heard publicly, there is now Air Force program. There's program office, where they will conduct Airworthiness Certification of aircraft that were not funded in development by the Air Force. And so we've already submitted our application in that process, so that's a work in progress as well. So we think this all kind of dovetails with getting the first conforming article built and ready to fly here in probably early to mid-summer, and the airworthiness program will get underway and the Air Force ultimately will try to provide the Airworthiness Certification of that aircraft, which is a big deal to all our prospective customers.

componenttextpreview: Well, the principal deals in the quarter were Able Engineering, which we announced. This is a repair and overhaul business that's sort of a mix of both Bell product as well as some fixed wing products. So we acquired that early in the quarter. That's now
componenttext: Well, the principal deals in the quarter were Able Engineering, which we announced. This is a repair and overhaul business that's sort of a mix of both Bell product as well as some fixed wing products. So we acquired that early in the quarter. That's now integrated into our Aviation services network, but it's providing both work actually right now probably more Bell than anything else. So they had a company who had great relations with a number of our customers that looked at a mix of how they maintain their fleet with a combination of both new parts as well as some parts can be overhauled. We've entered that business through the acquisition with Able, and frankly, that's going very well so far. We also acquired in the first quarter a company called. This is a company that provides technical training and principally under contract to the U.S. Navy. So supporting our current customers with fly missions that allow the Navy and the Marine Corps to not utilize their own asset to provide things like training, controlling training as well as adversary forces for schools like top gun as well as a lot of other aggressor forces to emulate enemy aircraft and exercises conducted by the U.S. Navy and the Marine Corps. I also has history doing some work for the Air Force. There's a number of opportunities out there that we think we continue to grow in that space, and that's a nice augmentation for us in terms of how we address customers within the U.S. as well as internationally to provide training capability. There was also a very small acquisition that we did in the quarter, a lot of the service and support that was done on the simulation training platforms in particular, the actual simulator maintenance, which is an important part of the business. That had been effectively outsourced for quite some time to a small company that was doing that. We think providing the right level of service to support is critical to those products over time and didn't feel comfortable we should be dependent on a third party. So we acquired that was basically acquiring the people. So they're now part of the company as opposed to having third party conducting that service and support speech. So the M&A impact on Aviation.
