Please go ahead.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. 
Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our SEC filings and also in today's press release.
On the call today we have Scott Donnelly, Textron's Chairman and CEO; and Frank Connor, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Our earnings call presentation can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website.
Textron's revenues in the quarter were $3.2 billion, up $128 million from last year's finance -- first quarter. Income from continuing operations was $0.55 per share, up 19.6% from $0.46 reported in last year's first quarter. Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions was a $222 million use of cash compared to $125 million use of cash in last year's first quarter. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. Revenues were up 4.2% in the quarter, reflecting the success of our strategy of investing for growth both in new products and acquisitions. Segment revenue was up in Industrial, Aviation and Systems while essenti
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. Revenues were up 4.2% in the quarter, reflecting the success of our strategy of investing for growth both in new products and acquisitions. Segment revenue was up in Industrial, Aviation and Systems while essentially flat at Bell, consistent with our expectations. 
At Bell, we delivered 6 V-22s, flat with last year's first quarter; 10 H-1s, up 4 units from last year; and 30 commercial helicopters, down from 35 a year ago. On the commercial side, we had a good showing at Heli-Expo where we displayed actual flight test articles of our new 525 Relentless and 505 Jet Ranger, both of which generated significant interests. At the show, we signed a letter of intent for 10 525s with [indiscernible] Group, a Chinese investment company. More recently, we also signed an LOI with PT White Sky Aviation, an Indonesian operator, for 30 505s. Development on both programs is proceeding well. 
The 3 test 505 helicopters have completed over 700 test hours with certification and first deliveries expected later this year. The 525 has 2 aircraft in flight test with a third unit expected to enter soon. The Relentless is meeting or exceeding all of its performance objectives including having demonstrated a top speed in excess of 200 knots. The effectiveness of 525's integrated fly-by-wire design has been evident during the testing by the aircraft's superior in-flight handling, maneuverability and stability. Combining these factors should significantly contribute to the value of this aircraft for our customers. 
At HAI, we also announced the new Bell Customer Advantage Plan or CAP, which provides our customers the opportunity to lock in predictable, cost-effective maintenance for their aircraft. Our CAP product delivers broad covered solutions for our customers' daily operation, which, in turn, protects the value of their investment while increasing aircraft availability. 
We were also named #1 in helicopter service and support for the 22nd consecutive year by Pro Pilot magazine. 
On the H-1 front, we have received recent orders from the DoD for 61 additional units including 9 FMS units for Pakistan. This takes production through the first quarter of 2019. The remaining U.S. DoD program record and significant additional foreign military demand provide a solid launch and outlook for this program. 
Moving to Systems. Revenues were up modestly, primarily driven by higher Unmanned Systems volumes. During the quarter, Textron Relentless systems received $174 million contract for 5 additional ship-to-shore units to be delivered in 2020. Earlier this month, we were also awarded a contract for 60 COMMANDO Select Armored Vehicles to be delivered this year in Iraq and Colombia. On the Canadian TAPV program, we're on track for deliveries beginning in the third quarter as we successfully completed the customer reliability testing program 2 weeks ago. 
At TRU Simulation + Training, we were just awarded another contract by Boeing to design and manufacture simulators for their newest twin-aisle airplane, the 777X. 
Moving to Industrial. We saw a 9.2% increase in revenue, reflecting our continued investments. During the quarter, in Specialized Vehicles, we launched our newest Bad Boy product, the Onslaught 550, a midsized 4x4 ATV. 
At Jake, we announced the HR700, which is the world's first 14-foot-wide rotary motor, providing increased productivity for our professional turf care customers. 
At Tools & Test, new products in our electric utility space are driving significant growth from this category. 
At Kautex, our selective catalytic reduction products and geographic expansion drove growth in excess of global vehicle production rates. 
Moving to Textron Aviation. We delivered 34 jets in the quarter compared to 33 last year and 26 King Airs compared to 25 last year. Our sales success affirms that our strategy of investing in new products is resonating with aircraft buyers. 
During the first quarter, we also received European certification for the Latitude as well as the Pro Line Fusion-equipped King Air 250 and 350. Advance sales of Latitude fractionals by NetJets to their end customers have been going very well and we look forward to starting deliveries of the new aircraft later this summer. 
To sum up. We had a good start to the year as demand in our end markets finished the quarter generally consistent with what we were expecting. Operationally, we also had another good quarter as we achieved margin improvements at each of our manufacturing segments. We continue to believe that we will be able to generate solid overall growth in revenue, earnings and cash this year. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $280 million, up $21 million from the first quarter of 2015 on $128 million increase in revenues. Let's review how each of the segments contributed starting with Textron Avi
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $280 million, up $21 million from the first quarter of 2015 on $128 million increase in revenues. 
Let's review how each of the segments contributed starting with Textron Aviation. At Textron Aviation, revenues were up $40 million from this period last year, primarily due to higher jet volume. Segment profit was $73 million, up from $67 million a year ago. Backlog in this segment ended the quarter at $1,047,000,000 lower than at the end of the fourth quarter. 
Moving to Bell. Revenues were essentially flat as higher military revenues offset lower commercial revenues. Segment profit increased $6 million from the first quarter of 2015, primarily due to improved performance. 
At Systems, revenues were up $9 million, primarily due to higher Unmanned Systems volumes while segment profit was up $1 million. 
Industrial revenues increased $80 million due to higher overall volumes and the impact of acquisitions. Segment profit increased $9 million, also reflecting the higher volumes and the impact of acquisitions. 
Finance segment revenues decreased $2 million and profit decreased $1 million. 
Moving below the segment line. Corporate segment -- or corporate expenses were $32 million compared to $43 million last year, reflecting the impact of a lower stock price on our share-based compensation expense. Interest expense was $33 million, flat from last year. 
During the quarter, we issued $350 million in 10-year notes at a rate of 4%. This was effectively prefunding the retirement of $250 million in 4 5/8% notes that are set to mature in September. We also repurchased 6.2 million shares of stock during the quarter, returning $215 million in cash to shareholders. 
To wrap up with guidance. We are confirming our expected full year EPS from continuing operations of $2.60 to $2.80 a share, and cash flow from continuing operations of the manufacturing group before pension contributions of $600 million to $700 million. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. So Greg, we can open the line for questions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So your Aviation volume was up, but your inventory step-up was down. Maybe give us some color in terms of why the profitability wasn't a little bit better?
componenttext: Yes. So your Aviation volume was up, but your inventory step-up was down. Maybe give us some color in terms of why the profitability wasn't a little bit better?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Cai, I think that when you look at the first quarter, the revenue increase was fairly modest. So in terms of leverage, we're talking about sort of what I would call the law of small numbers, okay? We, I think, had pretty good execution by the team.
componenttext: Well, Cai, I think that when you look at the first quarter, the revenue increase was fairly modest. So in terms of leverage, we're talking about sort of what I would call the law of small numbers, okay? We, I think, had pretty good execution by the team. We had an awful lot of R&D spending, frankly, as we're getting ready to do the first Longitude flight here coming up in the early part of this summer. And so even with step-up as you note in there, which was probably $5 million, $6 million, something like that, that was more than offset by a fair bit of R&D spending to get ready for Longitude. So there's nothing fundamentally different, I don't think. The mix obviously was more biased towards Latitude and some of our Legacy aircraft, but that's something we expected and kind of talked about in the context of our overall guidance for the segment leverage for the year and I think that's what we're seeing kind of play through.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a last follow-up. So should we assume that the Latitude is a mixed negative in terms of your shipment? And also could you comment on the level of used aircraft losses, if any.
componenttext: And then a last follow-up. So should we assume that the Latitude is a mixed negative in terms of your shipment? And also could you comment on the level of used aircraft losses, if any.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes, I think that -- as we talked about, I think the Latitude mix will be a slight drag in terms of our normal gross margin flow-through. We expect obviously that should improve over time. It's still a good product for us, but it's a little bit lower o
componenttext: So yes, I think that -- as we talked about, I think the Latitude mix will be a slight drag in terms of our normal gross margin flow-through. We expect obviously that should improve over time. It's still a good product for us, but it's a little bit lower on the mix side than some of our other aircraft at this point. Used aircraft, there were some losses in the quarter, but they're de minimis. I mean, they are not a material number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from RBC.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, there's been a lot of negativity in the last couple of months about the business jet demand environment. Used inventory seemed to have gone up. Pricing softened. I was wondering what Cessna was seeing out there in terms of customer interest and how
componenttext: Scott, there's been a lot of negativity in the last couple of months about the business jet demand environment. Used inventory seemed to have gone up. Pricing softened. I was wondering what Cessna was seeing out there in terms of customer interest and how confident you are in your forecast for 2016 in this division.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robert, I would say that if we look to the first quarter, there's no question that January and February were pretty rough flooding. The turmoil in the market and the general sentiment, I mean, I think caused a lot of people to sort of stop and wait to see
componenttext: Robert, I would say that if we look to the first quarter, there's no question that January and February were pretty rough flooding. The turmoil in the market and the general sentiment, I mean, I think caused a lot of people to sort of stop and wait to see what's going on. But as we went in through March and I'd say continuing now into April, the market has been pretty good. I mean, we'd always like to see it stronger but the momentum that we felt in the latter part of last year certainly took a pause through January and February, but it's returned to a pretty decent market here in March going into April.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up. Frank, obviously, you highlighted the buyback was strong in Q1. Do you expect it to moderate going forward? And would you more be interested in acquisitions perhaps?
componenttext: And then as a follow-up. Frank, obviously, you highlighted the buyback was strong in Q1. Do you expect it to moderate going forward? And would you more be interested in acquisitions perhaps?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said, I mean, we'll continue to take a look at what the acquisition opportunities look like, our cash flow needs and we return excess capital to shareholders, as you say. We -- kind of we did a lot of that in the first quarter. We'll continue
componenttext: Well, as we said, I mean, we'll continue to take a look at what the acquisition opportunities look like, our cash flow needs and we return excess capital to shareholders, as you say. We -- kind of we did a lot of that in the first quarter. We'll continue to look at kind of the appropriate use of capital as we go through the year, but we're ahead of the game in terms of our certainly our plan to at least offset dilution at this point.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on that last comment about the share count. Do you still assume it's going to be the 277 million shares? Or now that it was heavier in the first quarter, will that be lower for the year?
componenttext: Just following up on that last comment about the share count. Do you still assume it's going to be the 277 million shares? Or now that it was heavier in the first quarter, will that be lower for the year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It should be lower for the year by about the number over the normal dilution, so kind of 3-ish million. We bought about 3 million more than our normal employee plan dilution would reflect and it'd be lower by about that amount.
componenttext: It should be lower for the year by about the number over the normal dilution, so kind of 3-ish million. We bought about 3 million more than our normal employee plan dilution would reflect and it'd be lower by about that amount.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you talk a little bit about Bell and what you've seen as far as demand on the 412s and the relatively stronger dollar hurt you in those sales? And I guess, I'm wondering with 2 deliveries in the first quarter, are we still on track for
componenttext: Okay. And then can you talk a little bit about Bell and what you've seen as far as demand on the 412s and the relatively stronger dollar hurt you in those sales? And I guess, I'm wondering with 2 deliveries in the first quarter, are we still on track for 12 of them?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, I think that the commercial market is still challenging, for sure, on the helicopter side and exchange rates, U.S. dollar doesn't help us particularly. But the 412, I would say, our line of sight on the year for the guidance we provided, which was ar
componenttext: Sam, I think that the commercial market is still challenging, for sure, on the helicopter side and exchange rates, U.S. dollar doesn't help us particularly. But the 412, I would say, our line of sight on the year for the guidance we provided, which was around 12, I think, is firming up. So I think we feel pretty good about that and there are certainly opportunities out there as we look into the out-years and there's deals that still need to close, but they're still -- it's a great helicopter. It serves its purpose very well, it's got a great customer base and there are still people looking at expanding, increasing their fleets of 412s. So I'd say we have pretty reasonable line of sight on -- to the 2016 and are working opportunities that are going out to '17, '18 at this point.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sheila Kahyaoglu with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sheila Kahyaoglu with Jefferies.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, on R&D, can you talk about the expectations for R&D for the full year maybe on a segment basis? And then also in terms of headcount, I think you added headcount across 3 of the 4 segments with the exception of Bell and maybe what that additional
componenttext: I guess, on R&D, can you talk about the expectations for R&D for the full year maybe on a segment basis? And then also in terms of headcount, I think you added headcount across 3 of the 4 segments with the exception of Bell and maybe what that additional capacity is for.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Sheila, I would say that the total year R&D is probably going to be pretty consistent with what we guided, which we only do for the total company level. There's always a little bit of timing in this thing. I mean, clearly with getting ready for the
componenttext: Well, Sheila, I would say that the total year R&D is probably going to be pretty consistent with what we guided, which we only do for the total company level. There's always a little bit of timing in this thing. I mean, clearly with getting ready for the flight test programs and whatnot at Aviation and the Longitude program, we spent a disproportionate amount of that in terms of the run rate getting ready for flight test. So the other programs are running about as we expected. There's really no change to the guidance. The 525 flight test programs are going very well and are consuming expense at about the pace we expected. V-280 is going very well. We've had some nice significant milestones in the fabrication of that first unit for flight next year. So I think our guidance for the total year remains unchanged, we just had some higher spending here in the first quarter particularly Aviation getting ready for the Longitude program.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on headcount?
componenttext: Okay. And then on headcount?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The headcount numbers, I don't -- I'm not sure. I don't have the exact numbers in front of me, Sheila. I don't think there's any big material changes. The only place we've had really material changes in headcount, unfortunately, have really been around Be
componenttext: The headcount numbers, I don't -- I'm not sure. I don't have the exact numbers in front of me, Sheila. I don't think there's any big material changes. The only place we've had really material changes in headcount, unfortunately, have really been around Bell and that's mostly been dialing back some of the production run rates in Mirabel on the commercial helicopter front. Other than that, it's been, I think, relatively stable in most of the businesses.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to follow up on the demand question asked earlier. It's pretty original, but can you just talk about pricing and maybe if the competitive environment has changed at all?
componenttext: Okay. And then just to follow up on the demand question asked earlier. It's pretty original, but can you just talk about pricing and maybe if the competitive environment has changed at all?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In...
componenttext: In...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: In -- more so in Aviation, I guess.
componenttext: In -- more so in Aviation, I guess.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Aviation has been fairly flattish on a year-over-year basis, Sheila. There's a couple of models that have seen a little bit of an uptick in price, a couple have been a little bit down in price. But overall, not a big impact in pricing really across t
componenttext: Yes, Aviation has been fairly flattish on a year-over-year basis, Sheila. There's a couple of models that have seen a little bit of an uptick in price, a couple have been a little bit down in price. But overall, not a big impact in pricing really across the whole company. Pricing has been relatively flat. As I said, I think part of it is we had to be a little bit patient here as we went through a couple pretty tough months and hanging in there, but the demand environment, which is really kind of in the end what drives it, picked up in March and felt pretty good.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky from Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky from Citi.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to go back to Bell. Scott, can you talk a little bit about the next multiyear on the V-22? There's been some recent reports out there about how that's shaping up. If you can provide a little bit color on your thoughts on that, that'd be helpful
componenttext: Yes. Just to go back to Bell. Scott, can you talk a little bit about the next multiyear on the V-22? There's been some recent reports out there about how that's shaping up. If you can provide a little bit color on your thoughts on that, that'd be helpful particularly around the volumes.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'd start by saying that it's early in that process. So we've already started to work with the customer on providing information. Right now, Jason, the challenge is it's a pretty broad range of volumes depending on is they're working on their bud
componenttext: Sure. So I'd start by saying that it's early in that process. So we've already started to work with the customer on providing information. Right now, Jason, the challenge is it's a pretty broad range of volumes depending on is they're working on their budget for those out-years and obviously it's -- there's a mix of what they want to do with a program of record. For the Marine Corps, you've seen some articles other about the Air Force having an interest in some additional CVs. There's the Navy COG program and how that starts to drive demand as well as creating some optionality around FMS opportunities. So right now, when we're providing numbers, it's across a pretty broad range of units. So it's -- at this point, I'd be reluctant to put a number out there. Seriously, I don't think there's any we'd want to guide to yet to give you guys an idea because it's just -- the range of opportunity is just too high in terms of where that number falls out. It could -- it's just a -- they're running the numbers, running the financials and asking us for a lot of input on a pretty broad range of possible numbers of units.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But let me ask it a different way, without FMS, does the top end of that range allow you to hold current production rates?
componenttext: Okay. But let me ask it a different way, without FMS, does the top end of that range allow you to hold current production rates?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it's likely that we will hold current production rates. It's going to be -- it'll be south of that. I really don't see a potential outcome that would be the current production rate. So we are planning for another decrement down when we g
componenttext: No, I don't think it's likely that we will hold current production rates. It's going to be -- it'll be south of that. I really don't see a potential outcome that would be the current production rate. So we are planning for another decrement down when we get out there into that '19, '20 time frame, but it's -- we just don't know how big that decrement's going to be right now. When you look at Navy COG, that's 40-some units, there are still 20-some in the Marine Corps program of record. There could be a couple of CVs. There could be some optionality built in for FMS. But I do not think that the expectation should be it would run at the current run rates.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then the follow-on, the LOI that you got on the 505 and the 525, can you just remind us when those convert into actual contracts? When will you start telling us or have a better idea of what your ramp is going to look like on deliver
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then the follow-on, the LOI that you got on the 505 and the 525, can you just remind us when those convert into actual contracts? When will you start telling us or have a better idea of what your ramp is going to look like on deliveries for both of those aircraft? So just kind of the timing of the LOIs converting to contracts.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we'll start to can see conversion on 505 contracts and probably starting here pretty soon. Those aircraft we'll be looking at the initial deliveries likely in the fourth quarter. So there's already conversations going on with customers that
componenttext: Well, I think we'll start to can see conversion on 505 contracts and probably starting here pretty soon. Those aircraft we'll be looking at the initial deliveries likely in the fourth quarter. So there's already conversations going on with customers that are -- will convert those to actual contracts. I would say on the 525, you won't likely see that until sometime as you get closer to certification in midsummer or so last year -- next year rather with a -- just because our certification expectations are kind of late summer, early fall before we would start firming those up for deliveries by the end of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, geographically, is North America kind of still the only game in town? I think you had been running, I don't know, 75% of your Citation deliveries were North America and I think a similar amount at Bell commercial. I'm just wondering if that's the s
componenttext: Scott, geographically, is North America kind of still the only game in town? I think you had been running, I don't know, 75% of your Citation deliveries were North America and I think a similar amount at Bell commercial. I'm just wondering if that's the status. And if there's any change that you detect in the North America market versus 3 or 4 months ago.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, on the Aviation side, it's still more or less U.S. driven. I think jets this quarter were probably about 80% U.S. deliveries, about 20% international deliveries. If you look at our turboprop product, between the King Air and the Caravans,
componenttext: Well, certainly, on the Aviation side, it's still more or less U.S. driven. I think jets this quarter were probably about 80% U.S. deliveries, about 20% international deliveries. If you look at our turboprop product, between the King Air and the Caravans, those are more like 50-50 U.S. and international and that's more typical for those products. And I think the turboprops are doing well. Caravans, particularly in China, are strong. So we -- but I would say, however, we're starting to see some momentum pick up a little bit in Europe. So I think you'll start to see some increased jet deliveries over there and turboprop again staying fairly balanced between U.S. and international as we go through the balance of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. Got you. And then the last one, I just want to know your expectation was on this Air Force nuclear helicopter program. I think basically you guys are the incumbent. It's, I think, a few billion dollars probably and there's been a lot of chatte
componenttext: Okay, okay. Got you. And then the last one, I just want to know your expectation was on this Air Force nuclear helicopter program. I think basically you guys are the incumbent. It's, I think, a few billion dollars probably and there's been a lot of chatter that they would sole source it to a competitor. I'm just wondering what your expectation is there and if you had any thoughts.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, we're probably seeing and hearing the same things  that you're hearing. It sounds like -- I mean, we are the incumbent, but those helicopters have been there, those are Hueys from a long time ago and at least the requirements that we've seen o
componenttext: Well, look, we're probably seeing and hearing the same things  that you're hearing. It sounds like -- I mean, we are the incumbent, but those helicopters have been there, those are Hueys from a long time ago and at least the requirements that we've seen out there we think they're looking for a larger and a different helicopter. So we're seeing and hearing the same chatter. It sounds like they're looking at going sole source to another product at this point.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just Scott, quickly, wondered if you could give us some color on what you saw in service revenues across Aviation and Bell in the quarter?
componenttext: Just Scott, quickly, wondered if you could give us some color on what you saw in service revenues across Aviation and Bell in the quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the Aviation side, it was pretty consistent with where we've been. I think it was around 35% of revenue. On the helicopter side, I'm sorry I don't have exact percentage here in front of me, but it was down a bit year-over-year. And again, I think th
componenttext: So on the Aviation side, it was pretty consistent with where we've been. I think it was around 35% of revenue. On the helicopter side, I'm sorry I don't have exact percentage here in front of me, but it was down a bit year-over-year. And again, I think that's just reflecting that we continue to see lower utilization, particularly in the oil and gas segment in the marketplace.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when do you think you'll reach a bottom on that? I mean, clearly there's some destocking in that end market. So when do you start to lap some of the easier compares there?
componenttext: Yes, when do you think you'll reach a bottom on that? I mean, clearly there's some destocking in that end market. So when do you start to lap some of the easier compares there?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hard to say, Carter. I mean, I would be just making a total guess, but I think a lot of it's going to have to do with obviously what happens with oil prices and when the guys start utilizing the assets. I can tell you down in the Gulf where we have an awf
componenttext: Hard to say, Carter. I mean, I would be just making a total guess, but I think a lot of it's going to have to do with obviously what happens with oil prices and when the guys start utilizing the assets. I can tell you down in the Gulf where we have an awful lot of 412s that are operating with the oil prices being down, things have been slower. Frankly, some customers are going to slow the pace, some of the operators that we work, and so as a result, those guys will -- they'll put aircraft on the ground or they'll back off in general. But it's got to go through its cycle. So I'm not probably the right guy to opine on the oil prices and what that recovery looks like, but I think it'll tie more to that going forward.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on Systems, just a quick follow-up. Any more color you can give us on the Unmanned revenue in the quarter? Do you have a negative impact for the margins?
componenttext: Great. And then on Systems, just a quick follow-up. Any more color you can give us on the Unmanned revenue in the quarter? Do you have a negative impact for the margins?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think the unmanned is probably in line with typically what we expect for margins in that business. We've seen fairly high utilization on our fee-for-service programs, which are going well. I know the aircraft are performing well and executing the co
componenttext: No, I think the unmanned is probably in line with typically what we expect for margins in that business. We've seen fairly high utilization on our fee-for-service programs, which are going well. I know the aircraft are performing well and executing the contracts that we have. We've continued to deliver the upgrades for the Shadow B2 program and those are going to flowing through exactly as we expected, and we've got some decent business development work going on for some international sales and things like that. So I think everything at the -- in the Unmanned world is good. The margins, obviously, we were this quarter fairly light at Marine & Land Systems because we'll largely generate a lot of the revenue here in the third and fourth quarter associated with the Canadian TAPV program, obviously getting that milestones and the test complete was a big deal for us. So I think each of the units are doing well and where we expected, but Unmanned is good business and margins consistent with our expectations.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to start with the first question on Aviation margins because, I guess, in Q1, you were talking earlier about how the margins were a couple of hundred points short of the full year margin target in Aviation based off a mix of leverage, volume l
componenttext: Just wanted to start with the first question on Aviation margins because, I guess, in Q1, you were talking earlier about how the margins were a couple of hundred points short of the full year margin target in Aviation based off a mix of leverage, volume leverage and also R&D. As we think about the rest of the year and how you make up that 200 bps, should we think about that as fairly evenly split between R&D tailing off and leverage recovering? Or is there some sort of weighting between the 2?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julian, I mean, I think it's -- I wouldn't read a whole lot into the Q1 numbers, right? I mean, the revenue was up $40 million. So leverage on $40 million, a couple of million of -- a few million of R&D, a couple million of this or that just make such a h
componenttext: Julian, I mean, I think it's -- I wouldn't read a whole lot into the Q1 numbers, right? I mean, the revenue was up $40 million. So leverage on $40 million, a couple of million of -- a few million of R&D, a couple million of this or that just make such a huge swing. So I don't think there's anything that I would look at the first quarter granted, yes, just in terms of specifically R&D, the R&D spending is probably somewhat disproportionate in terms of the overall impact on margins here in Q1 that would be in the latter quarters. But I mean, I really don't think there's anything fundamental we look at in the leverage issue in the first quarter as being indicative of what's going to happen in Q2, 3 and 4. So our guidance that we provided you guys around sort of that window of overall operating margin percent, I think we're on track to do that in the revenue side. So the leverage is going to be pretty consistent, I think, with what we told you. And again, the number in Q1 is such a small incremental on the revenue that I don't think you can read a whole lot into it in terms of leverage.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very clear. And then my follow-up would be around the Manufacturing cash outflow, that was about $100 million higher year-over-year. The vast majority of that due to working capital stepping up. But at the same time, your buyback spend in Q1 suggests you'
componenttext: Very clear. And then my follow-up would be around the Manufacturing cash outflow, that was about $100 million higher year-over-year. The vast majority of that due to working capital stepping up. But at the same time, your buyback spend in Q1 suggests you're very confident of that cash flow swinging around. So maybe just give a little bit of background as to where that big working capital build really came. And you think we should see the Manufacturing cash flow swing positive in the second quarter.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, first of all, on an absolute basis, you guys know we generally consume cash in the first quarter. We tend to have inventory build associated with products that do sell off good, better and different. Aviation and Bell tend to have more higher
componenttext: So I think, first of all, on an absolute basis, you guys know we generally consume cash in the first quarter. We tend to have inventory build associated with products that do sell off good, better and different. Aviation and Bell tend to have more higher sales in the latter part of the year. So on an absolute basis, there's -- I don't think there's anything terribly surprising. In terms of the year-over-year comparative, we do have a situation with respect to customer deposits primarily -- almost exclusively, frankly, on the military side of Bell whereas as a result of performance-based payments over the last couple of years, we had a favorable position in terms of working capital, which will unwind through the course of this year and that's a good part of what you're seeing here in the first quarter. But those numbers are absolutely consistent with what we guided you guys in the overall cash number. So we'll see that working capital impact through the course of the year. But again, completely planned and consistent with expectation and so we have no change in our confidence in terms of our overall cash flow for the year.

componenttext: So the dynamics we have in the quarter, George, for sure, we have the last quarter really of any of the step-up impact on accounting in Aviation, that was about a $5 million number. It's just when you're looking at a $40 million increase in revenue, the difference between $4 million better in margin and $8 million better in margin, 10% leverage, 20% leverage, you're talking about a couple million dollars. So it's -- none of these numbers are big numbers and so...

componenttext: I'll really beg for your indulgence here to ask one more question about Aviation margins, which is just that if you look at what's implied for the remainder of the year, it looks fairly flat with what you did in Q2, Q3 and Q4 overall last year excluding the inventory step-up. And so to have flat margins year-on-year in Aviation for the rest of the year when it would seem like more Latitude deliveries to NetJets would be a headwind, what's sort of the opposing factor that allows you to keep those margins flat?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, in general, performance in the business is, I mean, the guys are executing well and we do have some volume that's increased on a year-over-year basis and we still have good gross margin product, so that does create some leverage to help off
componenttext: Well, I think, in general, performance in the business is, I mean, the guys are executing well and we do have some volume that's increased on a year-over-year basis and we still have good gross margin product, so that does create some leverage to help offset some of what might be a bit of a negative mix on a year-over-year comparative basis in terms of the mix of aircraft. So...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just as a follow-up also in terms of the pickup in activity that you've seen in March and April in terms of where it is across -- would you say it's across platforms? Or is there any place where it's concentrated? I mean, one of the
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just as a follow-up also in terms of the pickup in activity that you've seen in March and April in terms of where it is across -- would you say it's across platforms? Or is there any place where it's concentrated? I mean, one of the reasons I ask, I know we're talking about small number so it's hard to tell, but if you just look at the high end, the Sovereign and X deliveries were fairly low in Q1. I know Q1 is light, but is that a place where you're seeing kind of incremental weakness and demand relative to the other platforms?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably some of what you're seeing is, with the Latitude in there, we do see some aircraft that maybe a year or 2 years ago could have been a Sovereign are now going to be a Latitude. So the aircraft in terms of their range and performance are diffe
componenttext: It's probably some of what you're seeing is, with the Latitude in there, we do see some aircraft that maybe a year or 2 years ago could have been a Sovereign are now going to be a Latitude. So the aircraft in terms of their range and performance are different. And for a lot of our customers, the Sovereign is still the right answer and that's why we still see reasonable sales of Sovereign. But for sure, when we look at the total number of aircraft in that Sovereign space, some of those are now becoming Latitudes. So someone's in the middle of the country or they're in Europe or they're in some place where that 2,800 nautical miles will get you there, they're tending to err on the side of a Latitude versus a Sovereign. So that explains kind of where I think we are on Sovereigns. And on 10s, as we said, that's a fairly unique product. It's been a very popular product over time, but it's a relatively small number of units each year.

componenttext: It sounded like in the fourth quarter, the King Airs maybe were a little bit disappointing on the international side, but I guess, Scott, some of your commentary there sounded like you had seen a pickup as expected and so I expect year-on-year growth in King Airs?

componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think we've seen the King Air market pretty solid in most applications. I'd say it's been a little lighter on special missions that it has in the past and that's a little bit of what we saw in the fourth quarter and the first quarter this year. But remember, we also had the conversion going from the old cockpit to the new model that came out very late last year and so getting that into production and getting the last of the older models sold and now making that conversion to the new model also has some impact on volume. But frankly, with the new model out there selling well, we just got certification in Europe, which is through EASA is a big deal for us. So I think we feel pretty good about the King Air market and where it's going.

componenttext: And then one just last one. Could you give us some idea of what percent of the Aviation backlog is, the NetJet, Latitudes or some way to just kind of think about that?

componenttext: No, we don't get into that level of detail on the backlog, Jeff. But the only thing I'd say around the NetJet thing is that we really don't put stuff in -- from NetJets into that backlog until we have agreed delivery dates and tail numbers and that stuff. So we will incrementally add NetJets to that backlog only when we and NetJet says, hey, look, who wants delivery. This is the date, this is the tail and so there's only a small percentage of that overall order is in backlog today and that will grow the number we put in there fairly linearly as they start taking deliveries and start committing to the next aircraft delivery date.

componenttext: Yes, we can provide some color around that. The -- I didn't have that number right in front of me. But if you looked at the overall growth rates for -- I'm not sure how to break it out exactly. Our Specialized Vehicle business had pretty reasonable growth. We had relatively flat market in our Tools & Test world. Again, there's dynamics within that, which we kind of talked a little bit about it. I think we're doing very well in the utilities space. A lot of the other tools that were highly consumed by a lot of the oil and gas exploration kind of guys obviously continues to be soft, but net, there was some growth in that segment. We had very solid growth on the automotive side of things on a year-over-year basis and the turf care world was relatively flat.

componenttext: Well, I think we feel pretty good about where we are right now. The guys and pretty much all the businesses had a pretty solid quarter, but it's probably a little early in the year to feel like we would materially change the range on what we told you with respect to the segments. So certainly on the track we're on right now, there'd be towards the high end of it, but I'd say it's pretty early in the year, too.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ronald Epstein from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ronald Epstein from Bank of America.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe a couple quick details. You guys announced that you won a 777X flight simulator at Mechtronix, so congratulations on that. How big is that potentially? I mean, how do we think about that for the Mechtronix business?
componenttext: Just maybe a couple quick details. You guys announced that you won a 777X flight simulator at Mechtronix, so congratulations on that. How big is that potentially? I mean, how do we think about that for the Mechtronix business?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a good question. So the -- and I had to be careful because I don't know exactly all that was disclosed with our customer. But certainly, the scope of that contract is to provide the simulators for their use as well as their training centers and
componenttext: Well, it's a good question. So the -- and I had to be careful because I don't know exactly all that was disclosed with our customer. But certainly, the scope of that contract is to provide the simulators for their use as well as their training centers and beyond that, obviously, a lot of Boeing's 777 customers will buy their own simulators for doing their own pilot training. So I think that the scope of the contract that we have is for the sales directly to Boeing. But obviously, from our perspective, while that's a great contract and we're thrilled to have it, it also gives us, we think, the position in the marketplace that we should win our fair share of end customers from Boeing who buy their own simulator. So it's the contract value specifically associated with Boeing plus future opportunities that are still to be determined.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I was just -- maybe just for clarity, but this is a bigger -- Mechtronix historically wasn't as big a player, right, in the large commercial, right? This is a nice new segment of business for them? Correct or no?
componenttext: And I was just -- maybe just for clarity, but this is a bigger -- Mechtronix historically wasn't as big a player, right, in the large commercial, right? This is a nice new segment of business for them? Correct or no?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it is. So true -- when we bought Mechtronix, obviously part of the rationale for the acquisition was we felt they had some terrific technology, very capable team and a great product. But they were a very small company and they had, had some challenges
componenttext: No, it is. So true -- when we bought Mechtronix, obviously part of the rationale for the acquisition was we felt they had some terrific technology, very capable team and a great product. But they were a very small company and they had, had some challenges and got a little over-leveraged at one point and ran into some can financial trouble and that hurts you in that market because when you look at the customers, whether it's a Boeing or a lot of the major airlines in the world, these assets are like an aircraft. They're very long-lived, right, so companies want to know when you're buying a fairly high dollar capital item that you're going to be able to be around and provide the service and support and upgrades and such over time. And I do think that one of the things that hampered them in the marketplace was, as a result of their financial struggles, they had some uncertainty around them. So it wasn't a technical or product problem, it was a business liability issue and obviously when we acquired them and sort of put our balance sheet and reputation behind it, that kind of got rid of that sort of barrier with a lot of customers. So the team up there won the 737 MAX a couple of years ago. I think that they've executed very, very well on that. The Boeing folks obviously have been very happy with how the team has performed on the 737 MAX and that gave them confidence to then also make us their partner on the 777X. So if you execute well and perform well, it can sort of snowball in the right direction. But for sure, part of the underlying pieces of the deal was that we thought we had a company that a lot of great technology, great product, great capability, but it needed to have a little more certainty and strength from a financial standpoint and I think we've provided that.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, cool. And then one more, my favorite airplane, the Scorpion. Where do we stand on international interest, potential order, that kind of thing for it?
componenttext: Yes, cool. And then one more, my favorite airplane, the Scorpion. Where do we stand on international interest, potential order, that kind of thing for it?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think there's a fair bit of international interest. We still have a lot of customers that are talking to us. We've had the aircraft all over the country. We've had a lot of customers flying it. Really the next major milestone for us -- well, there's
componenttext: So I think there's a fair bit of international interest. We still have a lot of customers that are talking to us. We've had the aircraft all over the country. We've had a lot of customers flying it. Really the next major milestone for us -- well, there's really 2. One is that we've had a couple relatively minor things that we wanted to change in the production configuration of the aircraft. We've completed that engineering work and we're in the manufacturing process right now, building that, let's call it, the conforming production version of the aircraft. Customers obviously want to fly that and see that before they would place an order. And the other issue was, for us, was always around airworthiness and how do you get a certification. And as I think you've heard publicly, there is now an Air Force program. They're standing of a program office where they will conduct airworthiness certification of aircraft that were not funded in development by the Air Force. And so we've already submitted our application in that process. So that's sort of a work in progress as well. So we think this all kind of dovetails with getting the first conforming article built and ready to fly here in probably early to midsummer, and the air airworthiness program will get underway and the Air Force ultimately will provide the airworthiness certification of that aircraft, which is a big deal to all of our prospective customers so...

componenttext: Okay. And then just to make sure, you commented that aftermarket was about 35% of revenues each year, which would imply about 3.5% to 4% growth in the aftermarket?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you had $164 million of acquisitions in the quarter, Scott. Maybe if you could just list what they were because you make a couple of small ones and it's hard to keep track of them.
componenttext: Okay. And you had $164 million of acquisitions in the quarter, Scott. Maybe if you could just list what they were because you make a couple of small ones and it's hard to keep track of them.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the principal deals in the quarter were Able Engineering, which we announced. This is a repair and overhaul business that does sort of a mix of both Bell product as well as some fixed-wing products. So we acquired that early in the quarter. That's n
componenttext: Well, the principal deals in the quarter were Able Engineering, which we announced. This is a repair and overhaul business that does sort of a mix of both Bell product as well as some fixed-wing products. So we acquired that early in the quarter. That's now integrated into our Aviation services network, but it's providing both work -- or actually right now, probably more Bell than anything else. So they had a company who had great relations with a number of our customers that looked at a mix of how they maintain their fleet with a combination of both new parts as well as some parts that can be overhauled. We've entered that business through that acquisition with Able and frankly that's going very well so far. We also acquired in the first quarter a company called ATAC. This is a company that provides tactical training and principally under contract to the U.S. Navy. So supporting our current customers with fly missions that allow the Navy and the Marine Corps to not utilize their own assets to provide things like tactical area training, controller training as well as adversary forces for schools like Top Gun as well as a lot of other aggressor forces to emulate enemy aircraft and exercises conducted by the U.S. Navy and the Marine Corps. It also has history doing some work for the Air Force. There's a number of opportunities out there that we think we continue to grow in that space and that's a nice augmentation for us in terms of how we address customers both in the U.S. as well as internationally to provide training capability. There was also a very small acquisition that we did in the quarter, a lot of the service and support that was done on the TRU Simulation + Training platforms, in particular the actual simulator maintenance, which is an important part of the business. That had been effectively outsourced for quite some time to a small company that was doing that. We think providing the right level of service and support is critical to those products over time and didn't feel comfortable that we should be dependent on a third party, so we acquired -- it was basically acquiring the people so that they're now part of the company as opposed to having a third party conducting that service and support.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Vice Presi
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Doug Wilburne. Please go ahead.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. 
Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our SEC filings and also in today's press release.
On the call today we have Scott Donnelly, Textron's Chairman and CEO; and Frank Connor, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Our earnings call presentation can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website.
Textron's revenues in the quarter were $3.2 billion, up $128 million from last year's finance -- first quarter. Income from continuing operations was $0.55 per share, up 19.6% from $0.46 reported in last year's first quarter. Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions was a $222 million use of cash compared to $125 million use of cash in last year's first quarter. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. Revenues were up 4.2% in the quarter, reflecting the success of our strategy of investing for growth both in new products and acquisitions. Segment revenue was up in Industrial, Aviation and Systems while essenti
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. Revenues were up 4.2% in the quarter, reflecting the success of our strategy of investing for growth both in new products and acquisitions. Segment revenue was up in Industrial, Aviation and Systems while essentially flat at Bell, consistent with our expectations. 
At Bell, we delivered 6 V-22s, flat with last year's first quarter; 10 H-1s, up 4 units from last year; and 30 commercial helicopters, down from 35 a year ago. On the commercial side, we had a good showing at Heli-Expo where we displayed actual flight test articles of our new 525 Relentless and 505 Jet Ranger, both of which generated significant interest. At the show, we signed a letter of intent for 10 525s with Guangxi Diwang Group, a Chinese investment company. More recently, we also signed an LOI with PT Whitesky Aviation, an Indonesian operator, for 30 505s. Development on both programs is proceeding well. 
The 3 test 505 helicopters have completed over 700 test hours with certification and first deliveries expected later this year. The 525 has 2 aircraft in flight test with a third unit expected to enter soon. The Relentless is meeting or exceeding all of its performance objectives including having demonstrated a top speed in excess of 200 knots. The effectiveness of 525's integrated fly-by-wire design has been evident during the testing by the aircraft's superior in-flight handling, maneuverability and stability. Combining these factors should significantly contribute to the value of this aircraft for our customers. 
At HAI, we also announced the new Bell Customer Advantage Plan or CAP, which provides our customers the opportunity to lock in predictable, cost-effective maintenance for their aircraft. Our CAP product delivers broad covered solutions for our customers' daily operation, which, in turn, protects the value of their investment while increasing aircraft availability. 
We were also named #1 in helicopter service and support for the 22nd consecutive year by Pro Pilot magazine. 
On the H-1 front, we have received recent orders from the DoD for 61 additional units including 9 FMS units for Pakistan. This takes production through the first quarter of 2019. The remaining U.S. DoD Program of Record and significant additional foreign military demand provide a solid long-term outlook for this program. 
Moving to Systems. Revenues were up modestly, primarily driven by higher Unmanned Systems volumes. During the quarter, at Textron Marine & Land Systems we received $174 million contract for 5 additional ship-to-shore units to be delivered in 2020. Earlier this month, we were also awarded a contract for 60 COMMANDO Select Armored Vehicles to be delivered this year in Iraq and Colombia. On the Canadian TAPV program, we're on track for deliveries to begin in the third quarter as we successfully completed the customer reliability testing program 2 weeks ago. 
At TRU Simulation + Training, we were just awarded another contract by Boeing to design and manufacture simulators for their newest twin-aisle airplane, the 777X. 
Moving to Industrial. We saw a 9.2% increase in revenue, reflecting our continued investments. During the quarter, in Specialized Vehicles, we launched our newest Bad Boy product, the Onslaught 550, a midsized 4x4 ATV. 
At Jake [ph], we announced the HR700, which is the world's first 14-foot-wide rotary mower, providing increased productivity for our professional turf care customers. 
At Tools & Test, new products in our electric utility space are driving significant growth in this category. 
At Kautex, our selective catalytic reduction products and geographic expansion drove growth in excess of global vehicle production rates. 
Moving to Textron Aviation. We delivered 34 jets in the quarter compared to 33 last year and 26 King Airs compared to 25 last year. Our sales success affirms that our strategy of investing in new products is resonating with aircraft buyers. 
During the first quarter, we also received European certification for the Latitude as well as the Pro Line Fusion-equipped King Air 250 and 350. Advance sales of Latitude fractionals by NetJets to their end customers have been going very well and we look forward to starting deliveries of the new aircraft later this summer. 
To sum up. We had a good start to the year as demand in our end markets finished the quarter generally consistent with what we were expecting. Operationally, we also had another good quarter as we achieved margin improvements at each of our manufacturing segments. We continue to believe that we will be able to generate solid overall growth in revenue, earnings and cash this year. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $280 million, up $21 million from the first quarter of 2015 on $128 million increase in revenues. Let's review how each of the segments contributed, starting with Textron Av
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $280 million, up $21 million from the first quarter of 2015 on $128 million increase in revenues. 
Let's review how each of the segments contributed, starting with Textron Aviation. At Textron Aviation, revenues were up $40 million from this period last year, primarily due to higher jet volume. Segment profit was $73 million, up from $67 million a year ago. Backlog in this segment ended the quarter at $1,047,000,000 lower than at the end of the fourth quarter. 
Moving to Bell. Revenues were essentially flat as higher military revenues offset lower commercial revenues. Segment profit increased $6 million from the first quarter of 2015, primarily due to improved performance. 
At Systems, revenues were up $9 million, primarily due to higher Unmanned Systems volumes while segment profit was up $1 million. 
Industrial revenues increased $80 million due to higher overall volumes and the impact of acquisitions. Segment profit increased $9 million, also reflecting the higher volumes and the impact of acquisitions. 
Finance segment revenues decreased $2 million and profit decreased $1 million. 
Moving below the segment line. Corporate segment -- or corporate expenses were $32 million compared to $43 million last year, reflecting the impact of a lower stock price on our share-based compensation expense. Interest expense was $33 million, flat from last year. 
During the quarter, we issued $350 million in 10-year notes at a rate of 4%. This was effectively prefunding the retirement of $250 million in 4 5/8% notes that are set to mature in September. We also repurchased 6.2 million shares of stock during the quarter, returning $215 million in cash to shareholders. 
To wrap up with guidance. We are confirming our expected full year EPS from continuing operations of $2.60 to $2.80 a share, and cash flow from continuing operations of the manufacturing group before pension contributions of $600 million to $700 million. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. So Greg, we can open the line for questions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So your Aviation volume was up, but your inventory step-up was down. Maybe give us some color in terms of why the profitability wasn't a little bit better?
componenttext: Yes. So your Aviation volume was up, but your inventory step-up was down. Maybe give us some color in terms of why the profitability wasn't a little bit better?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Cai, look, I think that you look at the first quarter, the revenue increase was fairly modest. So in terms of leverage, we're talking about sort of what I would call the law of small numbers, okay? We, I think, had pretty good execution by the team.
componenttext: Well, Cai, look, I think that you look at the first quarter, the revenue increase was fairly modest. So in terms of leverage, we're talking about sort of what I would call the law of small numbers, okay? We, I think, had pretty good execution by the team. We had an awful lot of R&D spending, frankly, as we're getting ready to do the first Longitude flight here coming up in the early part of this summer. And so even with step-up as you note in there, which was probably $5 million, $6 million, something like that, that was more than offset by a fair bit of R&D spending to get ready for Longitude. So there's nothing fundamentally different, I don't think. The mix obviously was more biased towards Latitudes and some of our Legacy aircraft, but that's something we expected and kind of talked about in the context of our overall guidance for the segment leverage for the year, and I think that's what we're seeing kind of play through.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a last follow-up. So should we assume that the Latitude is a mix negative in terms of your shipment? And also could you comment on the level of used aircraft losses, if any.
componenttext: And then a last follow-up. So should we assume that the Latitude is a mix negative in terms of your shipment? And also could you comment on the level of used aircraft losses, if any.

componenttextpreview: So yes, I think that -- as we talked about, I think the Latitude mix will be a slight drag in terms of our normal gross margin flow-through. We expect, obviously, that should improve over time. It's still a good product for us, but it's a little bit lower
componenttext: So yes, I think that -- as we talked about, I think the Latitude mix will be a slight drag in terms of our normal gross margin flow-through. We expect, obviously, that should improve over time. It's still a good product for us, but it's a little bit lower on the mix side than some of our other aircraft at this point. Used aircraft, there were some losses in the quarter count, but they're de minimis. I mean, they are not a material number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from RBC.

componenttext: Scott, there's been a lot of negativity in the last couple of months about the business jet demand environment. Used inventory seemed to have gone up. Pricing softened. I was wondering what Cessna is seeing out there in terms of customer interest and how confident you are in your forecast for 2016 in this division.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robert, I would say that if we look at the first quarter, there's no question that January and February were pretty rough sledding. The turmoil in the market and general sentiment, I mean, I think caused a lot of people to sort of stop and wait to see wha
componenttext: Robert, I would say that if we look at the first quarter, there's no question that January and February were pretty rough sledding. The turmoil in the market and general sentiment, I mean, I think caused a lot of people to sort of stop and wait to see what's going on. But as we went in through March and I'd say continuing now into April, the market has been pretty good. I mean, we'd always like to see it stronger but the momentum that we felt in the latter part of last year certainly took a pause through January and February, but has returned to a pretty decent market here in March going into April.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up. Frank, obviously, you highlighted the buyback was strong in Q1. Do you expect it to moderate going forward? And would you more be interested in acquisitions perhaps?
componenttext: And then as a follow-up. Frank, obviously, you highlighted the buyback was strong in Q1. Do you expect it to moderate going forward? And would you more be interested in acquisitions perhaps?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Well, we'll, as we said, I mean, we'll continue to take a look at what the acquisition opportunities look like, our cash flow needs and we return excess capital to shareholders, as you say. We -- kind of we did a lot of that in the first quarter. We'll continue to look at kind of the appropriate use of capital as we go through the year, but we're ahead of the game in terms of our, certainly, our plan to at least offset dilution at this point.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you talk a little bit about Bell and what you've seen as far as demand on the 412s? And does the relatively stronger dollar hurt you in those sales? And I guess, I'm wondering with 2 deliveries in the first quarter, are we still on trac
componenttext: Okay. And then can you talk a little bit about Bell and what you've seen as far as demand on the 412s? And does the relatively stronger dollar hurt you in those sales? And I guess, I'm wondering with 2 deliveries in the first quarter, are we still on track for 12 of them?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sam, I think that the commercial market is still challenging, for sure, on the helicopter side and exchange rates, U.S. dollar doesn't help us particularly. But the 412, I would say, our line of sight on the year for the guidance we provided, which was ar
componenttext: Sam, I think that the commercial market is still challenging, for sure, on the helicopter side and exchange rates, U.S. dollar doesn't help us particularly. But the 412, I would say, our line of sight on the year for the guidance we provided, which was around 12, I think, is firming up. So I think we feel pretty good about that and there are certainly opportunities out there as we look into the out-years and there's deals that still need to close, but they're still -- it's a great helicopter. It serves its purpose very well, it's got a great customer base and there are still people looking at expanding, increasing their fleets of 412s. So I'd say we have pretty reasonable line of sight on -- to the 2016 and are working opportunities that are going out into '17, '18 at this point.

componenttext: I guess, on R&D, can you talk about the expectations for R&D for the full year maybe on a segment basis? And then also in terms of headcount, I think you added headcount across 3 of the 4 segments with the exception of Bell and maybe what that additional capacity is for.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Sheila, I would say that the total year R&D is probably going to be pretty consistent with what we guided, which we only do for the total company level. There's always a little bit of timing in this thing. I mean, clearly with getting ready for the
componenttext: Well, Sheila, I would say that the total year R&D is probably going to be pretty consistent with what we guided, which we only do for the total company level. There's always a little bit of timing in this thing. I mean, clearly with getting ready for the flight test programs and whatnot at Aviation on the Longitude program, we spent a disproportionate amount of that in terms of the run rate getting ready for flight tests. So the other programs are running about as we expected. There's really no change to the guidance. The 525 flight test programs are going very well and are consuming expense at about the pace we expected. V-280 is going very well. We've had some nice significant milestones in the fabrication of that first unit for flight next year. So I think our guidance for the total year remains unchanged, we just had some higher spending here in the first quarter, particularly Aviation getting ready for the Longitude program.

componenttext: The headcount numbers, I don't -- I'm not sure. I don't have the exact numbers in front of me, Sheila. I don't think there's any big material changes. The only place we've had really material changes in headcount, unfortunately, have really been around Bell and that's mostly been dialing back some of the production run rates in Mirabel on the commercial helicopter front. Other than that, it's been, I think, relatively stable in most of the businesses.

componenttext: Yes, Aviation has been fairly flattish on a year-over-year basis, Sheila. As I said, I think part of it is just we had to be a little bit patient here as we went through a couple pretty tough months and hang in there. But the demand environment, which is really kind of in the end what drives it, picked up in March and felt pretty good.
