headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'd start by saying that it's early in that process. So we've already started to work with the customer on providing information. Right now, Jason, the challenge is it's a pretty broad range of volumes depending on -- as they're working on their
componenttext: Sure. So I'd start by saying that it's early in that process. So we've already started to work with the customer on providing information. Right now, Jason, the challenge is it's a pretty broad range of volumes depending on -- as they're working on their budget for those out-years and obviously it's -- there's a mix of what they want to do with the Program of Record. For the Marine Corps, you've seen some articles out there about the Air Force having an interest in some additional CVs. There's the Navy COG program and how that starts to drive demand as well as creating some optionality around FMS opportunities. So right now, when we're providing numbers, it's across a pretty broad range of units. So it's -- at this point, I'd be reluctant to put a number out there. Seriously, I don't think there's any we'd want to guide to yet to give you guys an idea because it's just -- the range of opportunity is just too high in terms of where that number falls out. It could -- it's just a -- they're running the numbers, running the financials and asking us for a lot of input on a pretty broad range of possible numbers of units.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But let me ask it a different way, without FMS, does the top end of that range allow you to hold current production rates?
componenttext: Okay. But let me ask it a different way, without FMS, does the top end of that range allow you to hold current production rates?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it's likely that we would hold current production rates. It's going to be -- it'll be south of that. I really don't see a potential outcome that would be the current production rate. So we are planning for another decrement down when we
componenttext: No, I don't think it's likely that we would hold current production rates. It's going to be -- it'll be south of that. I really don't see a potential outcome that would be the current production rate. So we are planning for another decrement down when we get out there into that '19, '20 time frame, but it's -- we just don't know how big that decrement's going to be right now. When you look at Navy COG, that's 40-some units, there are still 20-some in the Marine Corps Program of Record. There could be a couple CVs. There could be some optionality built in for FMS. But I do not think that the expectation should be it would run at the current run rates.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then the follow-on, the LOI that you got on the 505 and the 525, can you just remind us when those convert into actual contracts? When will you start telling us or have a better idea of what your ramp is going to look like on deliver
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then the follow-on, the LOI that you got on the 505 and the 525, can you just remind us when those convert into actual contracts? When will you start telling us or have a better idea of what your ramp is going to look like on deliveries for both of those aircraft? So just kind of the timing of the LOIs converting to contracts.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we'll start to can see conversion on 505 contracts and probably starting here pretty soon. Those aircraft we'll be looking at the initial deliveries, likely, in the fourth quarter. So there's already conversations going on with customers tha
componenttext: Well, I think we'll start to can see conversion on 505 contracts and probably starting here pretty soon. Those aircraft we'll be looking at the initial deliveries, likely, in the fourth quarter. So there's already conversations going on with customers that are -- will convert those to actual contracts. I would say on the 525, you won't likely see that until sometime as you get closer to certification in midsummer or so last year -- next year rather with a -- just because our certification expectations are kind of late summer, early fall before we would start firming those up for deliveries by the end of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, geographically, is North America kind of still the only game in town? I think you had been running, I don't know, 75% of your Citation deliveries were North America and I think a similar amount at Bell commercial. I'm just wondering if that's the s
componenttext: Scott, geographically, is North America kind of still the only game in town? I think you had been running, I don't know, 75% of your Citation deliveries were North America and I think a similar amount at Bell commercial. I'm just wondering if that's the status. And if there's any change that you detect in the North America market versus 3 or 4 months ago.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, on the Aviation side, it's still more or less U.S. driven. I think jets this quarter were probably about 80% U.S. deliveries, about 20% international deliveries. If you look at our turboprop product, between the King Air and the Caravans,
componenttext: Well, certainly, on the Aviation side, it's still more or less U.S. driven. I think jets this quarter were probably about 80% U.S. deliveries, about 20% international deliveries. If you look at our turboprop product, between the King Air and the Caravans, those are more like 50-50 U.S. and international and that's more typical for those products. And I think the turboprops are doing well. The Caravans, particularly in China, are strong. So we -- but I would say, however, here that we're starting to see some momentum pick up a little bit in Europe. So I think you'll start to see some increased jet deliveries over there and turboprop, again, staying fairly balanced between U.S. and international as we go through the balance of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. Got you. And then the last one, I just wonder what your expectation was on this Air Force nuclear helicopter program. I think basically you guys are the incumbent. It's, I think, a few billion dollars probably and there's been a lot of chatter
componenttext: Okay, okay. Got you. And then the last one, I just wonder what your expectation was on this Air Force nuclear helicopter program. I think basically you guys are the incumbent. It's, I think, a few billion dollars probably and there's been a lot of chatter that they would sole source it to a competitor. I'm just wondering what your expectation is there and if you had any thoughts.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, we're probably seeing and hearing the same things that you're hearing. It sounds like -- I mean, we are the incumbent, but those helicopters have been there. Those are Hueys from a long time ago. And at least, the requirements that we've seen
componenttext: Well, look, we're probably seeing and hearing the same things that you're hearing. It sounds like -- I mean, we are the incumbent, but those helicopters have been there. Those are Hueys from a long time ago. And at least, the requirements that we've seen out there we think they're looking for a larger and a different helicopter. So we're seeing and hearing the same chatter. It sounds like they're looking at going sole source to another product at this point.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just Scott, quickly, wondered if you could give us some color on what you saw in service revenues across Aviation and Bell in the quarter?
componenttext: Just Scott, quickly, wondered if you could give us some color on what you saw in service revenues across Aviation and Bell in the quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the Aviation side, it was pretty consistent with where we've been. I think it was around 35% of revenue. On the helicopter side, I'm sorry I don't have exact percentage here in front of me, but it was down a bit year-over-year. And again, I think th
componenttext: So on the Aviation side, it was pretty consistent with where we've been. I think it was around 35% of revenue. On the helicopter side, I'm sorry I don't have exact percentage here in front of me, but it was down a bit year-over-year. And again, I think that's just reflecting that we continue to see lower utilization, particularly in the oil and gas segment in the marketplace.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when do you think you'll reach a bottom on that? I mean, clearly there's some destocking in that end market. So when do you start to lap some of the easier compares there?
componenttext: Yes, when do you think you'll reach a bottom on that? I mean, clearly there's some destocking in that end market. So when do you start to lap some of the easier compares there?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hard to say, Carter. I mean, I would be just making a total guess. But I think a lot of it's going to have to do with, obviously, what happens with oil prices and when the guys start utilizing the assets. I can tell you down in the Gulf where we have an a
componenttext: Hard to say, Carter. I mean, I would be just making a total guess. But I think a lot of it's going to have to do with, obviously, what happens with oil prices and when the guys start utilizing the assets. I can tell you down in the Gulf where we have an awful lot of 412s that are operating with the oil prices being down, things have been slower. Frankly, some customers have been slow to pay some of the operators that we work, and so as a result, those guys will -- they'll put aircraft on the ground or they'll back off in general. But it's got to go through its cycle. So I'm not, probably, the right guy to opine on the oil prices and what that recovery looks like, but I think it'll tie more to that going forward.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on Systems, just a quick follow-up. Any more color you can give us on the Unmanned revenue in the quarter? Did that have a negative mix impact for the margins?
componenttext: Great. And then on Systems, just a quick follow-up. Any more color you can give us on the Unmanned revenue in the quarter? Did that have a negative mix impact for the margins?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think the Unmanned is probably in line with, typically, what we expect for margins in that business. We've seen fairly high utilization on our fee-for-service programs, which are going well. I know the aircraft are performing well and executing the
componenttext: No, I think the Unmanned is probably in line with, typically, what we expect for margins in that business. We've seen fairly high utilization on our fee-for-service programs, which are going well. I know the aircraft are performing well and executing the contracts that we have. We've continued to deliver the upgrades for the Shadow V2 program and those are kind of flowing through exactly as we expected, and we've got some decent business development work going on for some international sales and things like that. So I think everything at the -- in the Unmanned world is good. The margins, obviously, we were this quarter fairly light at Marine & Land Systems because we'll largely generate a lot of the revenue here in the third and fourth quarter associated with the Canadian TAPV program. Obviously, getting that milestones and the test complete was a big deal for us. So I think each of the units are doing well and are where we expected, but Unmanned is good business and margins consistent with our expectations.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to start with the first question on Aviation margins because, I guess, in Q1, you were talking earlier about how the margins were a couple of hundred points short of the full year margin target in Aviation based off a mix of leverage, volume l
componenttext: Just wanted to start with the first question on Aviation margins because, I guess, in Q1, you were talking earlier about how the margins were a couple of hundred points short of the full year margin target in Aviation based off a mix of leverage, volume leverage and also R&D. As we think about the rest of the year and how you make up that 200 bps, should we think about that as fairly evenly split between R&D tailing off and leverage recovering? Or is there some sort of weighting between the 2?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julian, I mean, I think it's -- I wouldn't read a whole lot into the Q1 numbers, right? I mean, the revenue was up $40 million. So leverage on $40 million, a couple of million of -- a few million of R&D, a couple million of this or that, it just make such
componenttext: Julian, I mean, I think it's -- I wouldn't read a whole lot into the Q1 numbers, right? I mean, the revenue was up $40 million. So leverage on $40 million, a couple of million of -- a few million of R&D, a couple million of this or that, it just make such a huge swing. So I don't think there's anything that I would look at the first quarter granted, yes, just in terms of specifically R&D, the R&D spending is probably somewhat disproportionate in terms of the overall impact on margins here in Q1 than it would be in the latter quarters. But I mean, I really don't think there's anything fundamental we look at in the leverage issue in the first quarter as being indicative of what's going to happen in Q2, 3 and 4. So our guidance that we provided you guys around sort of that window of overall operating margin percent, I think we're on track to do that in the revenue side. So the leverage is going to be pretty consistent, I think, with what we told you. And again, the number in Q1 is such a small incremental on the revenue that I don't think you can read a whole lot into it in terms of leverage.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very clear. And then my follow-up would be around the Manufacturing cash outflow. That was about $100 million higher year-on-year. The vast majority of that due to working capital stepping up. But at the same time, your buyback spend in Q1 suggests you're
componenttext: Very clear. And then my follow-up would be around the Manufacturing cash outflow. That was about $100 million higher year-on-year. The vast majority of that due to working capital stepping up. But at the same time, your buyback spend in Q1 suggests you're very confident of that cash flow swinging around. So maybe just give a little bit of background as to where that big working capital build really came. And do you think we should see the Manufacturing cash flow swing positive in the second quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, first of all, on an absolute basis, you guys know we generally consume cash in the first quarter. We tend to have inventory build associated with products that do sell off: good, better, indifferent. Aviation and Bell tend to have more higher
componenttext: So I think, first of all, on an absolute basis, you guys know we generally consume cash in the first quarter. We tend to have inventory build associated with products that do sell off: good, better, indifferent. Aviation and Bell tend to have more higher sales in the latter part of the year. So on an absolute basis, there's -- I don't think there's anything terribly surprising. In terms of the year-over-year comparative, we do have a situation with respect to customer deposits primarily -- almost exclusively, frankly, on the military side of Bell whereas as a result of performance-based payments over the last couple of years, we had a favorable position in terms of working capital, which will unwind through the course of this year and that's a good part of what you see here in the first quarter. But those numbers are absolutely consistent with what we guided you guys in the overall cash number. So we'll see that working capital impact through the course of the year. But again, completely planned and consistent with expectation and so we have no change in our confidence in terms of our overall cash flow for the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott, I wanted to pursue a little bit more this R&D. So you made a comment first thing that the R&D spend was more than offset what was maybe $5 million step-up in Beech. Could you quantify how much more it offset? And then how much lower the R&D mi
componenttext: Yes, Scott, I wanted to pursue a little bit more this R&D. So you made a comment first thing that the R&D spend was more than offset what was maybe $5 million step-up in Beech. Could you quantify how much more it offset? And then how much lower the R&D might be in the subsequent quarters?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the dynamics we have in the quarter, George. For sure, we have the last quarter, really, of any of the step-up impact on accounting in Aviation. That was about a $5 million number. And all I'm saying is that our spending on the R&D side on a year-over-
componenttext: So the dynamics we have in the quarter, George. For sure, we have the last quarter, really, of any of the step-up impact on accounting in Aviation. That was about a $5 million number. And all I'm saying is that our spending on the R&D side on a year-over-year basis, to be comparative, was a number that was quite a bit bigger than that. So it was -- if you take those 2 significant pieces, it was dilutive to our margin rate or overall leverage, if you will, on a year-over-year basis. But again, in neither case are these huge numbers. It's just when you're looking at a $40 million increase in revenue, the difference between $4 million better in margin and $8 million better in margin, 10% leverage, 20% leverage, you're talking about a couple million dollars. So it's -- none of these numbers are big numbers and so...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I recognize that. I'm just wondering so is R&D of $10 million versus, say, the step-up being $5 million in the quarter? I'm just trying to roughly calculate what that impact might be and then how much higher R&D was this quarter than what you might e
componenttext: Yes, I recognize that. I'm just wondering so is R&D of $10 million versus, say, the step-up being $5 million in the quarter? I'm just trying to roughly calculate what that impact might be and then how much higher R&D was this quarter than what you might expect it to be in subsequent quarters?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, it was on the order of about $10 million. I mean, I think for modeling purposes, that's about the right number to put in there. Again, it's not a particular big number. And we don't expect it to change our overall company R&D over the whole course
componenttext: George, it was on the order of about $10 million. I mean, I think for modeling purposes, that's about the right number to put in there. Again, it's not a particular big number. And we don't expect it to change our overall company R&D over the whole course of the year. It's a relatively small number, but it's on that magnitude.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So does R&D go down a little bit then in the subsequent quarters?
componenttext: Okay. So does R&D go down a little bit then in the subsequent quarters?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but again not by a very big number because it was only up by a very small number.
componenttext: Yes, but again not by a very big number because it was only up by a very small number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, understood. And Frank, just to qualify. The tax rate was more like 30% this quarter versus the 31% guide. Are we going to still see 31%? Or is 30% a better number?
componenttext: Right, understood. And Frank, just to qualify. The tax rate was more like 30% this quarter versus the 31% guide. Are we going to still see 31%? Or is 30% a better number?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd keep using 31%. It obviously depends on, at the end of the day, kind of what our international versus domestic mix is, and we won't know that until we move further through the year, but I'd continue to use 31%.
componenttext: I'd keep using 31%. It obviously depends on, at the end of the day, kind of what our international versus domestic mix is, and we won't know that until we move further through the year, but I'd continue to use 31%.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then one last one, Scott. Orders this year versus last year's first quarter were up like $90 million or so or almost 10%. Was that still primarily domestic? Or did you see more of the orders from international at all this quarter?
componenttext: Okay. Then one last one, Scott. Orders this year versus last year's first quarter were up like $90 million or so or almost 10%. Was that still primarily domestic? Or did you see more of the orders from international at all this quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say on the jet side, most of the orders in the quarter were U.S. I think we'll see a more international mix here, certainly, as we're proceeding through April into Q2.
componenttext: I would say on the jet side, most of the orders in the quarter were U.S. I think we'll see a more international mix here, certainly, as we're proceeding through April into Q2.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Seifman from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Seifman from JPMorgan.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll really beg for your indulgence here to ask one more question about Aviation margins, which is just that if you look at what's implied for the remainder of the year, it looks fairly flat with what you did in Q2, Q3 and Q4 overall last year excluding t
componenttext: I'll really beg for your indulgence here to ask one more question about Aviation margins, which is just that if you look at what's implied for the remainder of the year, it looks fairly flat with what you did in Q2, Q3 and Q4 overall last year excluding the inventory step-up. And so to have flat margins year-on-year in Aviation for the rest of the year when it would seem like more Latitude deliveries to NetJets would be a headwind, what's sort of the opposing factor that allows you to keep those margins flat?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, in general, performance in the business is, I mean, the guys are executing well and we do have some volume that's increased on a year-over-year basis and we still have good gross margin product, so that does create some leverage to help off
componenttext: Well, I think, in general, performance in the business is, I mean, the guys are executing well and we do have some volume that's increased on a year-over-year basis and we still have good gross margin product, so that does create some leverage to help offset some of what might be a bit of a negative mix on a year-over-year comparative basis in terms of the mix of aircraft. So...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just as a follow-up also in terms of the pickup in activity that you've seen in March and April in terms of where it is across -- would you say it's across platforms? Or is there any place where it's concentrated? I mean, one of the
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just as a follow-up also in terms of the pickup in activity that you've seen in March and April in terms of where it is across -- would you say it's across platforms? Or is there any place where it's concentrated? I mean, one of the reasons I ask, I know we're talking about small number so it's hard to tell, but if you just look at the high end, the Sovereign and X deliveries were fairly low in Q1. I know Q1 is light, but is that a place where you're seeing kind of incremental weakness in demand relative to the other platforms?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably some of what you're seeing is, with the Latitude in there, we do see some aircraft that maybe a year or 2 years ago could have been a Sovereign are now going to be a Latitude. So the aircraft in terms of their range and performance are diffe
componenttext: It's probably some of what you're seeing is, with the Latitude in there, we do see some aircraft that maybe a year or 2 years ago could have been a Sovereign are now going to be a Latitude. So the aircraft in terms of their range and performance are different. And for a lot of our customers, the Sovereign is still the right answer and that's why we still see reasonable sales of Sovereign. But for sure, when we look at the total number of aircraft in that Sovereign space, some of those are now becoming Latitudes. So someone's in the middle of the country or they're in Europe or they're in some place where that 2,800 nautical miles will get you there, they're tending to err on the side of a Latitude versus a Sovereign. So that explains kind of where I think we are on Sovereigns. And on 10s, as we said, that's a fairly unique product. It's been a very popular product over time, but it's a relatively small number of units each year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It sounded like in the fourth quarter, the King Airs maybe were a little bit disappointing on the international side. But I guess, Scott, some of your commentary there sounded like you had seen a pickup as expected and still expect year-on-year growth in
componenttext: It sounded like in the fourth quarter, the King Airs maybe were a little bit disappointing on the international side. But I guess, Scott, some of your commentary there sounded like you had seen a pickup as expected and still expect year-on-year growth in King Airs?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think we've seen the King Air market being pretty solid in most applications. I'd say it's been a little lighter on special missions than it has in the past, and that's a little bit of what we saw in the fourth quarter and the first quarter
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think we've seen the King Air market being pretty solid in most applications. I'd say it's been a little lighter on special missions than it has in the past, and that's a little bit of what we saw in the fourth quarter and the first quarter this year. But remember, we also had the conversion going from the old cockpit to the new model that came out very late last year and so getting that into production and getting the last of the older models sold and now making that conversion to the new model also had some impact on volume. But frankly, with the new model out there selling well, we just got certification in Europe, which is through EASA is a big deal for us. So I think we feel pretty good about the King Air market and where it's going.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a clarification on the margins. The pension tailwind year-over-year, I expect it would have been $10 million to $15 million across the segments and maybe Aviation got $5 million of that. Is that the right way to think about the tailwin
componenttext: Okay. And then just a clarification on the margins. The pension tailwind year-over-year, I expect it would have been $10 million to $15 million across the segments and maybe Aviation got $5 million of that. Is that the right way to think about the tailwind from pension?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's probably somewhere around that $10 million number, but most of that is actually taken at corporate. Just the way we -- well, I mean, we spread it out. It's -- but it wouldn't be $5 million at Aviation. It's going to be a smaller number than that.
componenttext: No, it's probably somewhere around that $10 million number, but most of that is actually taken at corporate. Just the way we -- well, I mean, we spread it out. It's -- but it wouldn't be $5 million at Aviation. It's going to be a smaller number than that. So I wouldn't -- I don't have the exact number in front of me, but it's a relatively small number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a benefit, but it's spread around the organization.
componenttext: There's a benefit, but it's spread around the organization.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your neck next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research.
componenttext: Your neck next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, just a couple of questions on cash flow. Frank, thanks for the color on the -- or maybe it was Scott, but on the military dynamics. But just trying to think about the quarter here. Accounts receivable and inventories were both, actually, up. I would
componenttext: Hey, just a couple of questions on cash flow. Frank, thanks for the color on the -- or maybe it was Scott, but on the military dynamics. But just trying to think about the quarter here. Accounts receivable and inventories were both, actually, up. I would guess that Bell issue was, actually, in some accrued account somewhere? Can you speak to what was going on in the accounts receivable and inventories in the quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the issue I talked about on Bell is in the working capital line, Jeff. So that's where it's reflected.
componenttext: Well, the issue I talked about on Bell is in the working capital line, Jeff. So that's where it's reflected.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm just looking at the absolute growth in receivables and inventories in the quarter, so...
componenttext: Yes, I'm just looking at the absolute growth in receivables and inventories in the quarter, so...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, just to be clear, the comment on the customer deposits was a first quarter last year to first quarter this year versus a end of year last year to this quarter. So...
componenttext: Jeff, just to be clear, the comment on the customer deposits was a first quarter last year to first quarter this year versus a end of year last year to this quarter. So...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. Fine. And then just shifting to pension, do you foresee continued contributions at this level? Or is there a potential that those need to kind of move up in the out-years?
componenttext: Okay, all right. Fine. And then just shifting to pension, do you foresee continued contributions at this level? Or is there a potential that those need to kind of move up in the out-years?

But the only thing I'd say around the NetJet thing is that we really don't put stuff in -- from NetJets into that backlog until we have agreed delivery dates and tail numbers and that stuff. So we will incrementally add NetJets to that backlog only when we and NetJet says, hey, look, this is when I want delivery. This is the date, this is the tail and so there's only a small percentage of that overall order is in backlog today and that will grow the number we put in there fairly linearly as they start taking deliveries and start committing to the next aircraft delivery date.

componenttextpreview: Just maybe a couple of quick details. You guys announced that you won a 777X flight simulator at Mechtronix, so congratulations on that. How big is that, potentially? I mean, how do we think about that for the Mechtronix business?
componenttext: Just maybe a couple of quick details. You guys announced that you won a 777X flight simulator at Mechtronix, so congratulations on that. How big is that, potentially? I mean, how do we think about that for the Mechtronix business?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a good question. So the -- and I have to be careful because I don't know exactly all that was disclosed with our customer. But certainly, the scope of that contract is to provide the simulators for their use as well as their training centers, a
componenttext: Well, it's a good question. So the -- and I have to be careful because I don't know exactly all that was disclosed with our customer. But certainly, the scope of that contract is to provide the simulators for their use as well as their training centers, and beyond that, obviously, a lot of Boeing's 777 customers will buy their own simulators for doing their own pilot training. So I think that the scope of the contract that we have is for the sales directly to Boeing. But obviously, from our perspective, while that's a great contract and we're thrilled to have it, it also gives us, we think, the position in the marketplace that we should win our fair share of end customers from Boeing who buy their own simulator. So it's the contract value specifically associated with Boeing plus future opportunities that are still to be determined.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I was just -- maybe just for clarity, but this is a bigger -- Mechtronix, historically, wasn't as big a player, right, in the large commercial, right? This is a nice new segment of business for them? Correct or no?
componenttext: And I was just -- maybe just for clarity, but this is a bigger -- Mechtronix, historically, wasn't as big a player, right, in the large commercial, right? This is a nice new segment of business for them? Correct or no?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it is. So true -- when we bought Mechtronix, obviously part of the rationale for the acquisition was we felt they had some terrific technology, very capable team and a great product. But they were a very small company and they had, had some challenges
componenttext: No, it is. So true -- when we bought Mechtronix, obviously part of the rationale for the acquisition was we felt they had some terrific technology, very capable team and a great product. But they were a very small company and they had, had some challenges and got a little over-leveraged at one point and ran into some financial trouble. And that hurts you in that market because when you look at big customers, whether it's a Boeing or a lot of the major airlines in the world, these assets are like an aircraft. They're very long-lived, right, so companies want to know when you're buying a fairly high-dollar capital item that you're going to be able to be around and provide the service and support and upgrades and such over time. And I do think that one of the things that hampered them in the marketplace was, as a result of their financial struggles, they had some uncertainty around them. So it wasn't a technical or product problem, it was a business liability issue and obviously when we acquired them and sort of put our balance sheet and reputation behind it that kind of got rid of that sort of barrier with a lot of customers. So the team up there won the 737 MAX a couple of years ago. I think that they've executed very, very well on that. The Boeing folks, obviously, have been very happy with how the team has performed on the 737 MAX, and that gave them confidence to then also make us their partner on the 777X. So if you execute well and perform well, it can sort of snowball in the right direction. But for sure, part of the underlying thesis of the deal was that we thought we had a company that a lot of great technology, great product, great capability, but it needed to have a little more certainty and strength from a financial standpoint and I think we've provided that.

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, cool. And then one more, my favorite airplane, the Scorpion. Where do we stand on international interest, potential order, that kind of thing for it?
componenttext: Yes, cool. And then one more, my favorite airplane, the Scorpion. Where do we stand on international interest, potential order, that kind of thing for it?

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think there's a fair bit of international interest. We still have a lot of customers that are talking to us. We've had the aircraft all over the country. We've had a lot of customers flying it. Really, the next major milestone for us -- well, there's
componenttext: So I think there's a fair bit of international interest. We still have a lot of customers that are talking to us. We've had the aircraft all over the country. We've had a lot of customers flying it. Really, the next major milestone for us -- well, there's really 2. One is that we've had a couple relatively minor things that we wanted to change in the production configuration of the aircraft. We've completed that engineering work, and we're in the manufacturing process right now, building that, let's call it, the conforming production version of the aircraft. Customers obviously want to fly that and see that before they would place an order. And the other issue was, for us, was always around airworthiness and how do you get a certification. And as I think you've heard, publicly, there is now an Air Force program. They're standing up a program office where they will conduct airworthiness certifications of aircraft that were not funded in development by the Air Force. And so we've already submitted our application in that process. So that's sort of a work in progress as well. So we think this all kind of dovetails with getting the first conforming article built and ready to fly here in probably early to midsummer, and the air airworthiness program will get underway and the Air Force ultimately will provide the airworthiness certification of that aircraft, which is a big deal to all of our prospective customers so...

headline: Textron Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the principal deals in the quarter were Able Engineering, which we announced. This is a repair and overhaul business that does sort of a mix of both Bell product as well as some fixed-wing products. So we acquired that early in the quarter. That's n
componenttext: Well, the principal deals in the quarter were Able Engineering, which we announced. This is a repair and overhaul business that does sort of a mix of both Bell product as well as some fixed-wing products. So we acquired that early in the quarter. That's now integrated into our Aviation services network, but it's providing both work -- or actually right now, probably more Bell than anything else. So they had a company who had great relations with a number of our customers that looked at a mix of how they maintain their fleet with a combination of both new parts as well as some parts that can be overhauled. We've entered that business through that acquisition with Able and, frankly, that's going very well so far. We also acquired in the first quarter a company called ATAC. This is a company that provides tactical training and, principally, under contract to the U.S. Navy. So supporting our current customers, we fly missions that allow the Navy and the Marine Corps to not utilize their own assets to provide things like tactical area training, controller training as well as adversary forces for schools like Top Gun as well as a lot of other aggressor forces to emulate enemy aircraft in exercises conducted by the U.S. Navy and the Marine Corps. It also has history doing some work for the Air Force. There's a number of opportunities out there that we think we continue to grow in that space and that's a nice augmentation for us in terms of how we address customers both in the U.S. as well as internationally to provide training capability. There was also a very small acquisition that we did in the quarter, a lot of the service and support that was done on the TRU Simulation + Training platforms, in particular the actual simulator maintenance, which is an important part of the business. That had been, effectively, outsourced for quite some time to a small company that was doing that. We think providing the right level of service and support is critical to those products over time and didn't feel comfortable that we should be dependent on a third party. So we acquired -- and it was basically acquiring the people so that they're now part of the company as opposed to having a third party conducting that service and support.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Doug Wil
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Doug Wilburne, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stacey, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our
componenttext:
Thanks, Stacey, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our SEC filings and also in today's press release.
On the call today we have Scott Donnelly, Textron's Chairman and CEO; and Frank Connor, our Chief Financial Officer.
Our earnings call presentation can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website. Textron's revenue in the quarter were $3.5 billion, up $264 million from last year's second quarter. Income from continuing operations was $0.66 per share, up 10% from $0.60 reported in last year's second quarter. Manufacturing cash flow, before pension contributions, was a $26 million use of cash compared to a positive $106 million cash blow in last year's second quarter.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. Before I discuss our results, I would like to comment on the 525 accident which occurred on July 6, during developmental test flight and tragically claim the lives of 2 Bell pilots. Both pilots were highly regard
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. Before I discuss our results, I would like to comment on the 525 accident which occurred on July 6, during developmental test flight and tragically claim the lives of 2 Bell pilots. Both pilots were highly regarded individuals, well-respected members of Bell team and very experienced test pilots. We will miss them readily and keep them and their families in our thoughts and prayers.
We're currently providing assistance to the NTSB is supporting in the investigation to understand exactly what caused the accident. We suspended flight test activities on the program until we determine the cause of the accident. In the meantime, we're proceeding all of non-flight-related certification program activities. At this time, we do not have an estimate as to when fight testing might resume or the length of the delay and certification of our first deliveries. We do remained committed in the 525 program, and we'll work to ensure the aircraft will be a safe, reliable and high-performance helicopter.
Moving to the quarter, revenues were up 8.1%, reflecting our ongoing investments in both new products and acquisitions. Segment revenue was up in systems, industrial and aviation, while down in Bell consistent with our expectations.
At Bell, we delivered 6 V-22s flat with last year's second quarter, 9 H-1s, up from 6 units last year, and 24 commercial helicopters down from 39 a year ago. On the commercial side, our new 505 Jet Rangerx continues to generate strong interest in the marketplace and certification activities are running on track to support initial deliveries at the end of this year.
On the customer service front, during the quarter, we opened a new paint and delivery center in Prague to provide full aircraft completion and delivery capabilities to customers in the region.
Moving to the military side of the business. During the second quarter, we received an order for an additional V-22 under the current multiyear contract for delivery to U.S. Air Force. And earlier this week, we also received an order for 4 additional V-22s for delivery to Japan, and we continued to work with the DoD to identify sufficient quantities, both domestically and internationally to support a third multiyear contract.
We also continued to make progress on assembling our first V-28 aircraft as we reached the important milestone of meeting the wing and the cells to the aircraft fuselage in late April, bringing us one step closer to our scheduled first flight next year. 
We displayed our full scale markup at Farnborough last week and had significant interests from a large number of international customers.
Moving to systems, revenues were up significantly from the first quarter and last year, reflecting international weapons deliveries and higher unmanned aircraft volumes.
On the TAPV program at TMLS, we're making final preparations with our Canadian customer to begin deliveries next month. At our Unmanned Systems business, we received a contract for upgrading an additional 24 shadow systems, which takes us through the end of 2018 for this program. The shadow system also reached a major milestone during the quarter, achieving 1 million hours of in-service operation. 
Finally, at systems, earlier this year, we acquired a small business located in Newport near Virginia called Airborne Tactical Advantage Company, or ATAC. This business provides tactical flight training and air adversary services to the U.S. Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps using a fleet of 27 fighter and tactical aircraft flawn by former U.S. Military fighter pilots.
During the quarter, ATAC was awarded a new contract with the U.S. Navy, worth up to $43 million over the next year. A tax great fit for the company at it has significant synergies with a number of our businesses, and a good growth outlook as we believe the U.S. DoD and foreign militaries will increasingly rely on third parties to provide live airborne threat training services.
Moving to industrial, we saw an 8.3% increase in revenues, reflecting growth at Caltex and specialized vehicles. In specialized vehicles, we began shipping our newest Bad Boy off-road product, the Stampede 900, a recreational 4x4 utility vehicle with unmatched power and unrivaled hauling of storage capacity. We expect the Stampede will contribute to top line growth as this product taps into a new entirely market for this business.
During the quarter, we also acquired Premier engineering manufacturing, producer of the IC vehicles for the aviation industry. Premier will be part of our ground support business, which continues to grow nicely as airlines and airports invest in our infrastructure.
At Caltex, we continued to see good volume growth, reflecting ongoing adoption of our selective catalytic reduction product lines. Moving to Textron Aviation. Revenues were up $72 million, while profits were down $7 million. The increase in revenues reflected delivery of 45 jets in the quarter, compared to 36 last year and 23 King Airs compared to 30 last year. The increase in jets reflected 9 Latitudes, including our first delivery to NetJets. The Latitude continues to do well in the market, which superior performance, range, comfort and operating costs, and customer acceptance has been strong, including sales of fraction by NetJets to their end customers.
As result, NetJets increased their total expected contract requirement from 150 to 200 units, and accelerated their delivery schedule. However, launch pricing for the Latitude has been less than what we've hoped for due to competitive dynamics in this segment of the market, resulting in a lower per plane margin contribution.
Looking forward, while large portion of our capacities is currently allocated in NetJets, we continued to see strong end customer demand, which is translated to improved pricing for second half and next year deliveries.
Overall, we believe were still on track for our Aviation segment profit outlook, although our margins will likely be at the lower end of the range, where slightly higher volumes of expected Latitudes.
Longitude development continues to progress, as we made a wing in the cell for the aircraft fuselage on our first aircraft in May, and power the electrical distribution systems 3 weeks later. We're on track for first flight later this summer, and the aircraft continues to generate significant interest as customers anticipate its entry into service late next year.
On the service front, we opened our newest line maintenance station in Bremen, expanding our support offerings in Germany and throughout Europe. Moving to the Scorpion, the program is gaining momentum, as we began the U.S. DoD accreditation process with this week signing of a cooperative research and development agreement with the United States Air Force. Also production of the conforming aircraft is nearly complete with first flight expected next month.
We believe having the accreditation process underway and the conforming aircraft available for demo flights will help facilitate initial sales of the aircraft.
Last week, at Farnborough, we also announced that we were selected by the team of Kinetic and Telus to supply Scorpion jets for their bid on the U.K.'s air support to defense operational training program should they win the competition.
To sum up, demand in our end markets has been challenging, but we continue to believe that our new products and recent acquisitions will continue to contribute to overall growth in revenue, earnings and cash for the year.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $328 million, up $22 million from the second quarter of 2015, on a $264 million increase in revenues.Let's review how each of the segments contributed, starting with Textron
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $328 million, up $22 million from the second quarter of 2015, on a $264 million increase in revenues.
Let's review how each of the segments contributed, starting with Textron Aviation. At Textron Aviation, revenues were up $72 million from this period last year, primarily due to volume and mix. Segment profit was $81 million, down from $88 million a year ago, primarily reflecting an unfavorable impact from the mix of products sold in the period. Backlog in the segment ended the quarter at $1.1 billion, $122 million higher than at the end of last -- at the end of the first quarter.
Moving to Bell. Revenues were down $46 million, primarily due to volume and mix. Segment profit decreased to $20 million from the second quarter of 2015 reflecting the lower volume and mix. At Textron Systems, revenues were up $165 million, primarily due to higher volumes in our weapons and sensors and unmanned product lines. Segment profit was up $39 million, reflecting the higher volumes and mix. 
Industrial revenues increased $77 million due to higher overall volumes and the impact of acquisitions. Segment profit increased $13 million, reflecting the higher volumes.
Finance segment revenues decreased $4 million, and profit decreased $3 million. Moving below the segment line, corporate expenses were $31 million compared to $33 million last year. Interest expense was $37 million, up $5 million from last year.
On the tax front, the Internal Revenue Service approved a settlement on July 11 of our 1998 to 2008 tax years. As a result, in the third quarter, we expect to record an income tax benefit, including the reversal of accrued interest of approximately $315 million, of which approximately $200 million or $0.74 per share is attributable to continuing operations. The settlement results in immaterial net benefit to claim consolidated cash during the year. 
To wrap up with guidance, we are reiterating our expected full-year EPS from continuing operations of $2.60 to $2.80 per share, exclusive of the tax settlement. We also continue to expect cash flow from continuing operations of manufacturing group before pension contributions of $600 million to $700 million.
That includes our prepared remarks. So Stacy, we can open the line for questions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Carter, I mean it did have incremental impact for sure. It wasn't probably quite significant as it was in the first quarter. I would say, probably most importantly from an R&D standpoint, we -- in the first half, aviation had pretty high levels of s
componenttext: Well, Carter, I mean it did have incremental impact for sure. It wasn't probably quite significant as it was in the first quarter. I would say, probably most importantly from an R&D standpoint, we -- in the first half, aviation had pretty high levels of spending, and that really was largely around getting ready for the Longitude first flights and flight test programs, so we have incurred an awful lot of R&D. So our total year number is still going to be about what we thought it was, but there'll a significant reduction in the second half, just associated with the fact that we're just about complete with the high spending load on the Longitude program.

componenttextpreview: Well, the fact that we already have a lot of aircraft sold, and so we're looking at actuals in terms of the realized pricing that we're seeing in the second half of the year and going into 2017 versus the pricing that we had realized on the aircraft that
componenttext: Well, the fact that we already have a lot of aircraft sold, and so we're looking at actuals in terms of the realized pricing that we're seeing in the second half of the year and going into 2017 versus the pricing that we had realized on the aircraft that already shipped in the first and second quarter. So there's no change in the NetJet pricing, I mean that's a fixed number through the period, but when you look at retail aircraft sales, whole aircraft sales to end customers, what's all in our book is higher in the back half of the year and into '17 and what we experienced in the first half of the year.

componenttext: Well, I think we will have a second half pickup. Look, the end markets in the commercial helicopter business remained very challenging. What's most critical for us, obviously, is around our 412s. I think we still have reasonable line of sight on meeting where we need to be this year on 412s. As I kind of mentioned in the last quarter, we think there's some number of opportunities out there that we're working on, which hopefully will give us some better visibility into the future. But at least in terms of how we think the year will close out at Bell, for 2016, I think it will be consistent with our expectations.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondered if you could just walk us around the world and talk about demands, generally speaking, across your varied segments in North America, Europe and may be over into the Middle East and Asia?
componenttext: Just wondered if you could just walk us around the world and talk about demands, generally speaking, across your varied segments in North America, Europe and may be over into the Middle East and Asia?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at the Aviation, the U.S. remains probably the strongest market. We've seen particular earlier in the year, a little bit of an uptick in Europe, which has been encouraging. Obviously, we saw a fair bit of dislocations here everyw
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at the Aviation, the U.S. remains probably the strongest market. We've seen particular earlier in the year, a little bit of an uptick in Europe, which has been encouraging. Obviously, we saw a fair bit of dislocations here everywhere in the world in the last few weeks of the quarter, with the whole reaction of Brexit, I don't think any of that is actually fundamental at a macro level with Brexit, but just the upsets in the financial markets creates a lot of uncertainty, which kind of froze things up. But I think, other than that, we've seen a bit of a strengthening in Europe. South America is still very difficult. I think there's opportunities that are starting to show in some places like Argentina and that are starting to improve modestly, but Brazil, mostly down there are still very, very challenged. Middle East is there's activity certainly across most of our businesses, but again, it's a challenging environment. The conflict wars are going on down there, have allowed the government fairly distracted and focus on pretty immediate needs as opposed to much in the way of long-term work, but there's certainly are opportunities that are in the works. Southeast Asia, frankly, is probably one of the healthiest on the international markets in terms of opportunity. There's economies are a little more diversified and are doing okay. China continues to be okay for us, it's not the strength of the growth maybe it was in the past, but it was -- it's certainly, generally speaking, solid particularly in the Aviation segment. So Automotive, I think our numbers fairly well matched what you see going on the world. The European market actually has been kind of stronger. North America had general strength, but there's more strength in the larger vehicles and the trucks in the high-end and there are some of the smaller models, just I think reflecting the price of gas. So I don't think that you are seeing anything probably that will surprise you a lot versus just what's going on, in general, in terms of what GDP looks like in these various regions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then Scott you made some comments about conversations with customers on the Longitude, just wondering if you could give us a little bit flavor on how you think pricing is going to shape up in that, given the fact that we had go p
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then Scott you made some comments about conversations with customers on the Longitude, just wondering if you could give us a little bit flavor on how you think pricing is going to shape up in that, given the fact that we had go post move on us a little bit on the Latitude? What kind of customer mix are you expecting out of the gate of the Longitude that we are going to be selling into the fractional advantages is more directly into customers on a one-off basis?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, at this point, we expected to be primarily just end use customers on the Longitude. We've had kind of our normal sort of customers have been into Wichita, pretty extensively looking at the aircraft. As you might recall, we had a full, not j
componenttext: Well, I think, at this point, we expected to be primarily just end use customers on the Longitude. We've had kind of our normal sort of customers have been into Wichita, pretty extensively looking at the aircraft. As you might recall, we had a full, not just a mockup, but a full aircraft that we displayed last year, and we've kept that aircraft at the plant. We've had lots of people coming in to look at it. And with respect to pricing, I think our challenge on Latitude is that our competitor in net space has 2 aircraft, right? One, which is a little bit the smaller aircraft, which is really what we thought we would end up competing with, with the Latitude that was sort of our intention. And then you got us a larger aircraft, and those 2 aircraft have created a pricing problem. And I think our performance and our range were far superior to the smaller aircraft, which is where wanted to be,  but just kind of using the larger aircraft to try to compete with us, and that's really was generated a lot of the pricing problem. When you look at the Longitude, that's kind of the combination now where you have the much larger aircraft. And frankly, performance and range and I think will distinguish just very nicely from where the competition is. And so certainly our expectation is that we have a much better pricing position because we can distance ourselves in terms of the performance and capability of that aircraft, and there's none other aircraft the competitor has sitting on top of that to try to bring down on price to compete with it.

componenttext: Well, Sam, we did an awful lot of buying in the first quarter, so we did back off little bit on the second quarter, but I wouldn't attribute to the share sort of the shelf that's sitting there. We still do have 4.5 million or so available under that, but if we thought if that's the right thing to do, we had these discussions with the board and there'd be no problem going back and extending that authorization. So it's just -- we haven't officially taken that action, because as we still have enough that's available to exercise under the previous authorization that we haven't taken that from a board of action. But I mean, obviously, we have to discussion with the board, we have had preliminary discussions and I wouldn't expect that it would be an issue.

componenttext: Oh no, again, I don't think we want to go again to the specifics on a model by model basis, we haven't done that in quite some time. But look, I think it's not just NetJets, I mean as I think we've been pretty open about the fact Latitude is selling well, and our expectations for the year was that the overall market would be generally fairly flattish from last year in terms of most of the model types and most of the growth will be driven by the big new product introduction, which, in this case, this year is Latitude. And so I think, that expectation is kind of what we're seeing. I know we are seeing good demand on the Latitude, both from the NetJets as well as on the retail side. And other models are selling fine, they're selling consistent with how we expected. Some models are stronger than others. But, in general, the volume on the jet side is what we expected. And the thing that's driving the upside in terms of growth on a year-over-year basis, and then we would continue expect to see that as we rolled into next year is based on Latitude. And so the bulk of that increase in backlog, I would say, is going to be attributed to that, both NetJets and retail sales.

componenttext: Well, first of all, I mean, on total, it is from the numbers, sure I read all the stuff that you guys read, but there's an awful lot of mix down within that, right? And I would say that if you look at our aircraft, and particular on that light midsize, it's been relatively stable and frankly, the market is healthy. So the amount of turn, the number of sales that are going, on has been fine. So when we look at the amount of used aircraft sales that we had, in the quarter versus previous quarter, it's up. We see the number of transactions that are in our space involving our aircraft are seem to be doing fine, and we see relatively stable residual values. So there's different dynamics, obviously, in terms of what sizes of aircraft. And they're different markets, right? I mean the heavy iron market behaves differently than the light jet market. So actually for us, and for our customers, they're looking to sell used aircraft, buy used aircraft, it's been pretty stable, both pricing and volume.

componenttext: I'm probably not quite ready to do '17 yet. But we certainly feel like our view has been generally that markets airfare are fairly flat, but new products matter. componenttext: Well, I think, obviously, it's mixed across the model, the one that we're largely commenting around, where we feel like we've seen some nice positive momentum on the pricing side is specific around Latitude. And that product is pretty well spoken for at this point.

In fact, we had significantly -- a significant uptick in volume in the quarter, and good execution and performance by the team in terms of getting it done and doing it productively.

componenttext: The acquisition didn't play a whole lot into this thing, I mean as you expect an initial year of a deal like that, there's step-up, there's the normal accounting first year, so I would say it's relatively neutral impact on 2016, and we certainly expect it to be a nice accretive contributor in 2017 and on.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with regard to cash flow, you told us in the past to expect the cash flow to be fairly back half weighted, could you -- is there any way to sort of calibrate our expectations for there's a lot of cash coming in, in the second half, to calib
componenttext: Okay. And then with regard to cash flow, you told us in the past to expect the cash flow to be fairly back half weighted, could you -- is there any way to sort of calibrate our expectations for there's a lot of cash coming in, in the second half, to calibrate our expectations for Q3 versus Q4?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure we want to get into quarter-by-quarter, but we certainly still feel confident with the numbers that we provided in terms of the overall year guidance. We talked in the past, we know we have a headwind associated with customer deposits, largel
componenttext: I'm not sure we want to get into quarter-by-quarter, but we certainly still feel confident with the numbers that we provided in terms of the overall year guidance. We talked in the past, we know we have a headwind associated with customer deposits, largely the military payments, that are sort of unwinding through the course of the year, so those have been unwinding as we gone through the first half of the year. And generally speaking, for us, will serve to offset an awful lot of that in Q3 and Q4 as we see working capital reductions and lots of inventory through volume, largely in Aviation and Bell as we go through the balance of the year. And Taffy, of course, remember we don't start deliveries of those units here until August. So that's a fair bit inventory that we've been carrying that we'll see a significant reduction in Q3 and Q4.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we're obviously always seasonally stronger in Q4, if you just look historically, given the volumes that we see in Q4.
componenttext: And we're obviously always seasonally stronger in Q4, if you just look historically, given the volumes that we see in Q4.
