componenttext: And we'll go next to Sheila Kahyaoglu with Jefferies.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on a profitability, in terms of margins going forward, does it remain at about 10% rate if we assume commercial helicopter prices recover for some time?
componenttext: Just on a profitability, in terms of margins going forward, does it remain at about 10% rate if we assume commercial helicopter prices recover for some time?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sheila, that's kind of what we've talked about is probably being a 10% to 11% kind of range. And an awful lot of that will have to do with where we are, as usual on the commercial side on 412s, Again I think we feel pretty good about where we are for
componenttext: Yes, Sheila, that's kind of what we've talked about is probably being a 10% to 11% kind of range. And an awful lot of that will have to do with where we are, as usual on the commercial side on 412s, Again I think we feel pretty good about where we are for 2016, and we'll have a lot more visibility as we get to the end of the year to be able to provide guidance on where we think that will be in 2017. But at least so far, for this year, we're -- I think, we'll finish where we expect to be.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just one on the broader military opportunities, Scott, if you could talk about that a little bit whether it's the V-22 or the Scorpion, both domestically and internationally? And how you think about the programs and opportunities there?
componenttext: Got it. And just one on the broader military opportunities, Scott, if you could talk about that a little bit whether it's the V-22 or the Scorpion, both domestically and internationally? And how you think about the programs and opportunities there?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the V-22, obviously, has made some progress with the Japanese deal. And those orders now are firming up and coming in being exercised, either under the multiyear 2 contract or as some of the potential volume in the multiyear 3 deal. There continued
componenttext: Well, the V-22, obviously, has made some progress with the Japanese deal. And those orders now are firming up and coming in being exercised, either under the multiyear 2 contract or as some of the potential volume in the multiyear 3 deal. There continued to be a number of conversations with international customers that are going on. I certainly still think that there is a potential that was talked about for quite a while, and then sort of moved out, and there's still uncertainty around that, but I think there's still conversations going on, which are, at this point, very much government to government. The same is true with a couple of other countries. And so those are things, however, we all be talked about in the context of a multiyear 3, so it's not something that's going to hit here in the next couple of years. The only ones we'll see really we'll probably be Japan in that near-term. So there's certainly a lot of other discussion and opportunities dialogue going on, some which is -- public which is not around H-1s. The H1 is performing fabulously for the Marine Corps. It's both the utility and the attack versions of that are in the quote process. And for processes, for several potential international applications, so we'll be following that pretty closely. Scorpion is still very much a wildcard, it's a huge milestone for us to have the Air Force sign up to do the accreditation program, that's just happened this past week. We've had, as you know, a number of international customers that have been looking at the aircraft and they've really been 2 issues for them, one is how you going to get this thing certified, so they can provide their certification on top of it. And not unreasonably, customers want to fly production fully conforming aircraft. We have the accreditation path checked off, and in the next month or so, we'll be flying the first production configured aircraft. So our customers are already talking about when they'll be able to come in and get a chance to fly the aircraft. So 2 big milestones, sort of boxes that we needed to check to get done before we can proceed with final sales of the aircraft.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on the Scorpion, do you think international or domestic order is more likely?
componenttext: And just on the Scorpion, do you think international or domestic order is more likely?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, international has always been the focus of the aircraft for sure, and so those are the deals that we've been pursuing and working and staying close to those customers for a while. You know what, I think there is U.S. opportunities at some point. I t
componenttext: Well, international has always been the focus of the aircraft for sure, and so those are the deals that we've been pursuing and working and staying close to those customers for a while. You know what, I think there is U.S. opportunities at some point. I think there's been some papers here written recently. I mean the Air Force sort of facing in the reality in the U.S. that cost matters, and they need more aircraft that guys can fly and build hours. And frankly, a lot of missions that can be executed that don't need to have a very, very high end fighter capability, but those requirements, I think, are still in early formative stages, within the U.S., and so we'll -- I think we'll see how that plays out here over the next year or 2.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the line of Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: And we'll go to the line of Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick program questions. Scott, on the T6, you guys have delivered about 22 year-to-date, I'm wondering if you're thinking you'll hit 40 for the full year, biggest that would make it kind of flat year-over-year. And I was actually thinking it
componenttext: A couple of quick program questions. Scott, on the T6, you guys have delivered about 22 year-to-date, I'm wondering if you're thinking you'll hit 40 for the full year, biggest that would make it kind of flat year-over-year. And I was actually thinking it would kind of trend down, because I think U.S. deliveries are over. So just wondering what your thoughts are on that program going forward?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it will be fairly flat for the year. The U.S. program is winding down, but we've had a couple of international programs that we won, which will flush out or fill out the year. So I think '16 feels fairly solid and we will -- deliveries will b
componenttext: Yes, I think it will be fairly flat for the year. The U.S. program is winding down, but we've had a couple of international programs that we won, which will flush out or fill out the year. So I think '16 feels fairly solid and we will -- deliveries will be exactly where we expected them to be.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last one for me. Sensor fused weapon, I think there were some news in the quarter that the State Department was actually considering blocking a sale to Saudi. I just wondered if you heard the same thing, what your thoughts were? If tha
componenttext: Okay. And then just last one for me. Sensor fused weapon, I think there were some news in the quarter that the State Department was actually considering blocking a sale to Saudi. I just wondered if you heard the same thing, what your thoughts were? If that's real or not? And I know this is a lumpy program, but I think Saudi was one of the meaningful customers, so just raise a question in my mind there.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they're not a current customer, they're a prospective customer for sure. They have been a customer in the past, and so -- but basically, Pete, you're right, there's a lot of issues going on between the State Department, NSC and what's going on over
componenttext: Well, they're not a current customer, they're a prospective customer for sure. They have been a customer in the past, and so -- but basically, Pete, you're right, there's a lot of issues going on between the State Department, NSC and what's going on over the Middle East, and that is certainly, as a minimum, delaying of getting approvals, whether that breaks loose and ultimately is approved or whether it's not, it's still to be determined. But there's certainly an interest on their part. It's been notified to the Congress in the past, it was approved through that notification process, but now going back through and getting the approval through state, it is hung up at this point.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go the line Justin Bergner with Gabelli & Company.And we'll go to Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.
componenttext:
We'll go the line Justin Bergner with Gabelli & Company.
And we'll go to Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, too young a man to retire. So you guys had very nice resulted systems, and that's even without any shipments of TAPV that come here in the second half. On paper, it looks like systems might have some upside, is that a potential?
componenttext: Doug, too young a man to retire. So you guys had very nice resulted systems, and that's even without any shipments of TAPV that come here in the second half. On paper, it looks like systems might have some upside, is that a potential?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know, Cai, it's probably too early to say one way or the other. But look, you know the SFW side, in particular, can be kind of lumpy just because the way those deliveries happened. It was a very strong quarter for that business. TAPV will ce
componenttext: Well, I don't know, Cai, it's probably too early to say one way or the other. But look, you know the SFW side, in particular, can be kind of lumpy just because the way those deliveries happened. It was a very strong quarter for that business. TAPV will certainly kick in here in Q3 and Q4, as we expected that it would, but again, that's all -- it is built into our plan. We did expect that TAPV to be Q3 and Q4. So it was a very good quarter for that team. I think they're going to deliver a very solid year. But right now, my expectation, it will be consistent with what we guided.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, alternatively, when you look at Bell, you had a very strong military shipment in the first half, and that looks like it's going to be weaker in the second half. In commercial, again, was weak in the first half, has to get better in the sec
componenttext: Okay. And then, alternatively, when you look at Bell, you had a very strong military shipment in the first half, and that looks like it's going to be weaker in the second half. In commercial, again, was weak in the first half, has to get better in the second half to kind of get you home. My understanding was that commercial margins were lower than military margins. So is there much risk at Bell that mix that you come in at the low end or a little below it?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean the mix was different, even in the commercial world, model by model, I think that our military margins are solid. And we'll stay that way through the balance of the year. And we're delivering the same V-22s and H-1s that we delivered in the f
componenttext: Well, I mean the mix was different, even in the commercial world, model by model, I think that our military margins are solid. And we'll stay that way through the balance of the year. And we're delivering the same V-22s and H-1s that we delivered in the first half. So I think that business is in good shape, and they'll deliver to our expectations. I do think we'll be lighter on some of the commercial volume and total number than we would have expected at the beginning of the year. But it's largely in a lot of the lighter helicopter, which is on the initial equipment sale, is not as material to the business as others. Now those aircraft, of course, turn into a lot of service opportunities. So I mean, net, the margins in the commercial side are still good because of all the service that those aircraft pull through with them. But to be light, in terms of volume on some of the larger aircraft, will not have a meaningful impact within the year. In the end, it all comes down largely to the larger aircraft, in particular, the 412s. And I think we're on track to do that, and those are more heavily laid into the back half of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then switching to aviation, so you mentioned the better pricing for Latitude in the second half, talk to us a bit about the productivity, just probability improved because presumably you're coming down the learning curve as time goes by, so sh
componenttext: Got it. And then switching to aviation, so you mentioned the better pricing for Latitude in the second half, talk to us a bit about the productivity, just probability improved because presumably you're coming down the learning curve as time goes by, so should we expect the profitability of Latitude to improve going forward?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, no, I think that in general, it will. There's always a little bit of startup cost and variances and whatnot in the early model years. The team has done a nice job on cost, frankly. The aircraft is coming in around the cost where we expected
componenttext: Well, I mean, no, I think that in general, it will. There's always a little bit of startup cost and variances and whatnot in the early model years. The team has done a nice job on cost, frankly. The aircraft is coming in around the cost where we expected to be. There's still some benefit to be had, certainly, and especially since we have, for the first time a long time, a fairly significant volume of aircraft, which are the same configuration, that being NetJets, obviously, which will help. I mean so, obviously, the guys in the factory are focused on that in trying to draw some incremental productivity and efficiency around that. So we'll see some benefit from that. And I think, in part, that will help us with some of our margin rates as we go into the back half of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then could you conjecture, when you look at the Longitude, when in the second half it might deliver? Does it look like it goes very late in the year? Or could really have sort of meaningful impact in terms of next year?
componenttext: Got it. And then could you conjecture, when you look at the Longitude, when in the second half it might deliver? Does it look like it goes very late in the year? Or could really have sort of meaningful impact in terms of next year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean it's largely going to be a fourth quarter issue, Cai. I mean I don't know we really want to guide too much on that yet. We still -- we haven't started the flight test program yet, we still have to go through the certification process with the
componenttext: Well, I mean it's largely going to be a fourth quarter issue, Cai. I mean I don't know we really want to guide too much on that yet. We still -- we haven't started the flight test program yet, we still have to go through the certification process with the FAA. So it's having not yet started flight test, it's probably a little bit early to get a sense of where we are in that process and what the exact schedule will come out to be. But, you know, it's usually -- easily a year flight test program, you're talking about something that will probably be best case, late third quarter, probably into fourth quarter.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's why I asked, when do you expect to fly? Because usually I would expect to take at least a year to kind of get the thing certified. So I mean there would be some risks that it might slip out of 2017?
componenttext: That's why I asked, when do you expect to fly? Because usually I would expect to take at least a year to kind of get the thing certified. So I mean there would be some risks that it might slip out of 2017?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's some flight, there's some risks to that, of course. However, we're thinking we're going to be flying here in the next couple of months. You know, a year flight test program, that kind of puts you at the end of third quarter, beginning of fourth qu
componenttext: There's some flight, there's some risks to that, of course. However, we're thinking we're going to be flying here in the next couple of months. You know, a year flight test program, that kind of puts you at the end of third quarter, beginning of fourth quarter. And you know, as you know, we've been able on other models and programs to get certifications done and that kind of timeframe, and make some deliveries shortly thereafter. So there's still -- there's certainly a reasonable probability that will see fourth quarter sales of Latitude next year. Worst case, there's a few month delay. For sure, it could roll into the beginning of '18. But again, we'll know an awful lot more when we get around the in 2017 guidance, because we'll be months into flight test and have better feeling for where we are.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're go to the line of Justin Bergner with Gabelli & Company.
componenttext: We're go to the line of Justin Bergner with Gabelli & Company.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions. First on this tax impact, would there ultimately be a benefit to Textron from a cash point of view related to this $315 million and $0.74 from continuing operations?
componenttext: Two quick questions. First on this tax impact, would there ultimately be a benefit to Textron from a cash point of view related to this $315 million and $0.74 from continuing operations?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: There will be a little bit of cash inflow associated with it, but it's not be material. As we said in the comments, I think, obviously, the biggest cash impact is that the avoidance of kind of paying what we had accrued on the books here, obviously, so wh
componenttext: There will be a little bit of cash inflow associated with it, but it's not be material. As we said in the comments, I think, obviously, the biggest cash impact is that the avoidance of kind of paying what we had accrued on the books here, obviously, so which we always expected, but had the reserves for over a substantial period of time. But there will be some cash inflow associated with it, but it's not material.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I know the call hasn't focused as much on Bell, but are you seeing a bottoming in the commercial rotorcraft market? Or are you still seeing incremental weakness as you look out into the second half of the year?
componenttext: Okay, great. And I know the call hasn't focused as much on Bell, but are you seeing a bottoming in the commercial rotorcraft market? Or are you still seeing incremental weakness as you look out into the second half of the year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I don't know, it's very hard to say. I mean, I certainly hope it's a bottom. It's pretty tough out there.
componenttext: You know, I don't know, it's very hard to say. I mean, I certainly hope it's a bottom. It's pretty tough out there.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. What sort of are you looking for on the Bell side to get more confident that you reached a bottom on the commercial side?
componenttext: Okay. What sort of are you looking for on the Bell side to get more confident that you reached a bottom on the commercial side?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, not to be [indiscernible] but orders, right? We're talking to a lot of our customers, obviously, and we have a sense of where they are. Oil and gas, obviously, remains very difficult, right? I mean you've got some of these guys ar
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, not to be [indiscernible] but orders, right? We're talking to a lot of our customers, obviously, and we have a sense of where they are. Oil and gas, obviously, remains very difficult, right? I mean you've got some of these guys are in bankruptcy, you got on of their fleet, sitting on the ground, they're just not being utilized. Now the oil and gas cycle is in all likelihood exactly that, a cycle? I mean we've seen a rebounding of the price of oil, but not back to where it probably needs to be for them to feel better and starting to probably impact possibly in some regions of the world where $50 or so is you can attract and be profitable to certain parts of the world where it needs to be significantly higher than that to make them feel like that end customers is going to start getting stronger. And of course, a lot of economies, they're just oil and gas petrodollar based. So their economies will get healthier as that price per barrel rebounds. But we don't really have a great sense, at this point, what that lag is, between [indiscernible] rebounds and pricing and how quickly that will flow-through to having the ability to invest in their fleets, or, in general, those economies where people feel comfortable to start laying out the funding for significant CapEx kind of projects. But, anyway, I wish I had a very clear answer for you. But, we talk to customers everyday, our teams out there are working, we kind of know pretty much every opportunity in the world that's out there, it's just a matter of seeing some of those stuff to convert to orders, and it's been soft. I mean when you see that in the volumes in the quarter, and I'd be misleading if I thought it was going to all of a sudden materially improved to the fact the second half of this year, which is why I would expect unit volumes to be down, sort of from where we would have expected it to be, but not with significant financial impact for the year. Again, in terms of how we look out any further than that, that's something we'll have to work on and factor that into how we guide for 2017, and that will depend a lot on the sort of general outlook of what those conversations are like for customers. And in particular, a number of opportunities out there that are fairly significant, but we will materialize or not between now and the end of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the line of Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: And we'll go to the line of Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get back on to congratulate Doug publicly on his retirement first and foremost. And then secondly, Scott, just to ask you to offer up some perspective on the M&A pipeline at this point in cash deployment going forward?
componenttext: I wanted to get back on to congratulate Doug publicly on his retirement first and foremost. And then secondly, Scott, just to ask you to offer up some perspective on the M&A pipeline at this point in cash deployment going forward?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I'd say on the M&A front, most of what we've done this year have been relatively small add-on transactions, and I think that's something that we continue to look at. There's a number there in the pipeline that are relatively small. We like doing
componenttext: You know, I'd say on the M&A front, most of what we've done this year have been relatively small add-on transactions, and I think that's something that we continue to look at. There's a number there in the pipeline that are relatively small. We like doing those deals. In general, they've been attractive for us. They've played out very well in terms of returns and financials as they built into the business. And so our expectations is that's probably how things will continue to play out through the balance of the year. There's always stuff that we're looking at but, at this point, there's nothing out there that's immateriality that's something I would say something we're looking at or doing. But we have a number of things we're always looking at. And whether one of those could happen in the balance of the year or not is still to be determined. In general, our capital allocation strategy is kind of unchanged. We reserved and kind of targeted a certain amount of our allocation to M&A. But again, it's all totally opportunistic, right? If it's the right kind of deals, and we think it's good, we'll do them, if we don't, then obviously, we don't do them.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: And we'll go to George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones. On the Sovereign, we've seen the deliveries get pretty low, I mean it's really just really getting cannibalized from the Latitude? And kind of what your outlook for the Sovereign?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. On the Sovereign, we've seen the deliveries get pretty low, I mean it's really just really getting cannibalized from the Latitude? And kind of what your outlook for the Sovereign?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there is certainly some cannibalization, George, between the Sovereign+ and the Latitude. The aircraft are similar in some respects. I mean it's really a trade-off between the size of the cabin versus the number of passengers and range. So if you are l
componenttext: So there is certainly some cannibalization, George, between the Sovereign+ and the Latitude. The aircraft are similar in some respects. I mean it's really a trade-off between the size of the cabin versus the number of passengers and range. So if you are looking in your requirement as to do a little bit of a longer whole and you need to pick more taxable and then the Sovereign is a great airplane and that's why we still sell them. We have a number of customers that still looking at acquiring the Sovereign because it's it feels great for that mission and continues to be a great aircraft in that area if you don't quite need the range and you don't need a number of passengers want to go with that larger cabin, then the Latitude is a great choice. I think what you're seeing is that we have a fair number of customers that will give up a few hundred nautical miles and don't need to have the higher passenger count and they'll on the side of the Latitude. So from our perspective, they're both selling. Certainly with the Latitude being new, it is generating a little bit more demand, which is exactly what we expected. And certainly, some of those customers, if you went back 2 years ago, maybe people model Latitude. But it's good having them both in the portfolio. It give us the ability to deal and work with the customer, and say what's your mission and which one fits your mission better, and that's kind of where we are continuing to sell.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the 10, Scott, you're still figuring that that's kind of 6 to 10 a year in terms of the demand there?
componenttext: And on the 10, Scott, you're still figuring that that's kind of 6 to 10 a year in terms of the demand there?

componenttext: Yes, I think the 10, with just the market dynamics out there, George, it's just a relatively thin market. It's a great aircraft, there's -- we still have a lot of customers that love the airplane, so still see some demand. But it's going to be a small number.

componenttext: Okay. And then one quick one for you Frank, Caltex, I don't think they have a huge amount of exposure to the U.K., but with the devaluation of the pound happening towards the end of the quarter, probably didn't have a big impact this quarter, how much an impact you look forward in the third quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Doug Wilburne, Vice
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron Second Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Doug Wilburne, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stacey, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our
componenttext:
Thanks, Stacey, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our SEC filings and also in today's press release. On the call today, we have Scott Donnelly, Textron's Chairman and CEO; and Frank Connor, our Chief Financial Officer.
Our earnings call presentation can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website. Textron's revenues in the quarter were $3.5 billion, up $264 million from last year's second quarter. Income from continuing operations was $0.66 per share, up 10% from $0.60 reported in last year's second quarter. Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions was a $26 million use of cash compared to a positive $106 million cash flow in last year's second quarter.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. Before I discuss our results, I would like to comment on the 525 accident, which occurred on July 6, during developmental test flight and tragically claimed the lives of 2 Bell pilots. Both pilots were highly reg
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. Before I discuss our results, I would like to comment on the 525 accident, which occurred on July 6, during developmental test flight and tragically claimed the lives of 2 Bell pilots. Both pilots were highly regarded individuals, well-respected members of Bell's team and very experienced test pilots. We will miss them greatly, and keep them and their families in our thoughts and prayers.
We're currently providing assistance to the NTSB in supporting investigation to understand exactly what caused the accident. We've suspended flight test activities on the program until we determine the cause of the accident. In the meantime, we're proceeding with all non-flight-related certification and program activities. At this time, we do not have an estimate as to when flight testing might resume or the length of the delay and certification of our first deliveries. We do remain committed in the 525 program, and we'll work to ensure the aircraft will be a safe, reliable and high-performance helicopter.
Moving to the quarter, revenues were up 8.1%, reflecting our ongoing investments in both new products and acquisitions. Segment revenue was up at systems, industrial and aviation, while down at Bell, consistent with our expectations. At Bell, we delivered 6 V-22s, flat with last year's second quarter; 9 H-1s, up from 6 units last year; and 24 commercial helicopters, down from 39 a year ago. On the commercial side, our new 505 Jet Ranger X continues to generate strong interest in the marketplace, and certification activities are running on track to support initial deliveries at the end of this year. On the customer service front, during the quarter, we opened a new paint and delivery center in Prague to provide full aircraft completion and delivery capabilities to the customer in the region.
Moving to the military side of the business. During the second quarter, we received an order for an additional V-22 under the current multiyear contract for delivery to the U.S. Air Force, and earlier this week, we also received an order for 4 additional V-22s for delivery to Japan, and we continued to work with the DoD to identify sufficient quantities, both domestically and internationally to support a third multiyear contract.  We also continued to make progress on assembling our first V-28 aircraft, as we reach the important milestone of mating the wing in the cells to the aircraft fuselage in late April, bringing us one step closer to our scheduled first flight next year. We displayed our full scale markup at Farnborough last week, and had significant interest from a large number of international customers.
Moving to systems. Revenues were up significantly from the first quarter and last year, reflecting international weapons deliveries and higher unmanned aircraft volumes. On the TAPV program at TMLS, we're making final preparations with our Canadian customer to begin deliveries next month. At our Unmanned Systems business, we received a contract for upgrading an additional 24 shadow systems, which takes us through the end of 2018 for this program. The shadow system also reached a major milestone during the quarter, achieving 1 million hours of in-service operation. 
Finally, at Systems, earlier this year, we acquired a small business located in Newport News, Virginia, called Airborne Tactical Advantage Company or ATAC. This business provides tactical flight training and air adversary services to the U.S. Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps using a fleet of 27 fighter and tactical aircraft, flown by former U.S. Military fighter pilots.
During the quarter, ATAC was awarded a new contract with the U.S. Navy, worth up to $43 million over the next year. ATAC's a great fit for the company, as it has significant synergies with a number of our businesses, and a good growth outlook, as we believe the U.S. DoD and foreign militaries will increasingly rely on third parties to provide live airborne threat training services.
Moving to Industrial. We saw an 8.3% increase in revenues, reflecting growth at Kautex and specialized vehicles. At specialized vehicles, we began shipping our newest Bad Boy Off Road product, the Stampede 900, a recreational 4x4 utility vehicle, with unmatched power and unrivaled hauling of storage capacity. We expect the Stampede will contribute to top line growth, as this product taps into an entirely new market for this business.
During the quarter, we also acquired Premier Engineering & Manufacturing, a producer of de-icing vehicles for the aviation industry. Premier will be part of our ground support business, which continues to grow nicely, as airlines and airports invest in our infrastructure. At Kautex, we continue to see good volume growth, reflecting ongoing adoption of our selective catalytic reduction product lines. 
Moving to Textron Aviation. Revenues were up $72 million, while profits were down $7 million. The increase in revenues reflected delivery of 45 jets in the quarter compared to 36 last year, and 23 King Airs compared to 30 last year. The increase in jets reflected 9 Latitudes, including our first delivery to NetJets. The Latitude continues to do well in the market with superior performance, range, comfort and operating cost, and customer acceptance has been strong, including sales of fractions by NetJets to their end customers. As a result, NetJets increased their total expected contract requirement from 150 to 200 units, and accelerated their delivery schedule. However, launch pricing for the Latitude has been less than what we had hoped for due to competitive dynamics in this segment of the market, resulting in a lower per plane margin contribution. Looking forward, while a large portion of our capacity is currently allocated in NetJets, we continue to see strong end customer demand, which is translated to improved pricing for second half and next year deliveries. Overall, we believe we're still on track for our Aviation segment profit outlook, although our margins will likely be at the lower end of the range, with slightly higher volumes of expected Latitudes.
Longitude development continues to progress, as we mated the wing in the cells for the aircraft fuselage on our first aircraft in May, and power the electrical distribution systems 3 weeks later. We're on track for first flight later this summer, and the aircraft continues to generate significant interest, and as customers anticipate its entry into service late next year. On the service front, we opened our newest line maintenance station in Bremen, expanding our support offerings in Germany and throughout Europe. 
Moving to the Scorpion, the program is gaining momentum, as we began the U.S. DoD accreditation process, with this week's signing of a cooperative research and development agreement with the United States Air Force. Also, production of the conforming aircraft is nearly complete, with first flight expected next month. We believe having the accreditation process underway and the conforming aircraft available for demo flights will help facilitate initial sales of the aircraft.
Last week, at Farnborough, we also announced that we were selected by the team of QinetiQ and Thales to supply Scorpion jets for their bid on the U.K.'s Air Support to Defence Operational Training program, should they win the competition.
To sum up, demand in our end markets has been challenging, but we continue to believe that our new products and recent acquisitions will continue to contribute to overall growth in revenue, earnings and cash for the year.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $328 million, up $22 million from the second quarter of 2015, on a $264 million increase in revenues.Let's review how each of the segments contributed, starting with Textron
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $328 million, up $22 million from the second quarter of 2015, on a $264 million increase in revenues.
Let's review how each of the segments contributed, starting with Textron Aviation. At Textron Aviation, revenues were up $72 million from this period last year, primarily due to volume and mix. Segment profit was $81 million, down from $88 million a year ago, primarily reflecting an unfavorable impact from the mix of products sold in the period. Backlog in the segment ended the quarter at $1.1 billion, $122 million higher than at the end of last -- at the end of the first quarter.
Moving to Bell. Revenues were down $46 million, primarily due to volume and mix. Segment profit decreased to $20 million from the second quarter of 2015, reflecting the lower volume and mix. At Textron Systems, revenues were up $165 million, primarily due to higher volumes in our weapons and sensors and unmanned product lines. Segment profit was up $39 million, reflecting the higher volumes and mix. Industrial revenues increased $77 million due to higher overall volumes and the impact of acquisitions. Segment profit increased $13 million, reflecting the higher volumes. Finance segment revenues decreased $4 million, and profit decreased $3 million. Moving below the segment line, corporate expenses were $31 million compared to $33 million last year. Interest expense was $37 million, up $5 million from last year.
On the tax front, the Internal Revenue Service approved a settlement on July 11 of our 1998 to 2008 tax years. As a result, in the third quarter, we expect to record an income tax benefit, including the reversal of accrued interest of approximately $315 million, of which approximately $200 million or $0.74 per share is attributable to continuing operations. The settlement results in an immaterial net benefit to consolidated cash during the year. 
To wrap up with guidance, we are reiterating our expected full-year EPS from continuing operations of $2.60 to $2.80 per share, exclusive of the tax settlement. We also continue to expect cash flow from continuing operations of manufacturing group before pension contributions of $600 million to $700 million.
That concludes our prepared remarks. So Stacy, we can open the line for questions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will go to Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will go to Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I wondered if you could speak to the aviation margin, and I know you talked about last quarter, when we did the incremental math, the Longitude R&D being elevated ahead of that first flight. Can you quantify how much of an impact that would have ha
componenttext: Scott, I wondered if you could speak to the aviation margin, and I know you talked about last quarter, when we did the incremental math, the Longitude R&D being elevated ahead of that first flight. Can you quantify how much of an impact that would have had on the incremental this quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Carter, I mean, it did have incremental impact for sure. It wasn't probably quite as significant as it was in the first quarter. I would say, probably most importantly from an R&D standpoint, we've -- in the first half, aviation had pretty high leve
componenttext: Well, Carter, I mean, it did have incremental impact for sure. It wasn't probably quite as significant as it was in the first quarter. I would say, probably most importantly from an R&D standpoint, we've -- in the first half, aviation had pretty high levels of spending, and that really was largely around getting ready for the Longitude first flights and flight test programs, so we've incurred an awful lot of R&D. So our total year number is still going to be about what we thought it was, but there'll be a significant reduction in the second half, just associated with the fact that we're just about complete with the high spending load on the Longitude program.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the pricing impact, you talked about on Latitude, what sort of gives you the confidence that the pricing improves as you exit this year and into next year?
componenttext: And on the pricing impact, you talked about on Latitude, what sort of gives you the confidence that the pricing improves as you exit this year and into next year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the fact that we already have a lot of aircraft sold, and so we're looking at actuals in terms of the realized pricing that we're seeing in the second half of the year and going into 2017 versus the pricing that we had realized on the aircraft that
componenttext: Well, the fact that we already have a lot of aircraft sold, and so we're looking at actuals in terms of the realized pricing that we're seeing in the second half of the year and going into 2017 versus the pricing that we had realized on the aircraft that have already shipped in the first and second quarter. So there's no change in the NetJet pricing. I mean, that's a fixed number through the period, but when you look at retail aircraft sales, whole aircraft sales to end customers, what's already in our book is higher in the back half of the year and into '17 than what we've experienced in the first half of the year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Just wanted to make sure it was in the backlog.
componenttext: Great. Just wanted to make sure it was in the backlog.

componenttextpreview: Just wondered on the Aviation side of things, so I guess, if you look classically, you do have a very healthy second half versus first half margin ramp. Should we take from your prepared comments that the margins in the back half are sort of flattish year
componenttext: Just wondered on the Aviation side of things, so I guess, if you look classically, you do have a very healthy second half versus first half margin ramp. Should we take from your prepared comments that the margins in the back half are sort of flattish year-on-year for the second half of last year in that segment?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Julian, I haven't looked, I guess, in the numbers in front me just in terms of the comparable from 2015 to '16 on the second half. But certainly, incrementally, as we're -- as we usually see, you can certainly expect better margin rates as we g
componenttext: I'm sorry, Julian, I haven't looked, I guess, in the numbers in front me just in terms of the comparable from 2015 to '16 on the second half. But certainly, incrementally, as we're -- as we usually see, you can certainly expect better margin rates as we go through the second half of the year versus the first, in part, driven by the fact that we normally have higher volumes, and we would certainly expect to see that. But also, as I mentioned, we'll have lower R&D spending as well within that segment.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But you still think you can get to about 8.5% for the year as a whole in April?
componenttext: Okay. But you still think you can get to about 8.5% for the year as a whole in April?

componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on Bell, just very quickly, any color you could provide there on the trends in the commercial side, particularly aftermarket? And I guess there, as well, the margins year-to-date running at sort of the low end of the original full-year guide, sho
componenttext: And then on Bell, just very quickly, any color you could provide there on the trends in the commercial side, particularly aftermarket? And I guess there, as well, the margins year-to-date running at sort of the low end of the original full-year guide, should we expect the sort of second half pickup in that?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we will have a second half pickup. Look, the end markets in the commercial helicopter business remained very challenging. What's most critical for us, obviously, is around our 412s. I think we still have reasonable line of sight on meeting w
componenttext: Well, I think we will have a second half pickup. Look, the end markets in the commercial helicopter business remained very challenging. What's most critical for us, obviously, is around our 412s. I think we still have reasonable line of sight on meeting where we need to be this year on 412s. As I kind of mentioned on the last quarter, we think there's some number of opportunities out there that we're working on, which hopefully will give us some better visibility into the future. But at least, in terms of how we think the year will close out at Bell, for 2016, I think it will be consistent with our expectations.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the line of Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: And we'll go to the line of Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you could just walk us around the world and talk about demands, generally speaking, across your varied segments in North America, Europe and maybe over into the Middle East and Asia.
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you could just walk us around the world and talk about demands, generally speaking, across your varied segments in North America, Europe and maybe over into the Middle East and Asia.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you looked at the Aviation, the association -- the U.S. remains probably the strongest market. We've seen in particular, earlier in the year, a little bit of an uptick in Europe, which has been encouraging. Now obviously, we saw a fair bi
componenttext: Well, I think if you looked at the Aviation, the association -- the U.S. remains probably the strongest market. We've seen in particular, earlier in the year, a little bit of an uptick in Europe, which has been encouraging. Now obviously, we saw a fair bit of dislocations here everywhere in the world in the last few weeks of the quarter, with the whole reaction of Brexit. I don't think any of that is actually fundamental at a macro level with Brexit, but just the upset in the financial markets creates a lot of uncertainty, which kind of froze things up. But I think, other than that, we've seen a bit of a strengthening in Europe. South America is still very difficult. I think there's some opportunities that are starting to show in some places like Argentina that are starting to improve modestly. But Brazil, most of the economies down there are still very, very challenged. Middle East is -- there's activity, certainly, across most of our businesses, but again, it's a challenging environment. The conflict wars are going on down there, have a lot of the governments fairly distracted and focus on pretty immediate needs as opposed to much in the way of long-term work, but there certainly are opportunities that are in the works. Southeast Asia, frankly, is probably one of the healthiest on the international markets in terms of opportunity. There's -- economies are a little more diversified and are doing okay. China continues to be okay for us. It's not the strength of the growth maybe than it was in the past, but it's -- it's certainly, generally speaking, solid, particularly in the Aviation segment. So Automotive, I think our numbers fairly well match what you see going on the world. The European market, actually, has been kind of stronger. North America's had general strength, but there's more strength in the larger vehicles and the trucks in the high-end than there are in some of the smaller models, just I think reflecting the price of gas. So I don't think that you were seeing anything probably that would surprise you a lot versus just what's going on, in general, in terms of what GDP looks like in these various regions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, Scott, you made some comments about conversations with customers on the Longitude, and I'm just wondering if you could give us a little flavor for how you think pricing is going to shape up in that, given the fact that we h
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, Scott, you made some comments about conversations with customers on the Longitude, and I'm just wondering if you could give us a little flavor for how you think pricing is going to shape up in that, given the fact that we had goal posts moved us -- on us a little bit here on the Latitude. And what kind of customer mix are you expecting out of the gate on the Longitude? Are we going to be selling into the fractional advantages just more directly into customers on a one-off basis?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, at this point, we expected to be primarily just end use customers on the Longitude. We've had kind of our normal sort of customers have been into Wichita, pretty extensively looking at the aircraft. As you might recall, we had a full, not j
componenttext: Well, I think, at this point, we expected to be primarily just end use customers on the Longitude. We've had kind of our normal sort of customers have been into Wichita, pretty extensively looking at the aircraft. As you might recall, we had a full, not just a mockup, but a full aircraft that we displayed last year, and we've kept that aircraft at the plant. We've had lots of people coming in to look at it. And with respect to pricing, I think our challenge on Latitude is that our competitor in that space has 2 aircraft, right, one, which is a little bit the smaller aircraft, which is really what we thought we would end up competing with, with the Latitude. That was sort of our intention. And then they've got us a larger aircraft, and those 2 aircraft have created a pricing problem. And I think our performance and our range were far superior to the smaller aircraft, which is where wanted to be, but just kind of using the larger aircraft to try to compete with us, and that's really what's generated a lot of the pricing problem. When you look at Longitude, that's kind of the combination now where you have the much larger aircraft. And frankly, performance and range and [indiscernible] a little bit, I think, will distinguish us very nicely from where the competition is. And so certainly, our expectation is that we have a much better pricing position because we can distance ourselves in terms of the performance and capability of that aircraft, and there's not another aircraft that a competitor has sitting on top of that to try to bring down on price to compete with it.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the line of Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll go to the line of Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was surprised that you guys didn't buy any stock in this quarter, and I know at the end of the last quarter, you only had about 4.5 million shares left in the authorization. So is this -- can you talk a little bit about, philosophically, how you're deal
componenttext: I was surprised that you guys didn't buy any stock in this quarter, and I know at the end of the last quarter, you only had about 4.5 million shares left in the authorization. So is this -- can you talk a little bit about, philosophically, how you're dealing with that, and then, typically, when does the board look at that as to whether you need to expand the buyback?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Sam, I mean, we did an awful lot of buying in the first quarter, so we did back off a little bit on the second quarter, but I wouldn't attribute to the share sort of the shelf that's sitting there. We still do have 4.5 million or so available under
componenttext: Well, Sam, I mean, we did an awful lot of buying in the first quarter, so we did back off a little bit on the second quarter, but I wouldn't attribute to the share sort of the shelf that's sitting there. We still do have 4.5 million or so available under that. But if we thought it was the right thing to do, we've had these discussions with the board, and there'd be no problem going back and extending that authorization. So it's just -- we haven't officially taken that action because we still have enough that's available to exercise under the previous authorizations that we haven't taken that from a board of action. But I mean, obviously, it would have to be a discussion with the board. We have had preliminary discussions, and I wouldn't expect that, that would be an issue.

componenttext: Scott, I don't know how far or deep you'll go, but I just wanted to stay on that last question, if possible. It would be really helpful to be able to understand likely just -- we see the headline backlog and the headline book-to-bill being better in the quarter. It'd be great to understand how much of that is NetJets Latitude aircraft folding into the back August. You've said you'll do it carefully versus something at Beech versus just pure underlying regular old business jet?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh no, again, I don't think we want to get in to the specifics on a model-by-model basis. I mean, we haven't done that in quite some time. But look, I think it's not just NetJets. I mean, I think, we've been pretty open about the fact Latitude is selling
componenttext: Oh no, again, I don't think we want to get in to the specifics on a model-by-model basis. I mean, we haven't done that in quite some time. But look, I think it's not just NetJets. I mean, I think, we've been pretty open about the fact Latitude is selling well, and our expectations for the year was that the overall market would be generally fairly flattish from last year in terms of most of the model types, and most of the growth would be driven by the big new product introduction, which in this case, this year is Latitude, and so I think that expectation is kind of what we're seeing. We are seeing good demand on the Latitude, both on the NetJets as well as on the retail side, and other models are selling fine. They're selling consistent with how we expected. Some models are stronger than others, but in general, the volume on the jet side is what we expected, and the thing that's driving the upside in terms of growth on a year-over-year basis, and then we would continue to expect to see that as we roll into next year, is based on Latitude. And so the bulk of that increase in backlog, I would say, is going to be attributed to that, both NetJets and retail sales.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, I understand the desire to not get into specific aircraft, but just the NetJets situation alone is pretty unique and you know if there were 0 NetJets brought into backlog versus if there were 15 to 20, it's a difference between your book-to-
componenttext: Okay. I mean, I understand the desire to not get into specific aircraft, but just the NetJets situation alone is pretty unique and you know if there were 0 NetJets brought into backlog versus if there were 15 to 20, it's a difference between your book-to-bill of 1.1 and of 0.8, I mean it just kind of makes a big difference. I don't know if you guys would consider breaking that out today or in the future or whatever but...

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: So look, no, I mean, we're not trying to do this on purpose. We can give you the color around sort of where it's going, but I don't think I need to damage the business by providing my competitors a whole lot of information on where we stand on sales of which aircraft.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. I understand. What's your sense, Scott, of why market-wide used inventory is now back on an upward trend in business jet?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I mean, it's -- on total, it is from the numbers, I mean, sure, I read all the stuff that you guys read, but there's an awful lot of mix down within that, right? And I would say that if you look at our aircraft, and particularly on tha
componenttext: Well, first of all, I mean, it's -- on total, it is from the numbers, I mean, sure, I read all the stuff that you guys read, but there's an awful lot of mix down within that, right? And I would say that if you look at our aircraft, and particularly on that light mid-size, it's been relatively stable, and frankly, the market's healthy. So the amount of turn, the number of aircraft sales that are going on has been fine. So when we look at the amount of used aircraft sales that we had in the quarter versus previous quarter, it's up. We see the number of transactions that are in our space involving our aircraft are -- seem to be doing fine, and we see relatively stable residual values. So there's different dynamics, obviously, in terms of what sizes of aircraft. And they're different markets, right? I mean, the heavy iron market behaves differently than the light jet market. So actually, for us, and for our customers, they're looking to sell used aircraft, buy used aircraft. It's been pretty stable, both pricing and volume.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Right. And that's kind of what I'm saying. There's just a lot of variability from aircraft model by model, sizes of aircraft that you're going to have to go through all the details, but I think in the citation side, we haven't seen much change. It looks fine.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm probably not quite ready to do '17 yet, no. But we certainly feel like our view has been generally that market's airfare are fairly flat, but new products matter, and that's what we saw last year. That's what we're seeing this year. We're not ready to
componenttext: I'm probably not quite ready to do '17 yet, no. But we certainly feel like our view has been generally that market's airfare are fairly flat, but new products matter, and that's what we saw last year. That's what we're seeing this year. We're not ready to do '17 guidance. Obviously, we still feel very good about where the Latitude is in the market, and its trend in terms of its demand, and obviously, as we get into next year, we'll hit Longitude towards the latter part of the year. So I think that will help us as well. So -- but again, I think that will be positive. Longitude will be positive. Latitude will be positive. It's too early to make a call on just sort of the base market, I guess.

componenttext: Well, I mean, there's a little bit of that, George. I'm not sure if it's just specifically oil and gas, but the King Air has had a strong international marketplace, is a big part of that business, and it's a good part of the business, and it has certainly been a little bit weaker in the first half of the year. And we have, obviously, made some accommodation for that and I think it's -- it will be a little bit weaker than we'd like it to be, but again, I think, that's mostly driven by a lot of international markets that are just a little softer right now.

componenttext: Our product pricing, in general, George, has been pretty flat. There's been a couple of models we're seeing a little bit of price. I would say, right now, pricing, by and large, is fairly stable on most of the models.

It's primarily driven by the fact that which -- as you guys know, the weapons and sensors business has a tendency to be sort of lumpy, right, because we build at a relatively stable level, but a lot of acceptance is typical with a lot of international customers, so a lot of the positive margin is the fact that we had significantly -- a significant uptick in volume in the quarter, and good execution and performance by the team in terms of getting it done and doing it productively.

componenttext: Just to follow up on systems with the small acquisition that you mentioned there, the strong margin in the quarter, can you quantify what the acquisition contributed? And would you say your expectation for sales and EBIT there is higher than it was at the beginning of the year?

componenttext: The acquisition didn't play a whole lot into this thing. I mean, as you expect an initial year of a deal like that, there's step-up, there's the normal accounting first year. So I would say it's relatively neutral impact on 2016, and we certainly expect it to be a nice accretive contributor in 2017 and on.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with regard to cash flow, you told us in the past to expect the cash flow to be fairly back half weighted, could you -- is there any way to sort of calibrate our expectations for -- there's a lot of cash coming in, in the second half, to ca
componenttext: Okay. And then with regard to cash flow, you told us in the past to expect the cash flow to be fairly back half weighted, could you -- is there any way to sort of calibrate our expectations for -- there's a lot of cash coming in, in the second half, to calibrate our expectations for sort of Q3 versus Q4?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure we want to get into a quarter-by-quarter, but we certainly still feel confident with the numbers that we provided in terms of the overall year guidance. We've talked in the past, we know we have a headwind associated with the customer deposit
componenttext: I'm not sure we want to get into a quarter-by-quarter, but we certainly still feel confident with the numbers that we provided in terms of the overall year guidance. We've talked in the past, we know we have a headwind associated with the customer deposits, largely, the military payments, that are sort of unwinding through the course of the year, so those have been unwinding as we've gone through the first half of the year. And generally speaking, for us, we'll serve to offset an awful lot of that in Q3 and Q4 as we see working capital reductions and the loss of inventory through volume, largely in Aviation and Bell as we go through the balance of the year. And TAPV, of course, of which -- remember, we don't start deliveries of those units here until August. So that's a fair bit of inventory that we've been carrying that we'll see a significant reduction in Q3 and Q4.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we're obviously always seasonally stronger in Q4, if you just look historically, given the volumes that we see in Q4.
componenttext: And we're obviously always seasonally stronger in Q4, if you just look historically, given the volumes that we see in Q4.

componenttext: Just on Bell profitability. In terms of margins, going forward, does it remain at about a 10% rate if we assume commercial helicopter doesn't recover [ph] for some time?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sheila, that's kind of what we've talked about is probably being a 10% to 11% kind of range, and an awful lot of that will have to do with where we are, as usual, on the commercial side on 412s. So again, I think we feel pretty good about where we ar
componenttext: Yes, Sheila, that's kind of what we've talked about is probably being a 10% to 11% kind of range, and an awful lot of that will have to do with where we are, as usual, on the commercial side on 412s. So again, I think we feel pretty good about where we are for 2016, and we'll have a lot more visibility as we get to the end of the year to be able to provide guidance on where we think that'll be in 2017. But at least, so far, for this year, we're -- I think, we'll finish where we expect to be.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, just one on the broader military opportunities, Scott, if you could talk about that a little bit, whether it's the V-22 or the Scorpion, both domestically and internationally, and how you think about the programs and opportunities there.
componenttext: Got it. And then, just one on the broader military opportunities, Scott, if you could talk about that a little bit, whether it's the V-22 or the Scorpion, both domestically and internationally, and how you think about the programs and opportunities there.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the V-22, obviously, has made some progress with the Japanese deal. And those orders now are firming up and coming in being exercised, either under the Multiyear II contract or as some of the potential volume in the Multiyear III deal. There continu
componenttext: Well, the V-22, obviously, has made some progress with the Japanese deal. And those orders now are firming up and coming in being exercised, either under the Multiyear II contract or as some of the potential volume in the Multiyear III deal. There continue to be a number of conversations with international customers that are going on. I certainly still think that Israel is a potential, that was talked about for quite a while, and then sort of moved out, and there's still uncertainty around that, but I think there's still conversations going on, which are, at this point, very much government-to-government. The same is true with a couple of other countries. And so those are things, however, that would all be talked about in the context of a Multiyear III, so it's not something that's going to hit here in the next couple of years. The only ones we'll see, really, will probably be Japan in that near term. So there's certainly a lot of other discussion and opportunities dialogue going on, some which is  public, some of which is not around H-1s. The H1 is performing fabulously for the Marine Corps. It's both the utility and the intact [ph] versions of that are in the quote [ph] process and proposal processes for several potential international applications, so we'll be following that pretty closely. Scorpion is still very much a wildcard. It was a huge milestone for us to have the Air Force sign up to do the accreditation program that just happened this past week. And we've had, as you know, a number of international customers that have been looking at the aircraft. And there really have been 2 issues for them, one is how are you going to get this thing certified, so they can provide their certification on top of it. And not unreasonably, customers want to fly the production fully conforming aircraft. [ph] We have the accreditation path checked off, and here, in the next month or so, we'll be flying the first production configured aircraft. So our customers are already talking about when they're going to be able to come in and get a chance to fly the aircraft. So 2 big milestones, sort of boxes that we needed to check to get done before we can proceed with the final sales of the aircraft.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just on the Scorpion, do you think international or domestic order is more likely?
componenttext: And just on the Scorpion, do you think international or domestic order is more likely?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, international has always been the focus of the aircraft, for sure, and so those are the deals that we've been pursuing and working and staying close to those customers for a while. You know what, I think there is U.S. opportunity at some point. I th
componenttext: Well, international has always been the focus of the aircraft, for sure, and so those are the deals that we've been pursuing and working and staying close to those customers for a while. You know what, I think there is U.S. opportunity at some point. I think -- and there's been some papers here written recently, I mean, the Air Force is sort of facing the reality in the U.S. that cost matters and they need more aircraft that guys can fly and build hours. And frankly, there are a lot of missions that can be executed that don't need to have very, very, very high-end fighter capability. But those requirements, I think, are still in early formative stages within the U.S., and so we'll -- I think we'll see how that plays out here over the next year or 2.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the line of Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: And we'll go to the line of Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick program questions. Scott, on the T-6, you guys have delivered about 22 year-to-date. I'm wondering if you're thinking you'll hit 40 for the full year because that would make it kind of flat year-over-year. And I was actually thinking it
componenttext: A couple of quick program questions. Scott, on the T-6, you guys have delivered about 22 year-to-date. I'm wondering if you're thinking you'll hit 40 for the full year because that would make it kind of flat year-over-year. And I was actually thinking it would kind of trend down because I think U.S. deliveries are over. So just wondering what your thoughts are on that program going forward?

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it'll be fairly flat for the year. The U.S. program is winding down, but we've had a couple of international programs that we won, which will flush out or fill out the year. So I think '16 feels fairly solid and we'll -- deliveries will be ex
componenttext: Yes, I think it'll be fairly flat for the year. The U.S. program is winding down, but we've had a couple of international programs that we won, which will flush out or fill out the year. So I think '16 feels fairly solid and we'll -- deliveries will be exactly where we expected them to be.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last one for me. Sensor Fuzed Weapon, I think there were some news in the quarter that the State Department was actually considering blocking a sale to Saudi. I was wondering if you heard the same thing, what your thoughts were, if tha
componenttext: Okay. And then just last one for me. Sensor Fuzed Weapon, I think there were some news in the quarter that the State Department was actually considering blocking a sale to Saudi. I was wondering if you heard the same thing, what your thoughts were, if that's real or not. And I know this is a lumpy program, but I think Saudi was one of the meaningful customers, so it just raised a question in my mind there.

headline: Textron Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they're not a current customer, they're a prospective customer for sure. They have been a customer in the past, and so -- but basically, Pete, you're right, there's a lot of issues going on between the State Department, NSE, and what's going on over
componenttext: Well, they're not a current customer, they're a prospective customer for sure. They have been a customer in the past, and so -- but basically, Pete, you're right, there's a lot of issues going on between the State Department, NSE, and what's going on over the Middle East, and that is certainly, as a minimum, delaying getting approvals, whether that breaks loose and ultimately is approved or whether it's not, is still to be determined. But there's certainly an interest on their part. It's been notified to Congress in the past, it was approved through that notification process, but now going back through and getting the approval through state, it is hung up at this point.

componenttext: Doug, you're too young a man to retire. So you guys had very nice results at systems, and that's even without any shipments of TAPV that come here in the second half. On paper, it looks like systems might have some upside, is that a potential?
