headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think, in the last quarter, we have seen a pretty significant uptick in the number of orders that we booked compared to the first half of the year. Now this is still down from where it was in its peak. I mean we're not suggesting that this market
componenttext: Sure. I think, in the last quarter, we have seen a pretty significant uptick in the number of orders that we booked compared to the first half of the year. Now this is still down from where it was in its peak. I mean we're not suggesting that this market has recovered and things are great, but we had a year where order activity was extraordinarily weak. And so we are starting now to see customers that are coming forward, actually signing deals and closing contracts. And in particular, there's a number of campaigns that are in process where quotes are out there, activities happening and clearly deals are going to close. So that's the rationale for sort of our color on that. We're coming out of a year or so here of a very, very difficult environment in terms of closing any deals. And I think, in the last quarter, we saw a lot of deals closed and a lot of deals that are active and in progress. So it's -- again, it's not where things were in the great days, but it's certainly positive to see an uptick in activity in actual orders.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will go to the line of George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: We will go to the line of George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to -- the Aviation margin was somewhat lower than what I was looking for. In the second quarter, you said that you would see lower R&D on the Longitude in the third and the second half of the year, and pricing may be a little bit better. So could
componenttext: I wanted to -- the Aviation margin was somewhat lower than what I was looking for. In the second quarter, you said that you would see lower R&D on the Longitude in the third and the second half of the year, and pricing may be a little bit better. So could you just comment on that? And then also, to get to the low end of your 8.5% to 9% margin would require a margin north of 11% in the fourth quarter, so is that doable? And if not, what would you suggest is the range now?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so a couple of things, George. First of all, the R&D, as we went from Q2 to Q3, did come down in the business. And I think, if you look at -- the sequential margins are pretty good from Q2 to Q3, but if you look on a year-over-year basis, there's no
componenttext: Well, so a couple of things, George. First of all, the R&D, as we went from Q2 to Q3, did come down in the business. And I think, if you look at -- the sequential margins are pretty good from Q2 to Q3, but if you look on a year-over-year basis, there's no question that the leverage wasn't there. I'd say the -- most of that is a result of the fact that our revenue growth on a year-over-year basis was largely driven by used aircraft sales; and the inclusion of our acquisition at Able, which is a great little business but, in its first year, with deal-related costs and step-up and all that kind of stuff, its first year is kind of a breakeven. So if you look at that model, you have $50-plus million of revenue in there that's not -- that has no margin. It's used aircraft and the first year of that deal. So that's the bulk of where you don't have leverage, where you would probably have expected to see some of that leverage. And the rest of it still is this ongoing mix issue. So we did have positive pricing on the retail side on Latitude in the quarter, but it's still at lower margin rates than what we typically see in the rest of our portfolio. And obviously, all of the mix shift in the quarter, as well mentioned and you guys see the numbers in terms of aircraft, we had a couple more Mustangs. We had a couple more M2s. We certainly had more Latitudes, but we also were down a couple XLSes and Sovereigns, so from a mix standpoint, that certainly pressured some of the conversion as well on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what would you suggest now for a margin for the year, where you had been at 8.5% to 9%?
componenttext: And what would you suggest now for a margin for the year, where you had been at 8.5% to 9%?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I think that's going to be at the low end of that, George. And part of the rationale for or a large driver for the rationale for why you see us narrowing our range is that the top end of our original guidance range would have been a stronger ye
componenttext: Yes, look, I think that's going to be at the low end of that, George. And part of the rationale for or a large driver for the rationale for why you see us narrowing our range is that the top end of our original guidance range would have been a stronger year in the business jet market. Obviously, it's continued to be pretty flat, so we're probably going to be more towards that midpoint, which is why we revised our guidance. As it comes to the segment, I think we're probably expecting something more around a 10% kind of margin rate in the quarter for Aviation, as opposed to something that would be high enough to bring it up into the midpoint of its range.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if you could -- aftermarket growth in the quarter if you took out Able, so on an organic basis, what was that?
componenttext: Okay. And then if you could -- aftermarket growth in the quarter if you took out Able, so on an organic basis, what was that?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pretty flat.
componenttext: Pretty flat.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: And we'll go to Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, these are a little bit deeper into the TAPV programs. Suggested volumes are going to be a little lower than initially expected. Can you tell us why and what's expected going forward and then just comment as to the inventory levels on the balance sh
componenttext: Scott, these are a little bit deeper into the TAPV programs. Suggested volumes are going to be a little lower than initially expected. Can you tell us why and what's expected going forward and then just comment as to the inventory levels on the balance sheet related in part to the TAPV program?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we did make initial deliveries in the quarter. We're kind of going through that process and dealing with normal -- I'd say normal. I mean we had more issues just in terms of consistency in that and flowing vehicles through that process than we wo
componenttext: Sure. So we did make initial deliveries in the quarter. We're kind of going through that process and dealing with normal -- I'd say normal. I mean we had more issues just in terms of consistency in that and flowing vehicles through that process than we would have expected. The good news is we are now -- we're making deliveries every week. And we have an agreement with the customer on how many units they're taking. And that process appears to be flowing, but it is at a lower level than we would have originally planned in our AOP. So we will make a fair number of deliveries here in the fourth quarter. We will certainly not get to where we would have expected to be. And that's part of our cash pressure, right? So we will have higher finished goods inventory on the TAPV program than we would have expected in our plan. So that is certainly a significant part of the downward revision on our cash for the year. So again, there's no major issue there. The vehicles -- every week, we're delivering vehicles. Vehicles are going in and being delivered to the customer, but it's at a lower run rate than we would have planned.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then Scott, really quickly on business jets, can you just talk a little bit about the fourth quarter setup here? Does this fourth quarter feel similar to what you've experienced going into the fourth quarters over the last couple of years
componenttext: Okay, great. And then Scott, really quickly on business jets, can you just talk a little bit about the fourth quarter setup here? Does this fourth quarter feel similar to what you've experienced going into the fourth quarters over the last couple of years with regard to how may bookings you have in hand, with the pipeline; and how we closed out the year? Is it going to be as [indiscernible] as we've experienced here over the last few years?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jason, we normally have still aircraft to sell. The good news is in terms -- so things like the Latitude are in a very solid position, but there are still aircraft to sell. And we are closing orders, which is kind of what we expect to see happening.
componenttext: Well, Jason, we normally have still aircraft to sell. The good news is in terms -- so things like the Latitude are in a very solid position, but there are still aircraft to sell. And we are closing orders, which is kind of what we expect to see happening. We have NBAA coming up here in a couple weeks, which is usually a pretty significant event in terms of customer interactions, and we would expect to see a number of closings come out of that as well. So it's kind of where we've been. We always have aircraft to sell.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: And we'll go to Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, on the incremental Scorpion spend, you've talked a little bit about it, but are -- can you give us an updated sense of when you're expecting certification from the Air Force? And I don't know what else you'd be comfortable talking about in terms of
componenttext: Scott, on the incremental Scorpion spend, you've talked a little bit about it, but are -- can you give us an updated sense of when you're expecting certification from the Air Force? And I don't know what else you'd be comfortable talking about in terms of maybe expectations for a first order or a first delivery.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't have a firm date yet with the Air Force. Our teams and the certification folks are down the right path, are working together very carefully. I mean it's, frankly, quite busy. I mean there's a lot of activity going on, a lot of detailed test
componenttext: Well, we don't have a firm date yet with the Air Force. Our teams and the certification folks are down the right path, are working together very carefully. I mean it's, frankly, quite busy. I mean there's a lot of activity going on, a lot of detailed test plans being finalized. And they've been reviewed, so it's in the throes of the process you'd expect, I mean. So it's a very active sort of program. We did a lot of work here over the last month, obviously, to get ready to do a weapons drop, which was very successful, last week. So that was above and beyond certification work, a demonstration of its capability, which I think was important to our prospective customers and was being watched very carefully. The acceleration on the production process, maturing, obviously. We've been always planning to do this initial-production configuration aircraft to support certification program, but given the little activity, we've gone ahead and sort of pulled the trigger on initiating a small production build to help validate our manufacturing processes as well. So -- but we have a lot of customer conversation going on right now. We think there's a number of opportunities to demonstrate this aircraft. We have a bunch of customers that want to fly the aircraft. And that's really what led us to accelerate both the expense side as well as to bring in the inventory and initiate kind the of a limited rate of production, because we need to have these assets available for customer demonstrations, customer flights and, hopefully, eventually customer sales. So I won't provide any color, I don't think, on specific closure date of any particular contract, but there is a lot of customer activity and a lot of discussions ongoing.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, so you're feeling good about that program. Just one follow-up on Bell: Your comments on the market, does that include 412? That was kind of a rough quarter for the 412. Are there campaigns out there? Are you feeling the 412 will come back? And
componenttext: Okay, okay, so you're feeling good about that program. Just one follow-up on Bell: Your comments on the market, does that include 412? That was kind of a rough quarter for the 412. Are there campaigns out there? Are you feeling the 412 will come back? And then if you could just update us on the 525. Are flight testers still suspended, or not?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the 412 is certainly a very important part of what we see in the -- in sort of this recovery. There is a number of 412s deals that have closed, and there is a number of 412 opportunities that are out there that are actively in negotiations. So I
componenttext: Sure. So the 412 is certainly a very important part of what we see in the -- in sort of this recovery. There is a number of 412s deals that have closed, and there is a number of 412 opportunities that are out there that are actively in negotiations. So I think the 412 is an important part of what we see making a turn as we go into '17 and beyond. So that's very positive. With respect to the 525, again, this is an NTSB-run investigation. They are managing that process. We're obviously cooperating and supporting them in every way that we can. The flight test program is still not moving forward. We have teams that are making preparations for what return to flight looks like and being ready to do that. We also obviously continue to do all the non-flight test-related certification work, which is continuing to progress well. So we don't have a time or a date on the exact return to flight. That's a process we'll have to manage through working with the NTSB and the FAA, but that investigation work continues to progress.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And we'll go to Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your corporate expense was up, I mean. Was most of that the accelerated spending on Scorpion? And if so, how does that change your R&D expectation and corporate expense expectation for the full year?
componenttext: So your corporate expense was up, I mean. Was most of that the accelerated spending on Scorpion? And if so, how does that change your R&D expectation and corporate expense expectation for the full year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's probably about half-and-half split, Cai, between the accelerated spending on the Scorpion program which is flowing through there; and also the stock-based comp because we had a revision down a year ago, so the relative year-over-year comparison
componenttext: Well, it's probably about half-and-half split, Cai, between the accelerated spending on the Scorpion program which is flowing through there; and also the stock-based comp because we had a revision down a year ago, so the relative year-over-year comparison is up. So it's kind of split between those 2 factors, about $0.03 to $0.04 each kind of an impact. And I would expect to see that flow continuing through the fourth quarter as we continue the spending on the Scorpion program, getting to first flight; and continuing the work, the certification and manufacturing process validation programs.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Cai, as you know, on the corporate expense line, it obviously will depend on what happens with stock price in the fourth quarter. And there is always those impacts, but it's -- it will probably be a touch higher than we had originally guided in terms o
componenttext: So Cai, as you know, on the corporate expense line, it obviously will depend on what happens with stock price in the fourth quarter. And there is always those impacts, but it's -- it will probably be a touch higher than we had originally guided in terms of total year. And it's -- in terms of total R&D, it's not -- it won't change the total R&D spend [indiscernible].

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not a material number to the total R&D of the company, Cai, but the R&D -- I would expect a continuing pace on the Scorpion program, as we've accelerated that, but obviously the stock-based comp piece is a whole separate issue in terms of what that i
componenttext: It's not a material number to the total R&D of the company, Cai, but the R&D -- I would expect a continuing pace on the Scorpion program, as we've accelerated that, but obviously the stock-based comp piece is a whole separate issue in terms of what that is in the fourth quarter.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, but -- so the guide actually was narrowed. And so it sounds like we're talking $0.07, $0.08 incremental spending on Scorpion, so is there an offset to that, a lower tax rate, stronger ops in terms of the outlook?
componenttext: Right, but -- so the guide actually was narrowed. And so it sounds like we're talking $0.07, $0.08 incremental spending on Scorpion, so is there an offset to that, a lower tax rate, stronger ops in terms of the outlook?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say all of the above, Cai. I mean I think we've seen -- if you looked at kind of where we thought from the beginning of the year, I think Bell is performing very strongly. I think the Systems business is performing very well even in light of chall
componenttext: I would say all of the above, Cai. I mean I think we've seen -- if you looked at kind of where we thought from the beginning of the year, I think Bell is performing very strongly. I think the Systems business is performing very well even in light of challenges around the delays on the TAPV program. Industrial guys are doing quite well. And again, Aviation, I think, is -- they're performing well in a very difficult environment. We're probably not going to get the kind of leveraging growth that we would like to have seen to be towards the top end, but then we're throwing a [ph] little bit of the acceleration on Scorpion. That's kind of where we end up with all those puts and takes, around the midpoint of what we guided.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Last one: If you look at Bell, if you hit your target on V-22s, they're going to be down a lot in the fourth quarter. And so even if you get a pickup in commercial, and certainly based on third quarter, you've got a long way to go, Bell looks like
componenttext: Got it. Last one: If you look at Bell, if you hit your target on V-22s, they're going to be down a lot in the fourth quarter. And so even if you get a pickup in commercial, and certainly based on third quarter, you've got a long way to go, Bell looks like it has a tougher fourth quarter coming up. Is your guidance there changed for the year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think there's -- again, the performance of Bell all year has been strong. I think the productivity that we've expected has been delivered on, and I think the team will close out on a strong year.
componenttext: No. I think there's -- again, the performance of Bell all year has been strong. I think the productivity that we've expected has been delivered on, and I think the team will close out on a strong year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll go to Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit more about the restructuring? You increased it from what you thought at the end of August. You mentioned, mostly on the Aviation side. Is there a driver there? Is it that the pricing you thought might come through didn't, that
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit more about the restructuring? You increased it from what you thought at the end of August. You mentioned, mostly on the Aviation side. Is there a driver there? Is it that the pricing you thought might come through didn't, that causes you to want to restructure your costs? Can you talk a little bit about that?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Sam, I wouldn't attribute it directly to pricing, but I'd say obviously the aviation market continues to be challenging. And while we're pleased with the impact the new products were having, the legacy historic market is still a challenge. And as we
componenttext: Well, Sam, I wouldn't attribute it directly to pricing, but I'd say obviously the aviation market continues to be challenging. And while we're pleased with the impact the new products were having, the legacy historic market is still a challenge. And as we look at what we need to do to try to sustain margins and keep the business productive and competitive, we thought the most appropriate way to do that was looking in other cost restructuring there. We're doing the bulk of it, frankly, through a voluntary program, which has been well received, but we really keep costs in-line in a challenging market. It felt we -- it was appropriate at this time to do that. So -- and that's driving the bulk of the net add to the restructuring program. We obviously understood what we needed to do with our exit of the weapons business and overall what's going on across the Systems segment, but it was the right time to take an action in the Aviation side as well just given the overall weak demand environment in that industry.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the $100 million to $120 million of actual outlays, is that all in 2016?
componenttext: And the $100 million to $120 million of actual outlays, is that all in 2016?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It will be split between '16 and '17, Sam, so it's probably -- it will probably be close to half this year and half into '17. And a lot of that is severance. And while we have -- some of the severance costs will be borne this year, a fair bit of that
componenttext: No. It will be split between '16 and '17, Sam, so it's probably -- it will probably be close to half this year and half into '17. And a lot of that is severance. And while we have -- some of the severance costs will be borne this year, a fair bit of that will roll over into the beginning of 2017.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question, just looking at even the new manufacturing cash flow guidance, a pretty substantial step-up in Q4, over $500 million probably, in free cash. What is it that drives that big step-up?
componenttext: Okay. And then last question, just looking at even the new manufacturing cash flow guidance, a pretty substantial step-up in Q4, over $500 million probably, in free cash. What is it that drives that big step-up?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we typically see a fairly strong quarter on the Aviation side, all of that inventory which has been accumulating throughout the course of the year, which is pretty normal for us. I think we'll also see -- again, we are starting to flow more deliveri
componenttext: Well, we typically see a fairly strong quarter on the Aviation side, all of that inventory which has been accumulating throughout the course of the year, which is pretty normal for us. I think we'll also see -- again, we are starting to flow more deliveries on the vehicle side of the business, which is largely direct conversion into cash. So those are probably 2 of the biggest movers.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the line of Sheila Kahyaoglu with Jefferies.
componenttext: And we'll go to the line of Sheila Kahyaoglu with Jefferies.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the restructuring. I guess, how are you guys thinking about it across the segments? I've seen some announcements in Aviation and within Industrial. Anything in Bell? And then also, how do you think about the payback there for 2017?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the restructuring. I guess, how are you guys thinking about it across the segments? I've seen some announcements in Aviation and within Industrial. Anything in Bell? And then also, how do you think about the payback there for 2017?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the bulk of the restructuring activity that we've added, obviously, was Aviation. So the previous restructuring, and we talked about it, was largely Systems driven. There is some associated with the move of Jacobsen into the specialized vehicle busines
componenttext: So the bulk of the restructuring activity that we've added, obviously, was Aviation. So the previous restructuring, and we talked about it, was largely Systems driven. There is some associated with the move of Jacobsen into the specialized vehicle business as we shut down the Charlotte manufacturing operations and move that down to Augusta. That's really the only part in the -- that's in the Industrial segment. So the bulk of it is between Systems; and now with the reductions at Aviation, pretty heavy in that segment. From a payback, Sheila, there's a combination. I mean, part of this restructuring, obviously we expect to see sort of traditional payback over typical personnel-related costs 6 to 9 months, but part of this, obviously in particular to that associated with the shutdown of Weapons and Sensors SFW line, there's no payback there, right? This is an exit of a business. So I think the right way to think about this on a go-forward basis is that we will probably see annualized benefits that are roughly equivalent to that $100 million, $120 million that we're expending.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And so within Aviation, I guess, the $30 million is roughly the payback there, not to put, pin numbers down on that. And maybe just a sort of follow-on to the Aviation margin questions, how could we think about the steady-state margin from here? I
componenttext: Got it. And so within Aviation, I guess, the $30 million is roughly the payback there, not to put, pin numbers down on that. And maybe just a sort of follow-on to the Aviation margin questions, how could we think about the steady-state margin from here? Is it the 7% to 8% mark assuming R&D is at a normalized level and the pricing dynamic continues on the Latitude?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we'll finish the year, obviously, clearly towards the low end or even a little below the initial guidance we would have given you on the Aviation segment. On a continuing basis, we're probably not ready to do 2017 guidance yet, but it'll all
componenttext: Well, I think we'll finish the year, obviously, clearly towards the low end or even a little below the initial guidance we would have given you on the Aviation segment. On a continuing basis, we're probably not ready to do 2017 guidance yet, but it'll all depend on what kind of market we see and what kind of volume leverage we think we're going to get. Right now, we're expecting most of it to be driven by Latitude next year, with a little bit of growth driven by Longitude. We're -- hopefully, get that certification done and maybe get a couple initial deliveries in the latter part of next year, but again when you look at the margin rates, it's all going to be a matter of what kind of leverage can we get. And right now, that's largely new product driven.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a last one, on King Airs. Can you talk about what you're seeing in the demand environment there?
componenttext: Okay. And then just a last one, on King Airs. Can you talk about what you're seeing in the demand environment there?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So King Air deliveries were pretty flat. And I think that the demand levels have been pretty steady through the course of the year. They're obviously lower than they were last year. I think we had a good quarter with flat deliveries. One of the challenges
componenttext: So King Air deliveries were pretty flat. And I think that the demand levels have been pretty steady through the course of the year. They're obviously lower than they were last year. I think we had a good quarter with flat deliveries. One of the challenges for the King Air obviously is it's a more international product. And I would say, probably about where we are right now, we're about 2/3 U.S., 1/3 international on the King Airs. And international markets have been somewhat more challenged than the U.S. market, so -- but anyway, we feel good about the King Air where it is. And sales have been kind of holding in there, and it continues to be a pretty popular product.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the line of Julian Mitchell with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll go to the line of Julian Mitchell with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question would be around capital deployment. So if I think about sort of the first half of the year, you issued debt and did some buyback. Q3, you sort of paid down some debt, no buyback. How -- has anything changed on your perspective on capital
componenttext: My first question would be around capital deployment. So if I think about sort of the first half of the year, you issued debt and did some buyback. Q3, you sort of paid down some debt, no buyback. How -- has anything changed on your perspective on capital deployment? And maybe give us some color around how you look at the sort of inorganic growth opportunities today.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Julian, I mean it's I think our perspective hasn't really changed. Obviously, we're committed to at least doing the buybacks to avoid share dilution, and that's been more than accomplished already in the buybacks that we did in the first quarter. We
componenttext: Well, Julian, I mean it's I think our perspective hasn't really changed. Obviously, we're committed to at least doing the buybacks to avoid share dilution, and that's been more than accomplished already in the buybacks that we did in the first quarter. We will continue to look at it opportunistically. As you pointed out, we did deploy capital, repaid debt here in the third quarter, which was a -- obviously something that we needed to do. In terms of on a go-forward basis, we'd -- we'll continue to provide that same guide. We're going to avoid dilution and we'll do the buybacks as we see opportunistically appropriate. On the M&A front, on a year, it's been fairly quiet here lately. I mean there's been a couple small deals like the Safeaero, which is a very nice little bolt-on for our ground support business which is doing very well for us. We're very pleased with that business. And so continuing to round out the offerings that we take through that channel to the same customers and same service and support channels makes a lot of sense to us. And on the other M&A side, we continue to kind of look at things. There's nothing large that we would say is imminent, but we're always kind of keeping an eye on opportunities that would help to strengthen and grow the businesses. But -- and clearly, we have a very lightly leveraged balance sheet. We have the capacity and the ability to do something if something comes up.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on the -- going back to the Aviation restructuring again, not so much the spending and the payback and so on but more a question around the Genesis of it. I mean it doesn't sound as if the aviation market in your perspective changed much fro
componenttext: And then just on the -- going back to the Aviation restructuring again, not so much the spending and the payback and so on but more a question around the Genesis of it. I mean it doesn't sound as if the aviation market in your perspective changed much from July, on the Q2 call, to today, so -- but at the same time, you have launched an incremental restructuring. So is it more the case that, the market, maybe back in January, you thought you'd see a bigger pickup in the second half than what you're actually seeing? Or is it the case that the market sequentially did deteriorate slightly?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julian, it's not a huge swing one way or the other. It's just been fairly flat on those legacy sides. And when we look at our cost structure, I mean, we've obviously been spending a lot of money and doing a lot of things, particularly on the R&D front and
componenttext: Julian, it's not a huge swing one way or the other. It's just been fairly flat on those legacy sides. And when we look at our cost structure, I mean, we've obviously been spending a lot of money and doing a lot of things, particularly on the R&D front and a lot of new product programs. As if you -- as you look at that, the market environment and margins and, I think, expectations for the kind of returns that we need to provide, it makes sense to take a look at it and see if there is some restructuring we'd do to try to further improve our cost position. So I don't think the market in the segments that we serve have gotten dramatically worse. They -- I -- it just continues to be sort of a stubbornly soft market. And I think that was -- our reaction is to try to improve our cost position as we fight our way through that.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

Now as you know, Seth, I mean, from quarter to quarter, it's going to be sometimes flattish, sometimes up a few points. And we expect that's kind of the trajectory that we should be on going forward.

componenttext: Nothing in particular, Seth. The Industrial segment, I mean there is obviously seasonality to some of the businesses. And we'll expect to see that normal seasonality, but if you look at the margins that we expect on a total year basis, it should be consistent with what we guided. So I don't think there's nothing notable in the segment.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple quick questions for you. Maybe I'll start off with Frank. When you look at the inventory, from quarter to quarter, it went up a couple hundred million bucks. And year-over-year, it looks like it was up, well, $700 million, $800 million. What
componenttext: Just a couple quick questions for you. Maybe I'll start off with Frank. When you look at the inventory, from quarter to quarter, it went up a couple hundred million bucks. And year-over-year, it looks like it was up, well, $700 million, $800 million. What's driving that?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, as we said, we've seen some lower deliveries on the TAPV, which has contributed to a little bit of it. But if you look at it, we started the year a couple hundred million dollars up in inventory versus the end of '15. We've -- frankly, the inve
componenttext: Yes, well, as we said, we've seen some lower deliveries on the TAPV, which has contributed to a little bit of it. But if you look at it, we started the year a couple hundred million dollars up in inventory versus the end of '15. We've -- frankly, the inventory has increased at about the same rate through 9 -- the first 9 months of '16 versus the first 9 months of '15. So we are seeing a normal trending of inventory. We do have some slightly higher inventory levels than -- in some areas, like TAPV, than we would have planned for, which is putting a little bit of pressure on cash, but it's not wildly off from what we had expected or what we have seen in previous years. Just given the seasonality of the business, there is some additional pressure or some additional inventory. And there are also for Scorpion, as we talked about, that we wouldn't have had on a year-over-year basis.

componenttextpreview: And then Scott, a lot of talk about Scorpion this morning, which -- the airplane I love. You've been talking about that one for a long time. So I think -- and maybe you've picked up a little bit of this on the call. I think there's some skepticism in the
componenttext: And then Scott, a lot of talk about Scorpion this morning, which -- the airplane I love. You've been talking about that one for a long time. So I think -- and maybe you've picked up a little bit of this on the call. I think there's some skepticism in the investor community about a company-funded defense program, right? So things like the Northrop F-20 pop up and that sort of thing. When you think about the return on investment on the Scorpion and what your expectations are for this program, how can you make us all feel comfortable that, yes, this was a good place for Textron investment money?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, Ron, I think that we've been running this program for a few years now. We've been able, for the most part, to run this thing in a way that was at a low-enough level of investment that we were making accomplishments; getting the first flights;
componenttext: Well, look, Ron, I think that we've been running this program for a few years now. We've been able, for the most part, to run this thing in a way that was at a low-enough level of investment that we were making accomplishments; getting the first flights; being able to talk to customers; and kind of feel out where -- what this market could be from just the original sort of theory of what it might be to interacting with real customers, engaging their level of interest. And so I'd say, over the last few years, we've been able to run it without sort of making it an impact that would be problematic. This is the first quarter where we've had to say, look, this is having an impact on what we would have guided you guys both in terms of expense as well as some cash impact as we build inventory to actually make a run with aircraft. This is certainly not still at a sure bet standpoint, but I mean obviously we would not do that and make those investments and take that hit in terms of near term's earnings and cash if we didn't think that the level of customer interest that we're seeing, the fact that we now have a path to certification, the fact that we've demonstrated weapons capabilities, the level of interest that we'd have from customers that we've been talking to for a number of years has become strong enough that we felt it was time to accelerate that spending and be willing to invest some of our cash to be ready to do a limited production run here. So is it a sure thing? No. Do we see that the opportunity is real and that we think that there's a real future for this thing and something that can be a profitable line of business for the company? I'd have to say the answer is yes, or we wouldn't have made the decisions to go ahead and take some pressure on earnings and pressure on cash to really take that final step and bring this thing to the market in a very real, credible way.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now -- and so maybe just one follow-on to that. When you think about the return on invested capital on this, one would think you could probably do better with this than you can with a commercial, purely commercial, program. Is that a reasonable view?
componenttext: Now -- and so maybe just one follow-on to that. When you think about the return on invested capital on this, one would think you could probably do better with this than you can with a commercial, purely commercial, program. Is that a reasonable view?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, when we look at what we believe and again the conversations with customers on where we can price this aircraft, that -- it's a very -- it's, from a customer's perspective, a very competitive price versus the options that are out there in th
componenttext: Well, I think, when we look at what we believe and again the conversations with customers on where we can price this aircraft, that -- it's a very -- it's, from a customer's perspective, a very competitive price versus the options that are out there in the market in terms of the performance that you get for the dollar, the capability per dollar. So we think we can do that; and have it be a very solid, profitable program for us.

Is that sort of how I should think about the bridge, or are there other pieces to think about?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say there's a number of pieces, as in a year, right, of cash coming in and out and inventory levels, but for sure, when you look at, there's a pressure on the restructuring cash out. There's a pressure on slower TAPV deliveries and some Scorpion
componenttext: Well, I'd say there's a number of pieces, as in a year, right, of cash coming in and out and inventory levels, but for sure, when you look at, there's a pressure on the restructuring cash out. There's a pressure on slower TAPV deliveries and some Scorpion inventory coming in, but there are some positives in other areas and some better working capital management. There's -- well, there's a lot of moving parts that sums that, but certainly the -- what you mentioned are 2 of the -- are the biggest movers in terms of contributors of the pressure.

componenttext: Well, I think we'll see some better backlog on the commercial side. componenttext: We really haven't talked about white tails for a number of years. There's -- I mean we have aircraft being delivered in the first quarter, so there's -- obviously, we plan and are -- always have inventory that rolls from year to year because it's inside the manufacturing lead time to deliver aircraft when you get into the first quarter and beginning of the second quarter, so -- but right now, as we have been doing for quite a number of years now, we're building to a forecast and we've been matching that fairly well to the demand.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just had a question on Kautex, Scott. I think you guys are building a fifth plane in China now. Can you talk about what's kind of motivating that? Does that help you gain share or your presence in China? Is it a growth signal? And frankly, is there
componenttext: Yes, I just had a question on Kautex, Scott. I think you guys are building a fifth plane in China now. Can you talk about what's kind of motivating that? Does that help you gain share or your presence in China? Is it a growth signal? And frankly, is there a long-term competitive risk to that? I'm just curious about the strategy surrounding that.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The long-term view on China is that it gets -- I mean it's a massive automotive market. It continues to grow. It's been a good market for us, frankly. We've had a very strong business in China. And as that volume continues to grow, our customers are doing
componenttext: The long-term view on China is that it gets -- I mean it's a massive automotive market. It continues to grow. It's been a good market for us, frankly. We've had a very strong business in China. And as that volume continues to grow, our customers are doing well. And we -- as you know, these programs, when you're building tanks for these platforms, they tend to be fairly long cycle, so when we commit to go and invest the capital on a new plant and a new bolt-rolling machines and stuff like that, we clearly have line of sight to where that capacity is going to be utilized and all the platforms that capacity will be utilized on. So we don't see much downside risk of underutilization of those assets. And certainly, that's been -- our history over there is that these plants are well utilized and deliver good returns.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so is there -- the more plants you build there, I guess, is there more tailwind there in terms of adding capacity and maybe shifting your customer base from European OEMs to Chinese OEMs?
componenttext: Okay, so is there -- the more plants you build there, I guess, is there more tailwind there in terms of adding capacity and maybe shifting your customer base from European OEMs to Chinese OEMs?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure we'd look at it as shifting. I mean, again, we really do this and make these decisions based on specific opportunities, specific platforms that we win, and that's what drives us. So in terms of how we think about capital allocation in t
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure we'd look at it as shifting. I mean, again, we really do this and make these decisions based on specific opportunities, specific platforms that we win, and that's what drives us. So in terms of how we think about capital allocation in that business in the future, we allocate it to the places where we've won with a customer and need to produce locally. So -- and I mean I think, if you look in that this year so far, we've actually had more growth in Europe than we've had in North America or Asia, and that's because our customers in Europe have had higher growth rates. But again, our allocation of capital and where we choose to put locations is very highly driven to how we're doing and who we're winning with on where in the world. So we really let that drive it, as opposed to a philosophy of being in one particular region or the other.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron's Third Quarter Earnings Conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Eric Sa
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron's Third Quarter Earnings Conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Eric Salander, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stacy, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our
componenttext:
Thanks, Stacy, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our SEC filings and also in today's press release. On the call today, we have Scott Donnelly, Textron's Chairman and CEO; and Frank Connor, our Chief Financial Officer. Our earnings call presentation can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website.
Textron's revenues in the quarter were $3.3 billion, up $71 million from last year's third quarter. During this year's third quarter, we recorded a $115 million pretax charge or $0.27 per share after-tax related to the restructuring plan we announced this past summer. We also recorded a tax benefit of $0.76 per share related to a settlement of U.S. Internal Revenue Service audits. Excluding these items, adjusted income from continuing operations was $0.61 per share, down $0.02 from last year's third quarter. Manufacturing cash flow before pension contributions was $94 million compared to $116 million in last year's third quarter.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everybody.2.2% increase in third quarter revenues reflected growth in Industrial and Aviation. We had good execution in the quarter, with margin improvements in our Systems and Bell businesses. Despite the increase in rev
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and good morning, everybody.
2.2% increase in third quarter revenues reflected growth in Industrial and Aviation. We had good execution in the quarter, with margin improvements in our Systems and Bell businesses. Despite the increase in revenues, adjusted earnings per share was down $0.02, primarily the result of higher corporate expenses which reflected higher stock-based compensation expense and higher spending on the Scorpion program.
At Bell, revenues were down slightly, as lower commercial units delivered in the quarter more than offset higher military volumes. Specifically, we delivered 25 commercial helicopters, down from 45 in last year's third quarter. We delivered 6 V-22s, up from 4 units last year; and 8 H-1s, up from 5 last year. Our V-280 Valor program continues to progress, with assembly of the first aircraft approximately 2/3 complete and on track for first flight next year. We also announced a new military rotor -- tiltrotor product, the Bell V-247 Vigilant. The Bell V-247 Vigilant is a Group 5 unmanned aerial system that will leverage the investment we're making in the V-280 platform. The 247 design will provide unmatched speed, payload, long endurance capabilities and runway independence to fill a multitude of missions, including maritime environments. At the AUSA show earlier this month, customer interest was high around both our V-280 mockup and the Bell V-247 model that were on display.
On the commercial side, while deliveries were down significantly in the quarter, we saw an increase in order flow. As we consider customer -- current customer activity and contract opportunities, we believe that Bell commercial helicopter demand has stabilized and may be in the early stages of recovery. On our new 505 Jet Ranger X, we continue to make progress on certification. And we expect to achieve this initial certification late this year, with deliveries beginning shortly thereafter. During the quarter, we were awarded 2 FMS contracts for 13 Huey II helicopters to be delivered in Uganda and Kenya, with deliveries beginning in the fourth quarter. Overall, given the challenging commercial markets, we had a strong quarter at Bell, as cost productivity efforts over the past several years contributed to a 13% segment margin.
Moving to Systems. Revenues were down, as high revenues at Marine and Land Systems were more than offset by lower weapon deliveries. As you know, we announced we will be discontinuing production of Sensor Fuzed Weapon in March of next year. As a result, we are taking actions now to reduce costs across the Systems segment. At TMLS, we began initial TAPV deliveries to our Canadian customer in the quarter. Looking to the fourth quarter, we have a significant ramp in deliveries, although slower than we had originally planned.
Moving to Industrial. We saw a 7% increase in revenues, reflecting the impact of acquisitions and higher volumes in our automotive and specialized vehicle businesses. Last month, we announced we'll be consolidating Jacobsen with our specialized vehicle business to optimize efficiencies and better serve the company's shared customers and distributors. Also in the vehicle business, we recently acquired Safeaero, a Swedish manufacturer of de-icers for the commercial aviation industry. Safeaero will be part of our ground support equipment portfolio, which continues to grow very nicely. In our commercial business, we introduced a new line of Cushman Hauler utility vehicles, while in our consumer product line, our distributors kicked off retail sales of our new Stampede 4x4 off-road product. At Kautex, our selective catalytic reduction product lines continued to drive growth above the current auto market.
Moving to Textron Aviation. Revenues were up $39 million in the quarter. We delivered 41 jets compared to 37 last year; and 29 King Airs, flat with last year. On the new product front, the Longitude made its first flight in October 8, marking an important achievement in its path to certification and market entry. This first flight occurred less than 1 year after unveiling the Longitude NBAA last November, demonstrating our rapid new product development cycle, with a target certification later next year. Customer anticipation of this new aircraft remained strong, as we have begun executing purchase agreements with potential customers. During the quarter, we also unveiled the Cessna Denali, our new clean-sheet single-engine pressurized turboprop. The Denali will feature superior operating performance with the only flat floor cabin design in its class and will easily convert between passenger and cargo configurations. We're now currently serving this market segment and believe the highly differentiated Denali will contribute to significant future growth in Aviation with its best-in-class performance characteristics.
Moving to Scorpion. The program continues to make good progress, and we expect first flight of our initial production aircraft very soon. Last week, we conducted successful weapons testings with our existing aircraft at U.S. Air Force white sands proving grounds. With the accreditation process now underway and customer interest increasing, we have accelerated investment in the program. We have begun building several aircraft to support the accreditation requirements, validate our manufacturing process and expand our marketing and customer engagement activities.
Moving to an update on our restructuring plan. We've announced additional headcount reductions across our businesses, principally through a voluntary separation plan in our Aviation segment; and have increased our cost estimates accordingly. To wrap up, while several of our end markets remained challenging in the third quarter, we still achieved top line growth while furthering our development efforts on major new programs.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $310 million, down $2 million from the third quarter of 2015 on a $71 million increase in revenues.Let's review how each of the segments contributed, starting with Textron A
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Segment profit in the quarter was $310 million, down $2 million from the third quarter of 2015 on a $71 million increase in revenues.
Let's review how each of the segments contributed, starting with Textron Aviation. At Textron Aviation, revenues were up $39 million from this period last year primarily due to higher preowned aircraft volume and the impact of an acquisition. Segment profit was $100 million, down from $107 million at a year ago, primarily reflecting the mix of products sold. Backlog in the segment ended the quarter at $1.1 billion, approximately flat with the second quarter.
Moving to Bell. Revenues were down $22 million primarily due to lower commercial deliveries, partially offset by higher military volumes. Segment profit decreased $2 million from the third quarter of 2015, reflecting the lower commercial aircraft deliveries. Backlog in the segment was $4.9 billion at the end of the quarter, approximately flat with the second quarter.
At Textron Systems, revenues were down $7 million, primarily due to lower weapons volume, partially offset by higher revenues at marine and land. Segment profit was up $5 million, reflecting improved performance. Backlog in the segment was $2.2 billion, down $74 million from the end of the second quarter. Industrial revenues increased $58 million due to the impact of acquired businesses and higher volumes. Segment profit increased $5 million, reflecting improved performance. Finance segment revenues increased $3 million, and profit decreased $3 million.
Moving below the segment profit. Corporate expenses were $53 million compared to $27 million last year. As Scott explained, this reflected higher stock-based compensation expense and the accelerated spending on our Scorpion program. Interest expense was $35 million, up $2 million from last year. With respect to our restructuring plan in the quarter, we recorded pretax charges of $115 million on the special charges line. Looking forward, our revised cost estimate for the total restructuring plan is now a range of $140 million to $170 million pretax, up from $110 million to $140 million, to reflect the additional reductions that Scott discussed. Cash outlays associated with this plan are now estimated to be in a range of $100 million to $120 million compared to our previous estimate of $65 million to $85 million. We recorded a total income tax benefit of $319 million in the quarter related to settlement of U.S. IRS audits for years 1998 through 2008. $206 million, or $0.76 per share, was attributable to continuing operations.
To wrap up. We are narrowing our adjusted full year EPS from continuing operations guidance to $2.65 to $2.75 a share, which corresponds to GAAP EPS of $3.06 to $3.21 per share. Given our accelerated spending on Scorpion, higher investment in restructuring and slower TAPV deliveries, we are revising our outlook for cash flow from continuing operations of the manufacturing group before pension contributions to $500 million to $600 million, down from our previous estimate of $600 million to $700 million.
That concludes our prepared remarks, so Stacy, we can open the line for questions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll go to Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gavin on for Noah. Yes, just looking at the broader business, jet market, it kind of seems like it's weakened a little bit lately, with some of your competitors announcing production rate cuts over the last couple quarters. And then you look at de
componenttext: This is Gavin on for Noah. Yes, just looking at the broader business, jet market, it kind of seems like it's weakened a little bit lately, with some of your competitors announcing production rate cuts over the last couple quarters. And then you look at deliveries, ex Latitude, mostly flat with a little bit worst mix. So I'm curious if kind of -- somewhat on the cannibalization subject, what do deliveries look like ex Latitude for the next couple years? And is there pricing pressure in the market more broadly in addition to kind of these new model introductions you have on the -- lined up?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, Gavin, I'm not sure I would try to harbor a guess at the next few years on what the market looks like, but I think that, where the market is right now, it's certainly still soft. I would say it's more or less in line with what we expected this year,
componenttext: Look, Gavin, I'm not sure I would try to harbor a guess at the next few years on what the market looks like, but I think that, where the market is right now, it's certainly still soft. I would say it's more or less in line with what we expected this year, which is to say that most of the growth is driven by the new products that are coming onto the market. That's certainly been true with Latitude. The market for the kind of the historical products is pretty flat. And yes, there continues to be a pretty tight market that it's difficult to get any kind of pricing, but it's up a little on some models and down a little on some models, so it's -- it really is consistent with what we've been seeing for the last couple years. So our plan obviously is that -- the only growth that we've been seeing has been driven by the new products coming out into the marketplace, and that's why we continue to stay focused on bringing the Longitude to the market and bringing Denali to the market, ultimately bringing the Hemisphere to the market. Because I think that's -- at least in the market environment that we exist in today, that's the only way to drive growth. And you continue to expect that the legacy historical product lines will be relatively flat.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you look at kind of the -- could you try to size maybe the net impact of membership clubs, kind of Uber for business jet, if you will, where that's much higher utilization but it's bringing in new users who potentially hadn't had access to busine
componenttext: And when you look at kind of the -- could you try to size maybe the net impact of membership clubs, kind of Uber for business jet, if you will, where that's much higher utilization but it's bringing in new users who potentially hadn't had access to business jets before?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know that I'd go all the way to the Uber side. I mean obviously we have a couple very important customers that are in the -- that sort of non-retail own-your-own aircraft market. NetJets, to the extent they're obviously selling these aircraf
componenttext: Well, I don't know that I'd go all the way to the Uber side. I mean obviously we have a couple very important customers that are in the -- that sort of non-retail own-your-own aircraft market. NetJets, to the extent they're obviously selling these aircraft to fractional customers and they're card based. NetJets has a pretty broad range of product that they provide to reach people that aren't owning their own whole aircraft. So that's an important part of where we are today with Latitudes. Obviously, on the King Air side you have guys out there like Wheels Up that are operating primarily King Airs and also aimed at a non-equity and a broader base of potential customers. So we see some of that. I mean these are very real customers that are taking delivery of aircraft and are running pretty significant businesses today and appear to be doing so successfully. How much broader we see that market or how far that reaches to what customer segments in the world, I think, is still to be determined. It's -- there are a lot of different models out there. Some of them might stick around and [ph] work. And there's other ones that may not work, but certainly we have a couple key customers that are sort of in line with, I think, kind of your questions. How do you reach a broader base of people to get into a private aircraft? And today, we certainly see that happening very successfully with both the NetJets of the world as well as the Wheels Up of the world.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: And we'll go to the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick clarification on the Scorpion comment. I think, earlier in your prepared remarks, you said higher spending. And then in most of the other places you said accelerated spending. Just want to clarify there. Is there any cost growth in the manufa
componenttext: Just a quick clarification on the Scorpion comment. I think, earlier in your prepared remarks, you said higher spending. And then in most of the other places you said accelerated spending. Just want to clarify there. Is there any cost growth in the manufacturing efforts early on? Or is this all related to pulling forward investment that you intended to do further down the line?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the increased spending is in R&D expense, right? So we're in the process of getting ready for our first flight. We've also undertaken some things like going out and doing actual weapons deliveries. So the cost of those kinds of activities, obviously
componenttext: Yes, the increased spending is in R&D expense, right? So we're in the process of getting ready for our first flight. We've also undertaken some things like going out and doing actual weapons deliveries. So the cost of those kinds of activities, obviously a lot of the cost is around bringing the first production unit to the market and developing our manufacturing processes we -- as we start sort of what I'll refer to as a limited-rate production run. Our expenses, we've accelerated. So these are things that certainly could have been put off and originally would have been done in the future. But I think as we've established this creative with the Air Force and now have a path to certification, the level of activity with customers has stepped up considerably. And it's the right time for us to sort of step up and demonstrate this aircraft and its performance capability and get much more aggressive about the marketing and test flights. And I think it's the right time, based on what's going on in the customer community, to really mature this program. And so those are largely expenses that we've pulled forward because we think we need to do it now. I think waiting a year or spreading it out over a longer period of time won't help us given the opportunities that we see out there in the not-too-distant future.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's great color. And then on the comment you made regarding demand stabilization and potential recovery at Bell, I wondered if you might just give us a little bit more color there and what's driving that view? Is it customer pipeline and c
componenttext: Okay, great. That's great color. And then on the comment you made regarding demand stabilization and potential recovery at Bell, I wondered if you might just give us a little bit more color there and what's driving that view? Is it customer pipeline and conversations? I mean obviously the backlog was flat year-over-year -- or sequentially. Any more color on that would be helpful.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think, in the last quarter, we have seen a pretty significant uptick in the number of orders that we booked compared to the first half of the year. Now this is still down from where it was in its peak. I mean we're not suggesting that this market
componenttext: Sure. I think, in the last quarter, we have seen a pretty significant uptick in the number of orders that we booked compared to the first half of the year. Now this is still down from where it was in its peak. I mean we're not suggesting that this market has recovered and things are great, but we had a year where order activity was extraordinarily weak. And so we are starting now to see customers that are coming forward, actually signing deals and closing contracts. And in particular, there's a number of campaigns that are in process where quotes are out there, activity's happening and clearly deals are going to close. So that's the rationale for sort of our color on that. We're coming out of a year or so here of a very, very difficult environment in terms of closing any deals. And I think, in the last quarter, we saw a lot of deals close and a lot of deals that are active and in progress. So it's -- again, it's not where things were in the great days, but it's certainly positive to see an uptick in activity in actual orders.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will go to the line of George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: We will go to the line of George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, [indiscernible] the Aviation margin was somewhat lower than what I was looking for. In the second quarter, you said that you would see lower R&D on the Longitude in the third -- in the second half of the year, and pricing may be a little bit better.
componenttext: Yes, [indiscernible] the Aviation margin was somewhat lower than what I was looking for. In the second quarter, you said that you would see lower R&D on the Longitude in the third -- in the second half of the year, and pricing may be a little bit better. So could you just comment on that? And then also, to get to the low end of your 8.5% to 9% margin would require a margin north of 11% in the fourth quarter, so is that doable? And if not, what would you suggest is the range now?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so a couple things, George. First of all, the R&D, as we went from Q2 to Q3, did come down in the business. And I think, if you look at -- the sequential margins are pretty good from Q2 to Q3, but if you look on a year-over-year basis, there's no qu
componenttext: Well, so a couple things, George. First of all, the R&D, as we went from Q2 to Q3, did come down in the business. And I think, if you look at -- the sequential margins are pretty good from Q2 to Q3, but if you look on a year-over-year basis, there's no question that the leverage wasn't there. I'd say the -- most of that is a result of the fact that our revenue growth on a year-over-year basis was largely driven by used aircraft sales; and the inclusion of our acquisition at Able, which is a great little business but, in its first year, with deal-related costs and step-up and all that kind of stuff, its first year is kind of a breakeven. So if you look at that model, you have $50-plus million of revenue in there that's not -- that has no margin. It's used aircraft and the first year of that deal. So that's the bulk of where you don't have leverage, where you would probably have expected to see some of that leverage. And the rest of it still is this ongoing mix issue. So we did have positive pricing on the retail side on Latitude in the quarter, but it's still at lower margin rates than what we typically see in the rest of our portfolio. And obviously, all of the mix shift in the quarter, as we'll mention and you guys see the numbers in terms of aircraft, we had a couple more Mustangs. We had a couple more M2s. We certainly had more Latitudes, but we also were down a couple XLSes and Sovereigns, so from a mix standpoint, that certainly pressured some of the conversion as well on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what would you suggest now for a margin for the year, where you had been at 8.5% to 9%?
componenttext: And what would you suggest now for a margin for the year, where you had been at 8.5% to 9%?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I think that's going to be at the low end of that, George. And part of the rationale for or a large driver for the rationale for why you see us narrowing our range is that the top end of our original guidance range would have been a stronger ye
componenttext: Yes, look, I think that's going to be at the low end of that, George. And part of the rationale for or a large driver for the rationale for why you see us narrowing our range is that the top end of our original guidance range would have been a stronger year in the business jet market. Obviously, it's continued to be pretty flat, so we're probably going to be more towards that midpoint, which is why we revised our guidance. As it comes to the segment, I think we're probably expecting something more around the 10% kind of margin rate in the quarter for Aviation, as opposed to something that would be high enough to bring it up into the midpoint of its range.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then if you could -- aftermarket growth in the quarter if you took out Able, so on an organic basis, what was that?

componenttext: Pretty flat.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, can you dive a bit deeper into the TAPV program? You suggested volumes are going to be a little lower than initially expected. Can you tell us why and what's expected going forward and then just comment as to whether the inventory levels on the bal
componenttext: Scott, can you dive a bit deeper into the TAPV program? You suggested volumes are going to be a little lower than initially expected. Can you tell us why and what's expected going forward and then just comment as to whether the inventory levels on the balance sheet are related in part to the TAPV program?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we did make the initial deliveries in the quarter. Kind of going through that process and dealing with normal -- I'd say normal -- I mean we had more issues just in terms of consistency in that and flowing vehicles through that process than we wo
componenttext: Sure. So we did make the initial deliveries in the quarter. Kind of going through that process and dealing with normal -- I'd say normal -- I mean we had more issues just in terms of consistency in that and flowing vehicles through that process than we would have expected. The good news is we are now -- we're making deliveries every week. And we have an agreement with the customer on how many units they're taking. And that process appears to be flowing, but it is at a lower level than we would have originally planned in our AOP. So we will make a fair number of deliveries here in the fourth quarter. We will certainly not get to where we would have expected to be. And that's part of our cash pressure, right? So we will have higher finished goods inventory on the TAPV program than we would have expected in our plan. So that is certainly a significant part of the downward revision on our cash for the year. So yes, there's no major issue there. The vehicles -- every week, we're delivering vehicles. Vehicles are going in and being delivered to the customer, but it's at a lower run rate than we would have planned.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, Scott, really quickly on business jets, can you just talk a little bit about the fourth quarter setup here? Does this fourth quarter feel similar to what you've experienced going into the fourth quarters over the last couple of year
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, Scott, really quickly on business jets, can you just talk a little bit about the fourth quarter setup here? Does this fourth quarter feel similar to what you've experienced going into the fourth quarters over the last couple of years with regard to how may bookings you have in hand, the pipeline and how we closed out the year? Is it going to be this season as strong as we've experienced here over the last few years?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jason, I mean, as we normally have still aircraft to sell. The good news is in terms -- so things like the Latitude are in a very solid position, but there are still aircraft to sell. And we are closing orders, which is kind of what we expect to see
componenttext: Well, Jason, I mean, as we normally have still aircraft to sell. The good news is in terms -- so things like the Latitude are in a very solid position, but there are still aircraft to sell. And we are closing orders, which is kind of what we expect to see happening. We have NBAA coming up here in a couple weeks, which is usually a pretty significant event in terms of customer interactions, and we would expect to see a number of closings come out of that as well. So it's kind of where we've been. We always have aircraft to sell.
